description: The Becoming a Linux System Administrator covers managing Linux systems in a business environment. Topics covered include installing Linux, managing software and using centralized user directories among others. The primary goal of the course is to highlight the differences in managing Linux machines in a business environment versus stand-alone or home systems.

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.361
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.361 --> 00:00:09.726
Hello, Becoming a Linux System
Administrator is an exciting series we're

3
00:00:09.726 --> 00:00:13.150
offering here at ITProTV, and
to tell us more is Don Pezet.

4
00:00:13.150 --> 00:00:14.238
Don, tell us more about the course.

5
00:00:14.238 --> 00:00:18.050
>> All right, so Becoming a Linux
System Administrator is a course that's

6
00:00:18.050 --> 00:00:22.370
designed to really take your skills with
Linux and move them up to the next level.

7
00:00:22.370 --> 00:00:26.580
A lot of people use Linux as an operating
system, and it's used on servers across

8
00:00:26.580 --> 00:00:29.720
the world, a lot of the Internet
services we access use Linux.

9
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:32.070
But even on the desktop,
there's plenty of people like me,

10
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:34.986
where I'm running Linux right here
on my own desktop, and that's great.

11
00:00:34.986 --> 00:00:38.230
If you're just an individual,
it works really well.

12
00:00:38.230 --> 00:00:42.563
But when you move into the business world,
and now you're managing desktops and

13
00:00:42.563 --> 00:00:46.067
laptops for hundreds, thousands,
tens of thousands of users,

14
00:00:46.067 --> 00:00:48.438
things are a little bit different, right?

15
00:00:48.438 --> 00:00:51.629
If I just wanna install software for
myself, that's no big deal, but

16
00:00:51.629 --> 00:00:54.985
if I wanna install software for
100 people, that's much different,

17
00:00:54.985 --> 00:00:57.170
it's a different type of experience.

18
00:00:57.170 --> 00:01:02.663
And so in the Becoming
a Linux System Administrator series.

19
00:01:02.663 --> 00:01:03.582
>> You got it.
>> I know, it's tough.

20
00:01:03.582 --> 00:01:06.120
[LAUGH] In this series,

21
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:10.180
we take a look at what those skills are,
how things are different.

22
00:01:10.180 --> 00:01:14.010
Really, we can almost call this
series Linux in the Business, right?

23
00:01:14.010 --> 00:01:16.800
Instead of using it for
a personal computer or

24
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:20.170
just as a hobbyist type thing,
how is it used in a business?

25
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:24.000
And how is that different than
administering a system just for ourselves?

26
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:26.093
And that's really what we'll get a chance
to see right here in this series.

27
00:01:26.093 --> 00:01:28.946
>> And Don, who would benefit
most from watching the Becoming

28
00:01:28.946 --> 00:01:31.280
a Linux System Administrator series?

29
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:34.950
>> Well, really, anybody who uses Linux
would benefit from it, but really,

30
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:37.260
it's gonna be people using
Linux in the workplace.

31
00:01:37.260 --> 00:01:38.930
There's some of the things we learn,

32
00:01:38.930 --> 00:01:42.030
like configuring multiple
user accounts on a system.

33
00:01:42.030 --> 00:01:44.950
Well, if it's your home computer, you're
probably the only person who uses it,

34
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:46.940
you're not gonna need
multiple user accounts.

35
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:50.430
But in a workplace,
it's very common to have shared computers,

36
00:01:50.430 --> 00:01:52.940
where you might have ten different
employees that could sit down and

37
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:54.700
use a computer at a particular time.

38
00:01:54.700 --> 00:01:56.420
And that's something we have to support.

39
00:01:56.420 --> 00:02:01.478
So if you're using Linux in the workplace,
this series is really gonna benefit you.

40
00:02:01.478 --> 00:02:05.950
Now, if you're a home user, but you're
thinking about getting a job supporting

41
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:09.390
Linux in the workplace, then again, this
is gonna be a great skill set to have,

42
00:02:09.390 --> 00:02:12.080
that you'll be able to use when you
get out there in the workforce.

43
00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:13.510
So either side can benefit,

44
00:02:13.510 --> 00:02:16.780
but really, it is geared towards people
supporting Linux in the workplace.

45
00:02:16.780 --> 00:02:18.797
>> Now,
is there a certification that you can get?

46
00:02:18.797 --> 00:02:21.449
>> There are a number of
certifications that are out there, but

47
00:02:21.449 --> 00:02:23.940
this particular series
isn't built around them.

48
00:02:23.940 --> 00:02:27.540
We wanted to focus specifically on the
skills that you needed to support Linux

49
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:29.800
from that system administrator type role.

50
00:02:29.800 --> 00:02:34.217
There are certifications, like the CompTIA
Linux+ and the LPIC-1 certification,

51
00:02:34.217 --> 00:02:37.710
that both cover everything I'm
gonna cover here in this series.

52
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:40.820
But they cover a lot more, also,
they go well beyond it, and so

53
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:43.410
they're really designed for
more advanced Linux users.

54
00:02:43.410 --> 00:02:45.027
If you're just getting started
in system administration,

55
00:02:45.027 --> 00:02:45.828
that can be really daunting.

56
00:02:45.828 --> 00:02:49.174
So we wanted to focus on the core
tasks that were really important,

57
00:02:49.174 --> 00:02:53.150
the things that, really, you need
to know out there in the workplace.

58
00:02:53.150 --> 00:02:56.710
And then once you've got a grasp of that
and a firm understanding, then you can

59
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:59.520
start studying the more advanced things
and move on to those other certifications.

60
00:02:59.520 --> 00:03:02.000
We've already got those courses
on the ITProTV site, so for

61
00:03:02.000 --> 00:03:04.910
those of you who are ready for
that, you can jump right to it.

62
00:03:04.910 --> 00:03:07.380
But for everybody else,
this is where we'll want to start.

63
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:09.760
>> And
what topics are covered in this series?

64
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:13.610
>> All right, so we cover a lot of neat
things, and this is an evolving course, so

65
00:03:13.610 --> 00:03:15.170
we can always add more things to it later.

66
00:03:15.170 --> 00:03:17.360
But the core things that
we're gonna cover are,

67
00:03:17.360 --> 00:03:18.990
first off, learning system administration.

68
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:21.620
So what do we mean by
system administration, and

69
00:03:21.620 --> 00:03:24.720
why is that different than
on a personal computer?

70
00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:27.060
Then we'll take a look
at installing Linux.

71
00:03:27.060 --> 00:03:30.250
I know it seems like installing Linux is
pretty easy, you boot the computer up and

72
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:31.407
you press next 15 times.

73
00:03:31.407 --> 00:03:32.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

74
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:35.443
there's a lot of choices you can
manipulate in there that change the way

75
00:03:35.443 --> 00:03:38.840
the computer behaves, and so we're gonna
take a look at how that gets installed.

76
00:03:38.840 --> 00:03:40.260
Then we'll take a look at getting and

77
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:44.770
managing software, how we load software on
the system, how we keep it up to date, and

78
00:03:44.770 --> 00:03:47.830
how we can manage that and
control people's access to it.

79
00:03:47.830 --> 00:03:49.560
Then we take a look at
managing user accounts.

80
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:52.068
I mentioned in the workplace,
it's not uncommon to have shared systems.

81
00:03:52.068 --> 00:03:56.097
So how do we control user access, and
restrict access to some people and

82
00:03:56.097 --> 00:03:57.780
allow access to others?

83
00:03:57.780 --> 00:03:59.305
We'll get a chance to see that.
And then finally,

84
00:03:59.305 --> 00:04:03.837
we'll talk about managing disks and file
systems, how we control the way that our

85
00:04:03.837 --> 00:04:08.236
hard drives are presented to the operating
system, who has access to what, and

86
00:04:08.236 --> 00:04:11.080
the other resources that
are found inside of that.

87
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:14.312
So all of this is kinda pertaining to
keeping our system up and running, and

88
00:04:14.312 --> 00:04:17.543
healthy, and the things that we do in
the workplace, things like adding or

89
00:04:17.543 --> 00:04:20.555
replacing a hard drive, and
how that's reflected inside of the OS.

90
00:04:20.555 --> 00:04:24.370
Those are things we need to know if we're
going to be a system administrator.

91
00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:27.630
>> So if Becoming a Linux System
Administrator sounds interesting to you,

92
00:04:27.630 --> 00:04:30.850
make sure you check out all the videos,
all the lessons in the series.

93
00:04:30.850 --> 00:04:37.172
Thank you for watching.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Don explore graphical tools that can be used to help manage systems. First, they look at OS integrated features such as, system-config commands. Next, they look at tools specific to the window manager GNOME. Lastly, they cover some web based third party tools such as Webmin, Cockpit, and CUPS.
episodes.title: Graphical Administration Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:06.624
Welcome to ITPRO TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.624 --> 00:00:08.509
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.509 --> 00:00:12.178
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.178 --> 00:00:14.867
>> Welcome to Becoming
a Linux System Admin series,

5
00:00:14.867 --> 00:00:17.280
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.280 --> 00:00:20.590
In this episode we're going to be
taking a look at how we can utilize

7
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:25.160
graphical tools within a Linux
environment for management purposes.

8
00:00:25.160 --> 00:00:28.690
Back in studio, with us today, we have Mr.
Don Pezet, how's it going, Don?

9
00:00:28.690 --> 00:00:29.870
>> Hey, it is going great, Cherokee.

10
00:00:29.870 --> 00:00:32.210
Ready to jump right back
into the world of Linux.

11
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:34.955
And this is gonna be a fun episode
because we're gonna learn about system

12
00:00:34.955 --> 00:00:37.662
administration, which, you know,
can be a little bit challenging.

13
00:00:37.662 --> 00:00:41.584
But we're gonna learn about the graphical
user interface tools that are available to

14
00:00:41.584 --> 00:00:44.700
help us do that, so it's not such
a nightmare like a lot of us think.

15
00:00:44.700 --> 00:00:47.520
So we got all that lined up,
right here in this episode.

16
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:50.420
>> Now Don, because there are so
many variants or flavors of

17
00:00:50.420 --> 00:00:53.560
Linux distributions, the tools that
were gonna be looking at in this show.

18
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:57.710
Are they applicable to all those different
flavors, or what are we talking about?

19
00:00:57.710 --> 00:00:59.230
>> I have to be noncommittal on that one.

20
00:00:59.230 --> 00:01:01.090
Because some of the stuff that
we see in this episode, yes,

21
00:01:01.090 --> 00:01:02.800
is available on every distro.

22
00:01:02.800 --> 00:01:08.820
But one of the big bonuses or one of the,
it's a positive and it's a negative

23
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:12.420
of Linux is that every distribution can
choose to do whatever the heck they want.

24
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:16.190
And so a lot of them have a standard set
of administration tools that you can

25
00:01:16.190 --> 00:01:16.990
expect to find.

26
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:18.420
And you'll see them everywhere.

27
00:01:18.420 --> 00:01:21.870
Other's don't, other's choose to
have their own management suite or

28
00:01:21.870 --> 00:01:23.914
even proprietary software in some cases.

29
00:01:23.914 --> 00:01:28.439
And so now you end up in the situation
where you don't know what to expect, and

30
00:01:28.439 --> 00:01:33.420
that's why a lot of businesses will choose
one distribution and stick with it.

31
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:35.670
They'll say we're gonna
be an Ubuntu shop or

32
00:01:35.670 --> 00:01:38.200
we're gonna be a Red Hat
enterprise Linux shop.

33
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.130
And by doing that you have a consistent
experience with what you're

34
00:01:41.130 --> 00:01:42.320
going to run into.

35
00:01:42.320 --> 00:01:45.100
Now for a home user we don't
think about things like that,

36
00:01:45.100 --> 00:01:47.590
if it's my own laptop I can put
whatever distro I want on here.

37
00:01:47.590 --> 00:01:50.770
It can be some crazy fly by night
distro that nobody's ever heard of,

38
00:01:50.770 --> 00:01:55.390
it's not a big deal, but in a business,
in an enterprise, that is a big concern.

39
00:01:55.390 --> 00:01:59.140
So we're gonna try and pick a consistent
desktop and learn the tools that

40
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:02.080
are available in it to be able to
use them to manage our systems.

41
00:02:02.080 --> 00:02:03.050
>> Well, that makes sense.

42
00:02:03.050 --> 00:02:07.070
If you're just troubleshooting one
system as that end user at home,

43
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:10.330
it's a lot easier than troubleshooting
multiple systems, right?

44
00:02:10.330 --> 00:02:11.110
>> Absolutely, and

45
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:14.250
if you're trying to run commands on one
computer to troubleshoot another one.

46
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:15.850
So now you're working with
more than one system.

47
00:02:15.850 --> 00:02:18.040
It's nice to have it
consistent if you can.

48
00:02:18.040 --> 00:02:20.180
So that's where we end up on this one and

49
00:02:20.180 --> 00:02:23.030
we'll take a look at some of the different
utilities that are available.

50
00:02:23.030 --> 00:02:25.730
Most of them are pretty common sense.

51
00:02:25.730 --> 00:02:26.560
You'll stumble across them.

52
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:28.390
Some of them are hidden away.

53
00:02:28.390 --> 00:02:32.470
Some of them for example are in the GUI,
or have a GUI but don't have an icon so

54
00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:35.680
we don't have a way to go in and launch
unless we absolutely know they're there,

55
00:02:35.680 --> 00:02:37.150
that makes those kind of tricky too.

56
00:02:37.150 --> 00:02:39.610
>> How do we even know they're
there if the icon isn't present,

57
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:43.370
I mean, are we just going to be assuming
or are they integrated into the system,

58
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:44.105
how does that work?

59
00:02:44.105 --> 00:02:46.630
>> So there's two answers to this one.

60
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:49.565
>> There's the smarmy answer,
which is, you read the book, right?

61
00:02:49.565 --> 00:02:52.890
[LAUGH] Every operating system
that they've got manuals.

62
00:02:52.890 --> 00:02:54.440
They've got documents that RTFM.

63
00:02:54.440 --> 00:02:56.820
You go and you read the manual.

64
00:02:58.100 --> 00:03:00.580
But some of them you can stumble through,
and you can find.

65
00:03:00.580 --> 00:03:02.300
Some of them are really consistent.

66
00:03:02.300 --> 00:03:05.330
So for example,
I'm on a Red Hat machine here.

67
00:03:05.330 --> 00:03:07.540
So my laptop is running
Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

68
00:03:07.540 --> 00:03:12.140
And if you're running Red Hat or
CentOS or Fedora, those are all

69
00:03:12.140 --> 00:03:16.090
built off a common core, and they're very,
very common in the enterprise.

70
00:03:16.090 --> 00:03:19.190
And Red Hat tries to make
their systems easy to support,

71
00:03:19.190 --> 00:03:20.550
whether you've got a GUI or not.

72
00:03:20.550 --> 00:03:25.413
And so one of the things they do, is they
make a lot of their configuration commands

73
00:03:25.413 --> 00:03:27.823
all start with the same kind of verbage.

74
00:03:27.823 --> 00:03:31.380
So if I bring up a terminal,
let me fire up a terminal on my laptop.

75
00:03:31.380 --> 00:03:36.430
So here I am on my system and
I've got this one and it says server but

76
00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:39.750
server workstation is all the same
when it comes to this stuff.

77
00:03:39.750 --> 00:03:44.970
That I can run system-config and
just hit tab a couple of times for

78
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:48.740
the tab auto complete and I will
start to see some of these utilities.

79
00:03:48.740 --> 00:03:52.200
Now, I can configure printers
from the command line.

80
00:03:52.200 --> 00:03:55.528
That's not a big deal but
there's a GUI utility included right here,

81
00:03:55.528 --> 00:03:57.522
system-config-printer.

82
00:03:57.522 --> 00:04:02.870
And so that utility is there, it's
available for me and I can fire that up

83
00:04:02.870 --> 00:04:08.320
and if I do, if I say, system- can,
sorry, I've already got it on my screen.

84
00:04:08.320 --> 00:04:10.790
I could save some time typing and
just type printer.

85
00:04:10.790 --> 00:04:15.342
So system-config-printer and
when I run that, up comes a GUI.

86
00:04:15.342 --> 00:04:17.869
And now I'm able to see the printers
that I'm connected to and

87
00:04:17.869 --> 00:04:19.970
I can manage them right
here in a graphical method.

88
00:04:19.970 --> 00:04:25.400
So I don't have to be some crazy command
line wizard or remember a ton of things.

89
00:04:25.400 --> 00:04:30.030
I can just type system-config,
hit Tab a couple of times and

90
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:31.480
it'll show me all the ones that start.

91
00:04:31.480 --> 00:04:35.270
Now, the list that I'm showing you
here is not terribly impressive.

92
00:04:35.270 --> 00:04:38.560
It's just printer and-
>> I think it does help though,

93
00:04:38.560 --> 00:04:39.677
it's not so intimidating.

94
00:04:39.677 --> 00:04:42.800
It's a good segway getting into
that command line interface there.

95
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:45.920
>> Yeah, absolutely, but the other thing
is that there's a lot more of these

96
00:04:45.920 --> 00:04:47.850
utilities that just aren't
installed by default.

97
00:04:47.850 --> 00:04:50.660
You may not have the graphical utility for
something,

98
00:04:50.660 --> 00:04:52.730
so I could actually
install quite a few more.

99
00:04:52.730 --> 00:04:57.518
If I do a sudo yum install and
then specify some of

100
00:04:57.518 --> 00:05:03.164
the other GUI utilities
like system-config-users.

101
00:05:03.164 --> 00:05:07.750
If I fire that one up, it's gonna install
that and it's not installed by default,

102
00:05:07.750 --> 00:05:09.030
but it is available.

103
00:05:09.030 --> 00:05:12.570
Now I can manage user accounts right here
from the command line by using useradd,

104
00:05:12.570 --> 00:05:16.990
usermod, those commands that if
you know the CLI, are available.

105
00:05:16.990 --> 00:05:21.850
But now that I've got this one
installed I can do system-config, and

106
00:05:21.850 --> 00:05:23.980
there's that users showing up.

107
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:25.065
So I can just type users.

108
00:05:25.065 --> 00:05:26.847
System-config-users.

109
00:05:26.847 --> 00:05:30.133
And now, whoop, I've gotta be
an administrator to use this utility, so

110
00:05:30.133 --> 00:05:31.090
it's prompting me.

111
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:32.970
So that's nice,
I didn't even have to remember that.

112
00:05:32.970 --> 00:05:34.980
I can just run it, and there we go.

113
00:05:34.980 --> 00:05:36.940
Now I'm able to come in here and
manage my user account.

114
00:05:36.940 --> 00:05:40.300
I see that deep is the user account I'm
logged in with, and I can come in and

115
00:05:40.300 --> 00:05:42.150
i can add more users and groups.

116
00:05:42.150 --> 00:05:43.780
All done right through a GUI.

117
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:49.110
And the list of utilities that are
available this way is really impressive.

118
00:05:49.110 --> 00:05:53.470
We could do a search
through the repositories,

119
00:05:53.470 --> 00:05:56.010
and you'll find where
there's tons of tools.

120

But it's not so
nice in that it is a web page.

574
00:27:15.090 --> 00:27:15.630
It's open.

575
00:27:15.630 --> 00:27:16.260
It's running.

576
00:27:16.260 --> 00:27:17.710
It's on port 631.

577
00:27:17.710 --> 00:27:19.190
This is part of the service, and

578
00:27:19.190 --> 00:27:22.720
that means it's consuming resources and
potentially increasing the attack surface.

579
00:27:22.720 --> 00:27:25.000
So you always wanna be
careful with these utilities.

580
00:27:25.000 --> 00:27:27.460
If you're not going to use them,
you should disable them.

581
00:27:27.460 --> 00:27:31.060
You can disable this web interface in
CUPS, and you can also just block it on

582
00:27:31.060 --> 00:27:34.568
the firewall so it's available just for
you and not for everybody else.

583
00:27:34.568 --> 00:27:38.601
Those are all things to consider when
you use web utilities like these.

584
00:27:38.601 --> 00:27:40.603
>> Well, Don,
I think that's about it for this show.

585
00:27:40.603 --> 00:27:43.570
Do you have any final thoughts or
anything that you'd like to add?

586
00:27:43.570 --> 00:27:47.270
>> So the main thing here is there's
no right and wrong tool to use.

587
00:27:47.270 --> 00:27:50.690
When it comes to the graphical utilities,
just find the ones that you like.

588
00:27:50.690 --> 00:27:54.750
I showed the GNOME utility for
modifying disks and how easy it looked.

589
00:27:54.750 --> 00:27:57.250
There's actually another
utility called GParted.

590
00:27:57.250 --> 00:27:59.960
It's a graphical partition editor,
and that's what I normally use for

591
00:27:59.960 --> 00:28:00.780
modifying disks.

592
00:28:00.780 --> 00:28:03.070
It's not installed by default,
you have to install it.

593
00:28:03.070 --> 00:28:06.100
And I found that that's the tool that
I prefer for working with disks.

594
00:28:06.100 --> 00:28:07.020
That's what I like.

595
00:28:07.020 --> 00:28:08.900
And for you, you may find the same.

596
00:28:08.900 --> 00:28:12.037
Find utilities that you like, ones that
work for you, and just stick with those.

597
00:28:12.037 --> 00:28:15.913
And you'll find that you can do full
system administration just using graphical

598
00:28:15.913 --> 00:28:16.597
utilities and

599
00:28:16.597 --> 00:28:20.595
not the command line, which is what we're
gonna see in most of our other episodes.

600
00:28:20.595 --> 00:28:22.844
>> Well, thank you for taking the time
to show us a lot of these tools.

601
00:28:22.844 --> 00:28:24.533
And I think it's great especially for

602
00:28:24.533 --> 00:28:27.756
someone maybe comfortable or
familiar with the Windows environment and

603
00:28:27.756 --> 00:28:30.310
they're not ready to make
that full transition or leap.

604
00:28:30.310 --> 00:28:32.599
But now they have the tools
to get them on their way.

605
00:28:32.599 --> 00:28:33.758
>> [LAUGH]
>> So thank you for that.

606
00:28:33.758 --> 00:28:35.218
And thank you for joining us today.

607
00:28:35.218 --> 00:28:38.070
But stay tuned, we have additional
information headed your way.

608
00:28:38.070 --> 00:28:39.468
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign off.

609
00:28:39.468 --> 00:28:41.249
As your host, I've been Cherokee Boose.

610
00:28:41.249 --> 00:28:42.267
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

611
00:28:42.267 --> 00:28:45.345
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

612
00:28:45.345 --> 00:28:51.031
[MUSIC]

613
00:28:51.031 --> 00:28:54.378
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Cherokee define the root user account. Don explains the high level access this account carries and suggests using it on an as needed basis. He demonstrates a couple of alternative methods of temporary elevated access such as using superuser (sd) and superuser do (sudo). Don also suggests using a syntax checker (visudo) to help prevent typos.
episodes.title: The root User Account
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.806
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.806 --> 00:00:05.906
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.906 --> 00:00:07.904
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.904 --> 00:00:10.802
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.802 --> 00:00:14.263
>> Welcome to your Becoming
a Linux system admin series,

6
00:00:14.263 --> 00:00:17.175
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.175 --> 00:00:20.403
In this episode we're gonna
be taking a look at well,

8
00:00:20.403 --> 00:00:22.427
how to use the root user account.

9
00:00:22.427 --> 00:00:25.752
And back in the studios with us
today we have mister Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.752 --> 00:00:26.802
How's it going today Don?

11
00:00:26.802 --> 00:00:27.962
>> It is going great, Cherokee.

12
00:00:27.962 --> 00:00:30.230
I'm excited to jump back into
our Linux system admin track.

13
00:00:30.230 --> 00:00:33.464
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at the root user account.

14
00:00:33.464 --> 00:00:34.832
Like Cherokee mentioned,

15
00:00:34.832 --> 00:00:38.982
it is a very important account that
unfortunately gets misused way too much.

16
00:00:38.982 --> 00:00:42.052
So we're gonna spend our time here in this
episode talking about when we would use

17
00:00:42.052 --> 00:00:45.012
it, why we would use it, how we're
intended to use that root user account and

18
00:00:45.012 --> 00:00:46.022
what its purpose is.

19
00:00:46.022 --> 00:00:49.254
And we'll get a chance to see all of
that in the scope of Linux system

20
00:00:49.254 --> 00:00:51.237
administration right in this episode.

21
00:00:51.237 --> 00:00:52.350
>> Well, that sounds great, Don.

22
00:00:52.350 --> 00:00:55.433
I think the first question would be,
like you have mentioned,

23
00:00:55.433 --> 00:00:57.361
who should be using this root account?

24
00:00:57.361 --> 00:01:00.996
>> Well, so root user account
it's really intended just, why,

25
00:01:00.996 --> 00:01:03.808
it's just kinda hard to say,
it's intended for

26
00:01:03.808 --> 00:01:09.260
system administrators is for us, but it's
really intended for the system itself.

27
00:01:09.260 --> 00:01:13.225
When your computer boots up a lot of the
activities that it performs in the very

28
00:01:13.225 --> 00:01:15.482
beginning when it's initially starting,

29
00:01:15.482 --> 00:01:18.730
are being performed under
the permission set of the root user.

30
00:01:18.730 --> 00:01:22.360
Root user is actually the very first
user account created on your system.

31
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:25.431
When you install a Linux system the root
user account is created right there at

32
00:01:25.431 --> 00:01:26.290
the very beginning.

33
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:29.160
And this is from way
back in the Unix days.

34
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:31.330
That account has always been there.

35
00:01:31.330 --> 00:01:33.880
And this user has full permission,

36
00:01:33.880 --> 00:01:38.880
full access to every single
resource across your system.

37
00:01:38.880 --> 00:01:39.780
They can do anything.

38
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:41.811
You can't lock the user account out.

39
00:01:41.811 --> 00:01:44.468
You can't stop them from accessing
a file by changing permissions.

40
00:01:44.468 --> 00:01:46.148
It's a very, very powerful account.

41
00:01:46.148 --> 00:01:51.106
And as a result if we need to perform
some activity or action that requires

42
00:01:51.106 --> 00:01:55.678
elevated privileges, we can use
the root user account to do that.

43
00:01:55.678 --> 00:01:58.536
A regular user account,
a regular end user,

44
00:01:58.536 --> 00:02:01.630
somebody who is just a home user whatever.

45
00:02:01.630 --> 00:02:04.212
Probably shouldn't be using the root
user account on a regular basis.

46
00:02:04.212 --> 00:02:06.770
But there are times where
we need to have that.

47
00:02:06.770 --> 00:02:08.971
Like when we are installing software or

48
00:02:08.971 --> 00:02:12.410
we're installing hardware
drivers things like that.

49
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:16.532
Those are very important tasks that modify
the way the operating system works.

50
00:02:16.532 --> 00:02:18.596
And that's what that root
user account is intended for.

51
00:02:18.596 --> 00:02:22.783
So those are kinda some scenarios where we
might actually see that user account get

52
00:02:22.783 --> 00:02:23.880
put into play.

53
00:02:23.880 --> 00:02:27.450
>> It sounds like we should use some
discretion whenever we do allow use of

54
00:02:27.450 --> 00:02:29.933
this particular account
because of potential,

55
00:02:29.933 --> 00:02:33.034
it sounds like potential
security risks that could happen.

56
00:02:33.034 --> 00:02:37.082
So would our sysadmins be using a root
account for management purposes?

57
00:02:37.082 --> 00:02:40.370
>> So
this is where things get a little weird.

58
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:45.579
On the internet, [LAUGH] If we go and
learn from the internet, you

59
00:02:45.579 --> 00:02:52.360
can find forum posts all over the place
where people will say, log in as root.

60
00:02:52.360 --> 00:02:54.510
Or access a root shell and
start doing commands.

61
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:56.164
You can log in as root.

62
00:02:56.164 --> 00:02:59.800
I can log into my own laptop as root,
but I don't.

63
00:02:59.800 --> 00:03:03.790
As any user, really,
even if you're a system administrator,

64
00:03:03.790 --> 00:03:07.590
if you're the person who owns the company,
you shouldn't be logging in as root.

65
00:03:07.590 --> 00:03:09.080
You should be logging in as you.

66
00:03:09.080 --> 00:03:11.862
Everybody should have a regular
run-of-the-mill user account.

67
00:03:11.862 --> 00:03:17.050
And then you just use the root
account when you need to, right?

68
00:03:17.050 --> 00:03:22.060
The problem with logging in as root is
that when you log in as the root user,

69
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:23.750
everything you do,

70
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:27.375
from the most powerful administration
tasks down to the most menial,

71
00:03:27.375 --> 00:03:32.800
run-of-the-mill, monotonous task is being
run with full system privileges, okay?

72
00:03:32.800 --> 00:03:35.040
Have you ever accidentally deleted a file.

73
00:03:35.040 --> 00:03:37.238
And you're like I didn't
mean to delete that.

74
00:03:37.238 --> 00:03:38.830
And you go to the Recycle Bin and
you pull it back.

75
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:40.380
It's not a big deal.

76
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:42.656
Well, those are mistakes, they happen.

77
00:03:42.656 --> 00:03:44.073
As a regular user if you try and

78
00:03:44.073 --> 00:03:47.328
do something really bad you don't
have permission, it stops you.

79
00:03:47.328 --> 00:03:52.738
If you go to delete the /sys folder or
/boot folder it won't let you.

80
00:03:52.738 --> 00:03:53.892
You don't have permissions.

81
00:03:53.892 --> 00:03:55.874
But as the root user, it will let you.

82
00:03:55.874 --> 00:03:58.760
And if you delete the /boot folder,
guess what your system won't do?

83
00:03:58.760 --> 00:03:59.855
Boot.

84
00:03:59.855 --> 00:04:01.670
[LAUGH] It's a bad thing.

85
00:04:01.670 --> 00:04:04.714
So, as the root user,
if you're logged in that way,

86
00:04:04.714 --> 00:04:06.960
you have the ability to make mistakes.

87
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:09.000
And, it's not even you making the mistake.

88
00:04:09.000 --> 00:04:10.714
Really, there's other
things that can happen.

89
00:04:10.714 --> 00:04:13.048
Drive-by web installations.

90
00:04:13.048 --> 00:04:17.118
You go to a website, and the website
has some malicious flash plug-in or

91
00:04:17.118 --> 00:04:22.300
ActiveX java script, whatever thing you
know, and it tries to do something bad.

92
00:04:22.300 --> 00:04:24.894
If you're logged in as a regular user,
it can't do that right?

93
00:04:24.894 --> 00:04:29.056
It tries to do run, it's running in
your user account's privilege space, and

94
00:04:29.056 --> 00:04:30.308
it can't do anything.

95
00:04:30.308 --> 00:04:33.612
But if you're logged in as root and
you go to a malicious website and

96
00:04:33.612 --> 00:04:36.149
it runs some drive by attack,
guess what the attack

97
00:04:36.149 --> 00:04:39.986
is running as root cuz it's running as
you, you're the one who launched it.

98
00:04:39.986 --> 00:04:42.760
And now it can do whatever it wants.

99
00:04:42.760 --> 00:04:45.720
That's the risk we have but
you certainly log in as root.

100
00:04:45.720 --> 00:04:50.540
So for example here on my laptop I'm
logged into my desktop here as me,

101
00:04:50.540 --> 00:04:53.780
so if I do a whoami,
I'm dpezet, that's great.

102
00:04:53.780 --> 00:04:56.820
I can switch to another console and
this is gonna be really small,

103
00:04:56.820 --> 00:04:59.710
cuz at the console level I can't
increase the font size, right?

104
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:01.178
I'm at a hardware console.

105
00:05:01.178 --> 00:05:03.745
And I could come in here and
I could log in as root and

106
00:05:03.745 --> 00:05:07.120
I can punch in the password and
gain access to the system, right?

107
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:11.262
And I would then have a shell
account logged in as the root user.

108
00:05:11.262 --> 00:05:13.246
Now, I'm not gonna do it because, well,

109
00:05:13.246 --> 00:05:15.890
I can't actually remember
what my root password is.

110
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:17.024
Which you might think is kinda funny.

111
00:05:17.024 --> 00:05:20.310
Don, why don't you know the root
password to your own system?

112
00:05:20.310 --> 00:05:24.034
And the short answer is I don't
know it because I never use it.

113
00:05:24.034 --> 00:05:27.316
I don't use the root user account
because as a good system administrator,

114
00:05:27.316 --> 00:05:28.500
you really shouldn't.

115
00:05:28.500 --> 00:05:30.242
But, you do need to be
aware that it is there and

116
00:05:30.242 --> 00:05:32.298
we can use it a different way and
later in this episode,

117
00:05:32.298 --> 00:05:34.962
I'll show you how you actually can
use that, that root user account.

118
00:05:34.962 --> 00:05:39.076
The other thing is,
if I were back at my GUI, for example, and

119
00:05:39.076 --> 00:05:42.020
I wanted to log in as
a different user right?

120
00:05:42.020 --> 00:05:45.380
So I could log out and
switch to somebody else right?

121
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:48.780
So I'm gonna come in here and
try and log in as a different user.

122
00:05:48.780 --> 00:05:53.403
Well, at that log in screen, I guess it
kinda came and went really fast there, but

123
00:05:53.403 --> 00:05:57.300
you saw for just a brief moment
there where it showed dpezet, right?

124
00:05:57.300 --> 00:05:59.964
So it showed as me.

125
00:05:59.964 --> 00:06:01.680
Well, it didn't show root.

126
00:06:01.680 --> 00:06:06.240
The root user account is actually
hidden from most window managers.

127
00:06:06.240 --> 00:06:10.301
And they don't want you to log into
the window manager as root because well,

128
00:06:10.301 --> 00:06:14.372
the root user has too much power, and
it can damage the window environment.

129
00:06:14.372 --> 00:06:16.697
It can modify config files that
it shouldn't being modifying, and

130
00:06:16.697 --> 00:06:18.510
things that a regular user
should have to adhere to.

131
00:06:18.510 --> 00:06:22.890
It's not able to,
kinda play nice in that environment.

132
00:06:22.890 --> 00:06:26.624
So, the root user is very powerful,
and very dangerous.

133
00:06:26.624 --> 00:06:29.200
And so as a sysadmin you
really shouldn't be using it.

134
00:06:29.200 --> 00:06:31.980
You should never log in as the root user.

135
00:06:31.980 --> 00:06:35.940
Instead we've got a collection of
utilities that allow us to gain root

136
00:06:35.940 --> 00:06:38.904
privileges without actually
being that root user.

137
00:06:38.904 --> 00:06:42.659
>> So Don in addition to these
powerful options that we see here,

138
00:06:42.659 --> 00:06:46.779
are there any additional considerations
associated with this root

139
00:06:46.779 --> 00:06:49.365
account that we should be aware of?

140
00:06:49.365 --> 00:06:52.437
Yeah the root user
account is special right

141
00:06:52.437 --> 00:06:55.518
kind of a special snowflake of our system.

142
00:06:55.518 --> 00:06:56.695
If you look in for

143
00:06:56.695 --> 00:07:01.746
example lets take a look at /atc/passwd
that's the user data base for

144
00:07:01.746 --> 00:07:07.820
Linux system, and if I look in there I'll
see all these different user accounts.

145
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:12.140
Well the very first one is root, remember
I mentioned it was the first user account

146
00:07:12.140 --> 00:07:16.620
that was created and so
their user ID is ID zero.

147
00:07:16.620 --> 00:07:20.017
Versus if you look at mine,
right if we go way down here and find me,

148
00:07:20.017 --> 00:07:21.242
my user ID is 1000.

149
00:07:21.242 --> 00:07:26.120
Right and it jumps to a higher number for
those, but the root user is first.

150
00:07:26.120 --> 00:07:29.790
If I disable the root user account,
guess what happens to my system.

151
00:07:29.790 --> 00:07:31.226
It doesn't boot, right?

152
00:07:31.226 --> 00:07:34.494
The system requires that root user account
to be able to boot and load services and

153
00:07:34.494 --> 00:07:36.430
things that are running
at the very beginning.

154
00:07:36.430 --> 00:07:40.190
If I were to run like ps aux, and

155
00:07:40.190 --> 00:07:43.140
take a look at all the services
that are running on my computer,

156
00:07:43.140 --> 00:07:47.360
see how there's a lot that show dpezet,
that's me, I'm running stuff, right?

157
00:07:47.360 --> 00:07:50.688
But there's even more
that are showing as root.

158
00:07:50.688 --> 00:07:53.273
These are processes that are being run,

159
00:07:53.273 --> 00:07:56.554
that were likely being run
before I even logged in.

160
00:07:56.554 --> 00:08:00.948
In fact, if I go to the lower process IDs
way up here at the beginning You'll see

161
00:08:00.948 --> 00:08:05.226
things like process ID number one,
where it was launching a splash screen.

162
00:08:05.226 --> 00:08:08.200
The kernel thread, I see each of these
different things that were starting.

163
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:12.710
That's all part of my core OS, and
eventually I'll get to the Window Manager,

164
00:08:12.710 --> 00:08:13.460
where it started.

165
00:08:13.460 --> 00:08:15.040
It will be buried in here somewhere.

166
00:08:15.040 --> 00:08:18.697
And when that window manager started,
it was running as root before I finally

167
00:08:18.697 --> 00:08:21.962
provided it credentials, when I gave
it my username and password and

168
00:08:21.962 --> 00:08:25.083
then it was able to start launching
everything under my account.

169
00:08:25.083 --> 00:08:29.780
So that root user is very important and
we can't get rid of it.

170
00:08:29.780 --> 00:08:32.710
In fact, it's so important that I
don't want anybody messing with it.

171
00:08:32.710 --> 00:08:36.820
So, like our normal users,
we all get directories inside of /home.

172
00:08:36.820 --> 00:08:39.060
So if I look in there,
I've got /home/dpezel and

173
00:08:39.060 --> 00:08:42.540
if I create three more users,
they'll all have folders right here.

174
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:45.540
But the root user doesn't
have a folder in /home.

175
00:08:45.540 --> 00:08:49.860
Instead if I go into /root,
they have a folder.

176
00:08:49.860 --> 00:08:53.770
And see how I don't have access to it,
right, it's blocked off, but it is there.

177
00:08:53.770 --> 00:08:58.180
If we take a look at our
directory structure for

178
00:08:58.180 --> 00:09:02.610
root here, you'll see that
/root folder right there and

179
00:09:02.610 --> 00:09:07.020
only the owner has read, write and
execute on it and the owner is root.

180
00:09:07.020 --> 00:09:08.990
Even the root group doesn't
have access to that folder.

181
00:09:08.990 --> 00:09:12.490
Just the root account
itself has access and

182
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:17.010
they can jump in there and browse into
that folder and work with it and so on.

183
00:09:17.010 --> 00:09:21.390
So that's separate, it's stored outside

00:21:30.172 --> 00:21:33.150

00:21:33.150 --> 00:21:37.166

00:21:37.166 --> 00:21:40.446

00:21:40.446 --> 00:21:43.984

00:24:51.250 --> 00:24:54.497

00:25:27.760 --> 00:25:32.850

00:25:44.820 --> 00:25:52.180

00:28:16.840 --> 00:28:20.130

episodes.description: In this show, Don and Cherokee continue to examine helpful administrative commands. They specifically focus on system logs. Don explains how journald is making its way into the market but may not be supported by all applications thus making it important to also check syslogd for important log information.
episodes.title: Administrative Commands Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Don focus on hardware. They explain how the system detects and identifies different components. They look at how to identify if hardware is working properly by using tools such as dmessage and journalctl. Doe demonstrates how hardware should be detected by udevd. He also explains how overrides can be used as well as using ls to list different buses.

00:07:34.661 --> 00:07:37.130

00:07:37.130 --> 00:07:38.850

00:07:38.850 --> 00:07:40.818

00:08:39.160 --> 00:08:44.472

00:08:54.140 --> 00:08:57.800

00:09:02.107 --> 00:09:03.979

Windows has its EFI partition
which we need with Linux also.

402
00:20:54.888 --> 00:20:57.896
Then you've got your recovery partition
and then you've got your operating system,

403
00:20:57.896 --> 00:20:59.760
so it's three partitions right there.

404
00:20:59.760 --> 00:21:01.950
In Linux you're normally gonna have EFI,

405
00:21:01.950 --> 00:21:06.340
a swap memory partition and
then your operating system, that's three.

406
00:21:06.340 --> 00:21:10.230
But it's pretty common to also have
things like a home directory and /var and

407
00:21:10.230 --> 00:21:12.080
other things moved off
into their own partitions.

408
00:21:12.080 --> 00:21:16.078
So you could have 10 or 12 partitions in
here that really wouldn't be outrageous.

409
00:21:16.078 --> 00:21:19.894
You look at it, it seems like a lot
of partitions but in reality,

410
00:21:19.894 --> 00:21:23.090
a lot of this is automatically
created by the system.

411
00:21:23.090 --> 00:21:27.874
I didn't actually go in and set up a ton
of these, it did it for me cuz I'm lazy.

412
00:21:27.874 --> 00:21:30.911
[LAUGH] So, there's my hard drives and
I know they're detected and

413
00:21:30.911 --> 00:21:33.910
I know they're present and
I can even see those partitions.

414
00:21:33.910 --> 00:21:36.960
Doesn't mean I can use them, right,
I still have to mount them and

415
00:21:36.960 --> 00:21:40.110
have access to the file system and
so on like the Windows partition.

416
00:21:40.110 --> 00:21:43.370
I might not be able to access that cause
it's formatted for a Windows system but

417
00:21:43.370 --> 00:21:44.760
at least, I see it here.

418
00:21:44.760 --> 00:21:46.910
If you know the hardware is detected and

419
00:21:46.910 --> 00:21:49.600
recognized by the operating system,
then it should show up in here.

420
00:21:49.600 --> 00:21:50.360
And the reverse is true,

421
00:21:50.360 --> 00:21:53.830
if it shows up in here then it
should've been detected by the system.

422
00:21:53.830 --> 00:21:58.600
Now be careful, most of the main
distros will only show hardware in

423
00:21:58.600 --> 00:22:03.280
here if it was detected, but that's not
always the case like this FD right here.

424
00:22:03.280 --> 00:22:06.050
Okay, does that mean it detected
a floppy disk on my system and

425
00:22:06.050 --> 00:22:06.941
it's ready to use it?

426
00:22:06.941 --> 00:22:08.580
>> I hope not [LAUGH].

427
00:22:08.580 --> 00:22:13.165
>> It would mean I really need a new
laptop, no I don't have a floppy drive, so

428
00:22:13.165 --> 00:22:15.405
sometimes they put placeholders in.

429
00:22:15.405 --> 00:22:18.795
And if there's a placeholder in
there it'll show up regardless of

430
00:22:18.795 --> 00:22:21.105
whether the hardware was detected or
not, right?

431
00:22:21.105 --> 00:22:26.055
So I don't have a floppy disk but there it
is, most of this stuff is real, is real,

432
00:22:26.055 --> 00:22:28.015
it was detected and it's been seen.

433
00:22:28.015 --> 00:22:31.795
But just because it's
here isn't a guarantee

434
00:22:31.795 --> 00:22:33.600
that it's actually there and it's working.

435
00:22:33.600 --> 00:22:38.069
And most of this is mapping the physical
hardware, but some of this is

436
00:22:38.069 --> 00:22:42.396
mapping the virtual hardware like
my VMnet adapters from VMware.

437
00:22:42.396 --> 00:22:46.768
I've got VMnet 01 and
8 U random and /dev/random,

438
00:22:46.768 --> 00:22:50.410
those are random number generators, right?

439
00:22:50.410 --> 00:22:55.021
And they may be connected to a hardware
random number generator on your system,

440
00:22:55.021 --> 00:22:57.890
but most of us don't have
a hardware random number generator.

441
00:22:57.890 --> 00:23:00.881
So if you don't have one,
then it's mapped to a logical one and

442
00:23:00.881 --> 00:23:03.149
it's a piece of crap and
you shouldn't use it.

443
00:23:03.149 --> 00:23:06.183
[LAUGH] So that's a problem
in the security world, but

444
00:23:06.183 --> 00:23:07.740
we don't always have one.

445
00:23:07.740 --> 00:23:09.885
So that may be mapped
with something virtual,

446
00:23:09.885 --> 00:23:12.200
it might be mapped with something real.

447
00:23:12.200 --> 00:23:15.476
A lot of this stuff you have to
understand that actual technology,

448
00:23:15.476 --> 00:23:19.020
like the random number generator,
how do I know if I have a real one?

449
00:23:19.020 --> 00:23:24.647
Well, I can call the RNGD service right,
the Random Number Generation Daemon,

450
00:23:24.647 --> 00:23:28.798
and I can tell it to show me
information about its hardware.

451
00:23:28.798 --> 00:23:33.892
And when I run it, I'm seeing I have
an available entry resource of DRNG,

452
00:23:33.892 --> 00:23:38.919
which is a Deterministic Random
Number Generator, not a hardware one.

453
00:23:38.919 --> 00:23:42.208
If it was using my CPU then I would
actually see an entry, you're saying,

454
00:23:42.208 --> 00:23:45.407
Intel, blah blah blah, or
AMD blah blah blah, and it's not using it.

455
00:23:45.407 --> 00:23:47.929
Or if I was using the TPM I
would see a note in here.

456
00:23:47.929 --> 00:23:50.499
Here, but
right now I'm using a deterministic one.

457
00:23:50.499 --> 00:23:52.506
And I shouldn't call it a piece of crap.

458
00:23:52.506 --> 00:23:53.350
It's not bad.

459
00:23:53.350 --> 00:23:56.600
It's, for our use, for
routine use, it's perfectly fine.

460
00:23:56.600 --> 00:23:57.919
But if you're in the military and

461
00:23:57.919 --> 00:24:01.550
you're handling national secrets,
you don't want to do that.

462
00:24:01.550 --> 00:24:05.210
So that's an attack factor, but
this is an example though of where

463
00:24:05.210 --> 00:24:08.390
just by seeing /deb /random
that didn't tell me anything.

464
00:24:08.390 --> 00:24:11.090
I actually had to look into

465
00:24:11.090 --> 00:24:15.090
the random number generator itself to
find out if the hardware was there.

466
00:24:15.090 --> 00:24:17.440
So often times
troubleshooting hardware and

467
00:24:17.440 --> 00:24:22.790
identifying it requires an extra tool
that's specialized to that particular tool

468
00:24:22.790 --> 00:24:25.920
and that's where you're gonna have
to do some reading on that hardware.

469
00:24:26.960 --> 00:24:30.730
All right, let's see, what are some of
the other ones that you might see in here?

470
00:24:30.730 --> 00:24:33.240
Different vendors have different
shortcuts they'll put in.

471
00:24:33.240 --> 00:24:36.510
Sometimes you'll see /dev/cdrom,
so when you put in a CD ROM,

472
00:24:36.510 --> 00:24:37.700
that's what it'll map to.

473
00:24:37.700 --> 00:24:41.460
Fedora doesn't do that, so
I don't have a /dev/cdrom.

474
00:24:41.460 --> 00:24:46.200
It'll actually map it to a different
unique name that I can't remember offhand.

475
00:24:46.200 --> 00:24:49.380
We don't see it here cuz most distros
have automatic mounting now so

476
00:24:49.380 --> 00:24:54.810
we don't really care what it gets a name
for, but it will turn up that way.

477
00:24:54.810 --> 00:24:59.000
You may see things like,
let's see, what's another example?

478
00:24:59.000 --> 00:25:03.900
SND for your sound card,
/dev/snd is actually pretty common and

479
00:25:03.900 --> 00:25:05.270
you'll see I've got it here.

480
00:25:05.270 --> 00:25:07.380
That way software when
it wants to play sound,

481
00:25:07.380 --> 00:25:09.960
it doesn't have to know what kind of sound
card you have or anything like that.

482
00:25:09.960 --> 00:25:12.220
I can just retry out to /dev /sound and

483
00:25:12.220 --> 00:25:14.700
whatever that's mapped to
that's what'll play that sound.

484
00:25:14.700 --> 00:25:17.330
So it makes it easier for
software developers to use that.

485
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:22.745
And here ill see that snd is a folder
because most sound cards have speaker and

486
00:25:22.745 --> 00:25:26.056
microphone, they do
more than one function.

487
00:25:26.056 --> 00:25:28.877
When a device does more than one
function it'll normally be a folder, and

488
00:25:28.877 --> 00:25:31.790
in that folder you'll start to see where
it breaks things down into all these

489
00:25:31.790 --> 00:25:34.963
different components and apparently my
sound card does all sorts of crazy stuff.

490
00:25:34.963 --> 00:25:36.508
Which is
>> [LAUGH]

491
00:25:36.508 --> 00:25:39.140
>> Also not uncommon if you have HDMI

492
00:25:39.140 --> 00:25:40.190
like I do on my laptop.

493
00:25:40.190 --> 00:25:42.880
HDMI is technically another sound output.

494
00:25:42.880 --> 00:25:46.850
You might have a headphone
jack as well as other types of

495
00:25:46.850 --> 00:25:48.140
maybe you've got surround sound.

496
00:25:48.140 --> 00:25:51.230
Some of those, like the turtle
beach adapters or whatever,

497
00:25:51.230 --> 00:25:53.780
they have tons of outputs on those things.

498
00:25:53.780 --> 00:25:55.410
So you may see things there too.

499
00:25:55.410 --> 00:25:58.663
And you may even see some
logical sound processors and

500
00:25:58.663 --> 00:26:03.505
some scenarios especially if you have that
high end audio mixing software if you

501
00:26:03.505 --> 00:26:06.623
work in a recording studio or
something like that.

502
00:26:06.623 --> 00:26:08.689
>> Yeah, you're jamming out aren't you?

503
00:26:08.689 --> 00:26:10.047
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, this is all default stuff.

504
00:26:10.047 --> 00:26:12.963
I honestly had not looked at
this prior to this very moment.

505
00:26:12.963 --> 00:26:17.908
[LAUGH] So, that's the interesting thing
is that some of this stuff we don't have

506
00:26:17.908 --> 00:26:19.080
to worry about it.

507
00:26:19.080 --> 00:26:21.040
As long as we hear
a sound what do we care.

508
00:26:21.040 --> 00:26:23.780
But then when you go to troubleshoot it,
all of a sudden you do

509
00:26:23.780 --> 00:26:28.280
have to really kind of figure out what
are all of these entries in here?

510
00:26:28.280 --> 00:26:30.520
And obviously some of these hw,

511
00:26:30.520 --> 00:26:34.570
pcm you can start to kind of
figure out what it is they do.

512
00:26:34.570 --> 00:26:39.200
But other ones you may have to go and
look up and find out and troubleshoot.

513
00:26:39.200 --> 00:26:44.100
Now the key thing here
is that all of the /dev

514
00:26:44.100 --> 00:26:49.380
devices serve one primary purpose and
that's to make it where our software and

515
00:26:49.380 --> 00:26:52.850
ultimately the end-user doesn't
have to know about hardware.

516
00:26:52.850 --> 00:26:58.190
If I have software and it wants to play
music, It doesn't need to understand

517
00:26:58.190 --> 00:27:02.730
that I've got a sound lab, sound card or
whatever it is that I have got.

518
00:27:02.730 --> 00:27:05.110
I even don't know what
sound card I have here.

519
00:27:05.110 --> 00:27:08.270
It just have to know if I
call /dev/snd I can play.

520
00:27:09.480 --> 00:27:11.340
And then the operating system
takes care of the rest.

521
00:27:11.340 --> 00:27:14.070
The operating system has some sort
of a hardware obstruction layer.

522
00:27:14.070 --> 00:27:17.880
The kernel is sitting in between
the software and the hardware.

523
00:27:17.880 --> 00:27:20.500
And so,
when the software calls this fake file and

524
00:27:20.500 --> 00:27:25.805
sends a data the kernel takes that data
and sends it to the real hardware.

525
00:27:25.805 --> 00:27:28.710
So the kernel is what has to know
how to talk to the hardware and

526
00:27:28.710 --> 00:27:30.160
that's what dmesg is all about.

527
00:27:30.160 --> 00:27:34.300
dmesg is showing us does
the kernel recognize the hardware?

528
00:27:34.300 --> 00:27:39.940
And if so did it then engage with udev to
map those out and make them available?

529
00:27:39.940 --> 00:27:42.920
All right, now I've got a lot more
to talk about on hardware detection.

530
00:27:42.920 --> 00:27:46.340
But I know Cherokee's giving me
the signal that I'm running out of time.

531
00:27:46.340 --> 00:27:48.110
So let's break this up into a part two and

532
00:27:48.110 --> 00:27:51.590
in part two I'll show you some more
things we can do beyond just dmesg.

00:27:51.590 --> 00:27:55.570
To locate whether a hardware is working
and even try and force load some drivers

534
00:27:55.570 --> 00:27:58.000
and things, we'll get a chance to
see some of that all in part two.

535
00:27:58.000 --> 00:28:01.280
>> All right Don thank you for
being with us today and thank you for

536
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:04.660
being here as well but for this show
we are gonna go ahead and sign out.

00:28:04.660 --> 00:28:07.560
So we're gonna come back with a part two,
stay tuned.

538
00:28:07.560 --> 00:28:09.280
Remember I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

00:28:09.280 --> 00:28:10.050
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

in in most modern OSs.

00:27:36.558 --> 00:27:39.271
this episode so

37

38

on a physical machine, but

39
00:01:31.032 --> 00:01:32.790

machine here for the show.

40
00:01:32.790 --> 00:01:37.230
But what you would do is you'd basically
take the USB key that you made and

41
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:40.360

42
00:01:40.360 --> 00:01:42.550

43
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:45.270
most computers are not going to
boot the USB key by default.

44
00:01:45.270 --> 00:01:48.540

right completely blank, then yeah it may

45
00:01:48.540 --> 00:01:52.070
boot from USB but it's rare that you
have a computer that's completely blank.

46
00:01:52.070 --> 00:01:54.040
Even when you buy one brand new.

47
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:56.870
It's got some operating system on there,
probably Windows.

48
00:01:56.870 --> 00:01:58.440
And so it's going to try to boot to that.

49
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:03.170
So one of the things you'll need to do
is research how to make your computer

50
00:02:03.170 --> 00:02:06.440
either boot from USB by default
which you probably don't want.

51
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:09.720
Or, to make it where you
can bring up a boot menu.

52
00:02:09.720 --> 00:02:13.890
On a lot of computers, if you press f12
while booting, it'll display boot menu,

53
00:02:13.890 --> 00:02:16.785

device you want to boot from.

54
00:02:16.785 --> 00:02:19.602
If you're installing this on a Mac you
would hold the option key while you're

55
00:02:19.602 --> 00:02:22.410
booting and it would let you pick
what hard drive to boot from.

56
00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:26.120
But other systems might not have
a convenient boot menu like that.

57
00:02:26.120 --> 00:02:27.530
Other ones just use a different key.

58
00:02:27.530 --> 00:02:28.720
Like on my laptop its actually f7.

59
00:02:28.720 --> 00:02:30.250
I have to hold f7 while I’m booting up.

60
00:02:30.250 --> 00:02:32.980
So, you’ll need to look at your
vendor documentation for that.

61
00:02:32.980 --> 00:02:36.890
The alternative is to go into your
BIOS and change the boot order to move

62
00:02:36.890 --> 00:02:40.020
the USB key or
removable media up to the top of the list.

63
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:41.630
Now I said you probably
don't want to do that.

64
00:02:41.630 --> 00:02:44.680
The reason is there's actually a couple of
different security attacks that people can

65
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:48.330
perform that way if it boots
from removable media by default.

66
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:50.190
And so now people could
bypass your operating system.

67
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:51.150
We don't typically wanna do that.

68
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:54.620
But you could do it temporarily and when
you're done just go and put it back again.

69
00:02:54.620 --> 00:02:55.704
So those are options that are available.

70
00:02:55.704 --> 00:02:58.140
>> I know that everyone always
remembers to go back and do that.

71

[LAUGH]

it many-

00:03:01.977 --> 00:03:03.345

75
00:03:03.345 --> 00:03:06.450

76

So whatever process it is that

77

that's what you need to go through.

78
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:11.810
And when you boot,

79
00:03:11.810 --> 00:03:15.490
what you're going to see is what
I've got right here on my screen.

80
00:03:15.490 --> 00:03:16.910
So when you boot off
that that removal media,

81
00:03:16.910 --> 00:03:19.020
what you're gonna see is
a screen that looks like this.

82
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:22.630
And you'll see a couple of splash screens
that go by, maybe a little bit of text as

83
00:03:22.630 --> 00:03:25.820
it starts to initialize the boot
process and run through things.

84
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:28.340
And remember,
I'm running this in a virtual machine so

85
00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:31.250
in the background you've got my
regular old laptop over here.

86
00:03:31.250 --> 00:03:33.950
And in this little window is

00:03:33.950 --> 00:03:35.600
Ubuntu install happening.

88
00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:40.090
Now the reason I'm doing this

89
00:03:40.090 --> 00:03:43.510
there is a minimal set of
hardware drivers that are loaded.

90
00:03:43.510 --> 00:03:45.390
And so
there's a lot of things that are missing.

91
00:03:45.390 --> 00:03:49.679

92
00:03:49.679 --> 00:03:50.572
the recording.

93
00:03:50.572 --> 00:03:52.820
Because the screen mirroring
drivers aren't loaded.

94
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:56.209
And notice how it's a 4 by 3
resolution but my laptop is 16 by 9,

95
00:03:56.209 --> 00:03:58.950
well the full drivers for
that aren't loaded either.

96
00:03:58.950 --> 00:04:03.031
So when you're doing the install,
it's actually loading a minimal set of

97
00:04:03.031 --> 00:04:05.980
drivers that it knows will
work on every machine.

98
00:04:05.980 --> 00:04:07.490
So it might not be the prettiest.

99
00:04:07.490 --> 00:04:11.366
It might not take full advantage of your
resources, but it'll guarantee that you

100
00:04:11.366 --> 00:04:14.359
can at least get the stuff installed and
then use it from there.

101
00:04:14.359 --> 00:04:17.860
So that`s why I`m kind of running it
here in a little boxed in window.

102
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:21.266
>> Don, I love this that they give you
this option to try Ubuntu before you

103
00:04:21.266 --> 00:04:22.612
actually install Ubuntu.

104
00:04:22.612 --> 00:04:25.168
Kind of give you that live environment
without saving anything to your hard

105
00:04:25.168 --> 00:04:26.760
drive, you don`t have to install anything.

106
00:04:26.760 --> 00:04:28.660
And if you like it, then you can install.

107
00:04:28.660 --> 00:04:31.520
>> You know, not every distro does it,
but most of the major ones do.

108
00:04:31.520 --> 00:04:34.559
They call it a live cd although
it`s not really a cd anymore.

109
00:04:34.559 --> 00:04:35.950
>> [LAUGH] yeah.

110
00:04:35.950 --> 00:04:37.150
>> But with a live installation,

111
00:04:37.150 --> 00:04:39.960
what it does is it actually
boots from the USB key.

112
00:04:39.960 --> 00:04:43.610
If I choose that it'll actually load
the rest of the drivers and it'll try and

113
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:45.590
take advantage of all
the hardware I've got and

114
00:04:45.590 --> 00:04:49.010
bring up Ubuntu without
touching my hard drive.

115
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:52.806
So if I have Windows, or
MacOS, or Fedora, like I do,

116
00:04:52.806 --> 00:04:57.774
I could actually boot from Ubuntu and
not break my other installation.

117
00:04:57.774 --> 00:05:02.037
And if I like it and I love it then I can

118
00:05:02.037 --> 00:05:05.924
if I hate it, I just reboot and

119
00:05:05.924 --> 00:05:07.870
So that's what that's all about.

120
00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:10.720
I use this not so much to figure

00:05:10.720 --> 00:05:13.460

122
00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:18.310
If I think I'm gonna need some drivers,

124
00:05:21.910 --> 00:05:23.560
So I can't go and download the drivers.

125
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:24.420
I just lost it.

126
00:05:24.420 --> 00:05:28.860
So I might boot from a live CD like this,
see if the network card works, and

127
00:05:28.860 --> 00:05:30.880

128
00:05:30.880 --> 00:05:34.390
And if it doesn't, I can reboot back

129
00:05:34.390 --> 00:05:37.941
Browse the network, download the drivers
and have them ready ahead of time.

130
00:05:37.941 --> 00:05:42.530
So that`s another great thing we can do

131
00:05:42.530 --> 00:05:48.900

Debian does it, but not every distro does.

132
00:05:48.900 --> 00:05:53.470
Most of the Cent OS disks,
the CentOS disks don't give you a live CD.

133
00:05:53.470 --> 00:05:55.570
Red Hat doesn't give you a live version.

134
00:05:55.570 --> 00:05:57.600
You can make them, but
there's no official one.

135
00:05:57.600 --> 00:05:59.910
This one's official,
it's part of that installation media.

136

00:06:07.319 --> 00:06:12.220

139
00:06:12.220 --> 00:06:14.240

00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:18.170
Ubuntu, the founder Mark Shuttleworth,

00:06:18.170 --> 00:06:20.038
that's where the name of
the product came from.

00:06:20.038 --> 00:06:24.330
Ubuntu is an African word, or

143
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:30.120
an ancient word for, it was like a friends
of humanity or something like that.

144
00:06:30.120 --> 00:06:32.660
>> I am who I am because of who we are,
I think it said.

145
00:06:32.660 --> 00:06:33.220
>> There we go.

146
00:06:33.220 --> 00:06:35.970
Okay, so it's one of those like
multi-meaning type phrases.

147
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:39.760
But this is kind of

148
00:06:39.760 --> 00:06:41.580

00:06:41.580 --> 00:06:43.090

150
00:06:43.090 --> 00:06:45.250
So you can pick whichever

00:06:45.250 --> 00:06:46.570

the user interface.

152
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:49.208
You'll see it's localized

153
00:06:49.208 --> 00:06:51.719
You'll see lots of options in here for
different ones and

154
00:06:51.719 --> 00:06:54.310
there's more if I were
to scroll down to them.

155
00:06:54.310 --> 00:06:56.660
But this isn't the only screen
that's gonna ask us about this.

156
00:06:56.660 --> 00:06:59.328
We'll see some more based
around the keyboard, right?

157
00:06:59.328 --> 00:07:02.813
And in fact, when I booted, you might have
noticed at the bottom of the screen for

158
00:07:02.813 --> 00:07:04.966
a brief moment there was
a picture of a keyboard and

159
00:07:04.966 --> 00:07:06.677
picture of a little person in a circle.

160
00:07:06.677 --> 00:07:08.838
The keyboard icon there,
if I had clicked on it,

161
00:07:08.838 --> 00:07:11.670
would have let me pick
an alternate language keyboard.

162
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:14.190
Not every keyboard has keys
in the same place, and

163
00:07:14.190 --> 00:07:16.050
we need to make sure we
choose the appropriate one.

164
00:07:16.050 --> 00:07:20.368
For example, on my US keyboard,
I can see the letters in the top row

165
00:07:20.368 --> 00:07:24.244
are Q-W-E-R-T-Y, so
we call that a QWERTY keyboard.

166
00:07:24.244 --> 00:07:28.920
But if I were in France, They have
AZERTY keyboards it's A-Z-E-R-T-Y, so

167
00:07:28.920 --> 00:07:30.920
it's a little bit different.

168
00:07:30.920 --> 00:07:36.050
The M key on a US keyboard I
think is actually a semicolon or

169
00:07:36.050 --> 00:07:37.350
something on French keyboard.

170
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:40.290
So those are variations that we need
to pick and you can do that back then.

171
00:07:40.290 --> 00:07:44.450
The accessibility options are if we
need things like a screen reader or

172
00:07:44.450 --> 00:07:48.230
the zoom function or other things to
help us with assistive technologies.

173
00:07:48.230 --> 00:07:51.357
Those are there too as
part of the installer.

174
00:07:51.357 --> 00:07:53.119
But I'm gonna go ahead and
choose to do the install,

175
00:07:53.119 --> 00:07:54.209
since that's what we wanna do.

176
00:07:54.209 --> 00:07:57.790
If I hadn't chosen the keyboard and those
other options back at the boot screen,

177
00:07:57.790 --> 00:07:58.855
you can still do it now.

178
00:07:58.855 --> 00:08:02.935
Notice up here in the top in my top
menu bar, I've got a little person.

179
00:08:02.935 --> 00:08:06.136
And that's where I can turn on the screen
reader, I can turn on braille or

180
00:08:06.136 --> 00:08:06.880
high contrast.

181
00:08:06.880 --> 00:08:09.820
These different options,
same as back there on the boot screen.

182
00:08:09.820 --> 00:08:13.928
And right here the EN is telling me I'm
in the english character map right now.

183
00:08:13.928 --> 00:08:17.230
And I can go to a keyboard layout chart or
text entry settings and

184
