00:28:43.463 --> 00:28:46.100
So try and get it right [LAUGH].

634
00:28:46.100 --> 00:28:48.080
We'll punch in our password.

635
00:28:49.470 --> 00:28:52.630
I'm not putting a very strong one in, so
it's telling me mine is a little bit weak.

636
00:28:52.630 --> 00:28:56.550
And then whether I want to do auto login,
or require the password.

637
00:28:56.550 --> 00:28:58.170
We usually wanna require a password, but

638
00:28:58.170 --> 00:29:01.430
you can do automatic login if it's a home
computer and you don't wanna mess with it.

639
00:29:01.430 --> 00:29:05.190
You do still have a password,
it's just automatically logging in.

640
00:29:05.190 --> 00:29:08.490
And then here's the encrypt my home
folder option I mentioned earlier.

641
00:29:08.490 --> 00:29:09.450
You can do that.

642
00:29:09.450 --> 00:29:12.750
It's decent but it's not as good
as encrypting entire hard drives.

643
00:29:12.750 --> 00:29:14.530
Encrypting the hard drive
is a better option,

644
00:29:14.530 --> 00:29:16.930
but one scenario where
you might like this.

645
00:29:16.930 --> 00:29:18.910
If you have more than one user account,
and

646
00:29:18.910 --> 00:29:21.490
the users are sharing the same computer.

647
00:29:21.490 --> 00:29:23.120
And you encrypt the entire hard drive.

648
00:29:23.120 --> 00:29:25.870
Each user has to be able to
decrypt the entire hard drive, so

649
00:29:25.870 --> 00:29:28.560
the other users would have
access to your data potentially.

650
00:29:28.560 --> 00:29:31.620
So, if I wanted to keep my data private
even from other users of my own computer,

651
00:29:31.620 --> 00:29:33.240
I might choose to encrypt the home folder.

652
00:29:33.240 --> 00:29:35.740
And you can actually do both where
you encrypt the hard drive and

653
00:29:35.740 --> 00:29:38.210
your home folder which will
be the best for both worlds.

654
00:29:38.210 --> 00:29:39.710
But if it's a dedicated machine just for

655
00:29:39.710 --> 00:29:41.549
you, encrypting the hard
drive is the best option.

656
00:29:43.740 --> 00:29:47.340
After that it's got everything it needs
and is gonna start the installer.

657
00:29:47.340 --> 00:29:49.990
Now the installer may take,
it could take ten or

658
00:29:49.990 --> 00:29:52.390
15 minutes, it could take two minutes.

659
00:29:52.390 --> 00:29:53.600
It depends on the speed of your system,

660
00:29:53.600 --> 00:29:57.710
mine will go pretty quick thanks to SSD
but I'm not gonna wait on it because

661
00:29:57.710 --> 00:30:00.570
we're running out of time but in real
life it could take 10 or 15 minutes.

662
00:30:00.570 --> 00:30:03.600
That little orange bar is going to scroll
across the bottom of your screen and

663
00:30:03.600 --> 00:30:06.100
when it's done It's gonna reboot.

664
00:30:06.100 --> 00:30:08.420
And then we're almost done with
getting Ubuntu to installed.

665
00:30:08.420 --> 00:30:11.230
We'll have a few little odds and ends
to take care of as soon as that's done.

666
00:30:11.230 --> 00:30:12.950
>> Well, Don, thanks for
getting us this far.

667
00:30:12.950 --> 00:30:16.090
And if you've never seen a boot
to a Linux installation before or

668
00:30:16.090 --> 00:30:19.180
maybe even a Linux installation before,
Don, I think you did a great job of

669
00:30:19.180 --> 00:30:22.020
demonstrating how that works and
explaining each of the options

670
00:30:22.020 --> 00:30:25.230
that you're going to stumble across
as you work your way through it.

671
00:30:25.230 --> 00:30:27.120
So if you've never see that before,
now you know what those do.

672
00:30:27.120 --> 00:30:30.180
And if you have done it before, maybe you
don't know what each one of those done.

673
00:30:30.180 --> 00:30:33.240
Now if you feel so strong, you're like,
I didn't know that did that,

674
00:30:33.240 --> 00:30:35.750
you can go back and
repartition or something.

675
00:30:35.750 --> 00:30:39.010
Now being said like Don has eluded to,
we are out of time for this episode.

676
00:30:39.010 --> 00:30:42.570
Definitely join us back for
part three to finish installation, but

677
00:30:42.570 --> 00:30:45.040
that is leading us to signing off.

678
00:30:45.040 --> 00:30:47.246
For ITPRO TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

679
00:30:47.246 --> 00:30:47.975
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

680
00:30:47.975 --> 00:30:49.902
>> We'll see you next time.

681
00:30:49.902 --> 00:30:56.177
[MUSIC]

682
00:30:56.177 --> 00:30:59.792
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish walking you through installing Ubuntu Linux. Here they will demonstrate finishing up the install, perform software and kernel updates, and look for any hardware errors that would need troubleshooting with dmesg.
episodes.title: Installing Ubuntu Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:01.251
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.251 --> 00:00:06.659
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.659 --> 00:00:08.878
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.878 --> 00:00:10.607
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.607 --> 00:00:12.791
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:12.791 --> 00:00:16.080
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPRO.TV.

7
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:18.013
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

8
00:00:18.013 --> 00:00:22.821
in today's episode it is more with our
becoming a Linux system administrator.

9
00:00:22.821 --> 00:00:26.676
And joining us back from the studio to
continue our conversation on getting Linux

10
00:00:26.676 --> 00:00:29.963
and Unbuntu or Unbuntu and Linux
should I get that right installed and

11
00:00:29.963 --> 00:00:32.929
completing our installation
our good friend Mr. Don Pesat.

12
00:00:32.929 --> 00:00:35.486
Don we're glad to have you back yet
again, how's it going?

13
00:00:35.486 --> 00:00:39.421
>> Hey it is going great and hopefully
we'll wrap up our install this episode so

14
00:00:39.421 --> 00:00:41.829
we left off with
the installer running right.

15
00:00:41.829 --> 00:00:42.354
>> Yep.

16
00:00:42.354 --> 00:00:43.318
>> The little orange bar
crawling across the screen.

17
00:00:43.318 --> 00:00:45.920
Which is representative of my career.

18
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:47.339
>> [LAUGH]
>> Slowly crawling across the years.

19
00:00:47.339 --> 00:00:51.720
[LAUGH] So anyhow at this point
the install has finished.

20
00:00:51.720 --> 00:00:53.750
And when it's done,
you just get a little screen telling you.

21
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:55.270
As a second it's on my computer right now.

22
00:00:55.270 --> 00:00:57.980
Telling us that the install has completed.

23
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:00.546
And now we're ready to restart,
which is kind of that moment of truth.

24
00:01:00.546 --> 00:01:03.725
Right, that,
we've booted off the install media.

25
00:01:03.725 --> 00:01:06.985
And the install media booted with
a very vanilla set of drivers and

26
00:01:06.985 --> 00:01:08.059
we know that worked.

27
00:01:08.059 --> 00:01:13.340
But after we do that first reboot, now
it's going to reload the full driver set.

28
00:01:13.340 --> 00:01:16.910
And so, just because everything has
gone great right up until this point

29
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:18.840
Doesn't mean things are going
to keep going great.

30
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:22.110
So we've got to be prepared to start
watching for any kind of errors or

31
00:01:22.110 --> 00:01:23.120
other things to happen.

32
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:26.210
That's why it pauses on that screen
instead of just automatically

33
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:27.200
rebooting for us.

34
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:30.170
So that if we walked away, and got some
coffee, took a break, started another

35
00:01:30.170 --> 00:01:33.670
show, then you can come back and
now you can watch that reboot process.

36
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:36.970
That's where we're going to be kicking off
today and actually seeing what happens.

37
00:01:36.970 --> 00:01:38.860
>> All right Don,
well without further ado,

38
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:40.917
I say we jump right back
into where we left off.

39
00:01:40.917 --> 00:01:44.252
>> All right, well I'm gonna take
the plunge, I'm gonna click Restart Now.

40
00:01:44.252 --> 00:01:45.123
>> Do it, do it.

41
00:01:45.123 --> 00:01:47.380
[LAUGH]
>> If you were using a USB key,

42
00:01:47.380 --> 00:01:50.142
this is the point where you would
pop it out of the computer so

43
00:01:50.142 --> 00:01:52.780
that you wouldn't boot
back up off of it again.

44
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:56.970
If you used a boot menu like pressing
F12 to get to it or something like that,

45
00:01:56.970 --> 00:01:59.530
then usually you don't have to
worry about taking the key out,

46
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:03.240
because it's just gonna reboot and
come back up and you'll be fine.

47
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:05.120
So my system is rebooting.

48
00:02:05.120 --> 00:02:09.450
And what we hope to see is something
more than just a black screen.

49
00:02:09.450 --> 00:02:13.960
So what we should be seeing, here shortly,
is the Ubuntu logo should pop up.

50
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:16.720
And we may see some text scrolling by.

51
00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:18.840
A lot of times this stuff gets hidden.

52
00:02:18.840 --> 00:02:21.390
It hides the text scrolling by so
that we don't see it.

53
00:02:21.390 --> 00:02:24.150
You just see the Ubuntu logo and
it's nice and pretty.

54
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:28.180
But if it doesn't happen,
if it sees like even one error,

55
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:30.640
it'll get rid of that logo and
actually start showing the text.

56
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:32.316
So when you start seeing that scroll
by that's an indicator that something

57
00:02:32.316 --> 00:02:32.856
might have gone wrong.

58
00:02:32.856 --> 00:02:37.930
Unfortunately, while it shows you
the text it doesn't actually slow down or

59
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:38.954
pause for you.

60
00:02:38.954 --> 00:02:40.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> It shoots right on by.

61
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:43.530
So, that's where we talked
about this in earlier episodes.

62
00:02:43.530 --> 00:02:46.100
We'll need to get the system online so
that we can look at D message.

63
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:48.310
We can look at the logs and
we can see what happened.

64
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:50.750
Now my system is still sitting
here in a black screen.

65
00:02:50.750 --> 00:02:51.467
And I haven't seen the little logo.
So,

66
00:02:51.467 --> 00:02:55.281
this is probably indicating that
it hasn't actually restarted.

67
00:02:55.281 --> 00:02:58.158
I clicked the restart button and
it closed the graphics and

68
00:02:58.158 --> 00:03:01.447
right now it's reaching out to
the motherboard and saying, hey,

69
00:03:01.447 --> 00:03:04.510
let me trigger ACPI and
tell it to reboot the system.

70
00:03:04.510 --> 00:03:06.695
Now, if it doesn't have the right
driver for the motherboard or

71
00:03:06.695 --> 00:03:08.759
if can't communicate like that
then it might not restart and

72
00:03:08.759 --> 00:03:10.065
that's maybe what's going on here.

73
00:03:10.065 --> 00:03:11.949
>> That's probably an issue
because it's a virtual machine and

74
00:03:11.949 --> 00:03:13.222
not actually reaching the motherboard.

75
00:03:13.222 --> 00:03:17.165
>> More than likely, in my scenario, but
it could happen on a real machine as well.

76
00:03:17.165 --> 00:03:17.688
>> Right.

77
00:03:17.688 --> 00:03:20.700
>> And if that's the case, the solution
here is actually not very elegant.

78
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:22.570
>> Yeah Don,
when you say not very elegant,

79
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:25.760
we basically are talking about brut
forcing the power off with your

80
00:03:25.760 --> 00:03:28.150
finger on the button until it shuts off,
right?

81
00:03:28.150 --> 00:03:31.750
>> Yeah, and we don't like to do that cuz
you can get disk errors, improper rights,

82
00:03:31.750 --> 00:03:32.790
they don't finish.

83
00:03:32.790 --> 00:03:36.990
But in this part of the install,
it's done, it's already installed.

84
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:38.670
It's supposed to be shutting down.

85
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:39.620
All the rights should be committed.

86
00:03:39.620 --> 00:03:40.790
So it's pretty safe to do.

87
00:03:40.790 --> 00:03:43.260
So I'm just gonna hit that
power button and there we go.

88
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:45.330
So it's gonna start a restart.

89
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:48.020
It's gonna come up, the Ubuntu
logo will flash by, really fast.

90
00:03:48.020 --> 00:03:50.670
But hopefully, this is what we see.

91
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:51.373
And I've got my little speaker turned off.

92
00:03:51.373 --> 00:03:53.491
You'd normally hear a, dungdung, noise.

93
00:03:53.491 --> 00:03:53.997
>> Yeah.

94
00:03:53.997 --> 00:03:56.544
>> Ubuntu makes every time it books up.

95
00:03:56.544 --> 00:03:59.942
So, once it's up and running,
here I am, I'm at my login screen,

96
00:03:59.942 --> 00:04:02.940
with the user account that was
created during the install.

97
00:04:02.940 --> 00:04:06.320
So I should be able to login,
assuming I remember my password.

98
00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:11.420
And we could get logged in, and now,
we're up and we're running Ubuntu.

99
00:04:11.420 --> 00:04:14.860
Now, you might say to yourself,
we're done.

100
00:04:14.860 --> 00:04:16.600
But you're not technically done.

101
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.486
There's still some odds and ends we've got
to get taken care of here to make sure.

102
00:04:19.486 --> 00:04:22.595
But, we are past the major-
>> We are done-ish.

103
00:04:22.595 --> 00:04:26.450
[LAUGH]
>> Right, we've made our major decisions,

104
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:30.050
dispartitioning, and
all of that are done and put in place.

105
00:04:30.050 --> 00:04:34.480
And in fact, if I start doing things
like jumping into a terminal and

106
00:04:34.480 --> 00:04:37.202
browsing around and looking for things,

107
00:04:37.202 --> 00:04:40.873
then I should see that that's
all already being filed.

108
00:04:40.873 --> 00:04:42.718
Whoops, a little too big there.

109
00:04:42.718 --> 00:04:43.321
There we go.
So

110
00:04:43.321 --> 00:04:46.614
that petitioning scheme should
already in place for me.

111
00:04:46.614 --> 00:04:51.006
If I do something like a df-h and
look, I can kind of look in here and

112
00:04:51.006 --> 00:04:55.680
see where I've got my root partition
is showing up as 5.4 gigs.

113
00:04:55.680 --> 00:05:00.050
My home partition is 24 gigs,
my boot partition is 1.9 gigs.

114
00:05:00.050 --> 00:05:02.820
Right, there's all those partitions
we created during the install.

115
00:05:02.820 --> 00:05:04.760
And they're all setup for us.

116
00:05:04.760 --> 00:05:06.400
As a user I don't even
have to think about them,

117
00:05:06.400 --> 00:05:07.870
I just browse around on the hard drive and

118
00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:12.650
I don't realize that I'm moving between
partitions when I do something like that.

119
00:05:12.650 --> 00:05:15.140
But it's happening in the background.

120
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:18.510
The swap partition is already activated,
and it's up and running.

121
00:05:18.510 --> 00:05:20.200
My software appears to be working.

122
00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:25.133
Now, I'm still in a 4x3 resolution,
so I might need to go in and

123
00:05:25.133 --> 00:05:26.945
customize my desktop.

124
00:05:26.945 --> 00:05:31.000
You've got your settings icon right here
in your launchpad, where you can go into

125
00:05:31.000 --> 00:05:35.013
your displays and modify the resolution to
set it to whatever it is that you want.

126
00:05:35.013 --> 00:05:39.741
So maybe, I want to jump it all the way
up to 1920 by 1080 or 1280 by 720.

127
00:05:39.741 --> 00:05:42.810
We can start to experiment around with
these things to get it configured

128
00:05:42.810 --> 00:05:44.048
properly for our computer.

129
00:05:44.048 --> 00:05:49.760
And when we do that you may find, where
some of the settings work just great.

130
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:52.100
And everything is now perfect and happy.

131
00:05:52.100 --> 00:05:56.190
Other times, where a setting doesn't work
quite right, and you've got to tweak

132
00:05:56.190 --> 00:05:59.410
it some more and adjust it to get things
kind of configured the way you want.

133
00:05:59.410 --> 00:06:04.280
But as far as the core OS,
we are actually done with that part, but

134
00:06:04.280 --> 00:06:07.300
there's always a little bit of
administrative tasks that I want to do as

135
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:09.080
soon as an install is done.

136
00:06:09.080 --> 00:06:10.010
One of those,

137
00:06:10.010 --> 00:06:13.970
is I want to check to see if there were
any errors in hardware detection, right,

138
00:06:13.970 --> 00:06:17.750
which In our managing hardware episode,
I covered how to do that.

139
00:06:17.750 --> 00:06:20.520
So, if you didn't watch the episode
though, just a quick summary.

140
00:06:20.520 --> 00:06:23.050
Drop to a terminal and
use the D message command.

141
00:06:23.050 --> 00:06:25.160
D message will show you
everything that happened in boot.

142
00:06:25.160 --> 00:06:26.810
All the stuff that was hidden from us,

143
00:06:26.810 --> 00:06:30.970
during the boot will be tucked
away inside of D message output.

144
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:36.247
So if we run d-m-e-s-g, D message, that
shows everything that happened, and a lot

145
00:06:36.247 --> 00:06:40.692
of this is good stuff, good information
that, it found my network card.

146
00:06:40.692 --> 00:06:44.778
It did whatever, but
if we pipe that into grep,

147
00:06:44.778 --> 00:06:49.300
we can always do a search for
the word error.

148
00:06:49.300 --> 00:06:51.217
And just see if any errors popped up,
and I did get one.

149
00:06:51.217 --> 00:06:57.949
In EXT4 error there on VDA5 was remounted,
which is not actually a big deal here.

150
00:06:57.949 --> 00:07:01.662
It's just saying, one of the options was,
if there is an error,

151
00:07:01.662 --> 00:07:03.970
we're going to remount it as read only.

152
00:07:03.970 --> 00:07:06.460
So, that's actually fine,
we expect to see that one.

153
00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:07.559
There weren't any other errors.
So it looks good.

154
00:07:07.559 --> 00:07:12.047
If all my hardware was detected, if I hear
sound, then I'm in good shape, otherwise,

155
00:07:12.047 --> 00:07:14.778
I need to go back to that
managing hardware episode and

156
00:07:14.778 --> 00:07:16.550
see how all that works from there.

157
00:07:16.550 --> 00:07:19.080
>> Man, that's a whole lot
easier than just going, why am

158
00:07:19.080 --> 00:07:22.610
I not getting any network connectivity or
where's the sound in this stinking thing?

159
00:07:22.610 --> 00:07:23.800
Why isn't that working?

160
00:07:23.800 --> 00:07:26.325
>> Yeah looking at those logs
that will save you a ton of time.

161
00:07:26.325 --> 00:07:29.005
The other thing that we
need to do are updates.

162
00:07:29.005 --> 00:07:31.929
Now, I chose not to download
updates during my install and

163
00:07:31.929 --> 00:07:33.550
there are two reasons I do that.

164
00:07:33.550 --> 00:07:36.821
One, is I was in a hurry.

165
00:07:36.821 --> 00:07:38.704
>> [LAUGH]
>> And two,

166
00:07:38.704 --> 00:07:42.904
is the updates that it downloads are just
the updates for this particular version,

167
00:07:42.904 --> 00:07:47.150
and it won't update certain things like
the kernel that's shipped with it.

168
00:07:47.150 --> 00:07:51.793
Now, if I'm running Ubuntu 16.04,
there's been 16.04.1 and .2, since then,

169
00:07:51.793 --> 00:07:54.451
and by the time you watch this show,
maybe even a .3 and

170
00:07:54.451 --> 00:07:57.814
there are kernel updates from time
to time, and those won't happen.

171
00:07:57.814 --> 00:08:02.860
So I need to go in and
do a full set of updates on this system.

172
00:08:02.860 --> 00:08:06.002
Now you might be tempted to use
the updates that are right here as part

173
00:08:06.002 --> 00:08:07.004

>> It's pretty good, yeah.

399
00:18:52.680 --> 00:18:55.176
All right, well Daniel,
I think that's a pretty good spot for

400
00:18:55.176 --> 00:18:56.504
us to wrap up installing Ubuntu.

401
00:18:56.504 --> 00:18:59.227
We've seen that whole process
from the very beginning of

creating our install media to
performing the installation, and

403
00:19:02.347 --> 00:19:04.627
then now performing
the post-install tasks.

404
00:19:04.627 --> 00:19:08.048
It's done and
now we get a usable computer.

405
00:19:08.048 --> 00:19:09.632
>> All right, well, Don,
we do thank you for

406
00:19:09.632 --> 00:19:11.362
walking us through
the Ubuntu installation.

407
00:19:11.362 --> 00:19:15.473
It was pretty painless and now we have
a little more knowledge to be able

408
00:19:15.473 --> 00:19:18.061
to do that task ourselves
in real life land.

409
00:19:18.061 --> 00:19:21.088
That being said, and looks like
we're at the end of our episode.

410
00:19:21.088 --> 00:19:22.824
We do thank you for watching,
we hope you enjoyed it.

411
00:19:22.824 --> 00:19:25.421
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

>> In

We're gonna take a look at

And how we can get it, build our
installation media, get it installed,

00:00:47.580 --> 00:00:51.870
get it updated, and actually start to

20

Now everybody out there has their

People find their favorite and

00:00:57.140 --> 00:00:59.560
My personal favorite does happen to be

23
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:03.350
So looking forward to this episode and

00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:04.310
running in your environment.

25
00:01:04.310 --> 00:01:08.070
>> I half expect Don to pull out a red
fedora at some point and put it on for

00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:10.770

28

I guess when it comes to installing
a new operating system or picking

an operating system, the first thing we

30

31
00:01:19.582 --> 00:01:22.290
>> All right, well we can get a copy
of Fedora right from their web page,

32
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:24.650
which is actually,
let me pull it up right here.

33

The getfedora.org.

34
00:01:26.557 --> 00:01:28.895
And you know-
>> That's pretty helpful.

35

[LAUGH]
>> I wanna get Fedora, where do I go?

36
00:01:30.408 --> 00:01:31.583
Getfedora.org.

37
00:01:31.583 --> 00:01:35.840
That .org is kind of important because
it is a non-profit organization, right.

38
00:01:35.840 --> 00:01:38.620
Fedora is completely free.

39
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:41.725
And like many operating systems
you might ask yourself,

40
00:01:41.725 --> 00:01:43.970
well how can it be completely free?

41
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:45.250
How do they make their money?

42
00:01:45.250 --> 00:01:47.010
We talked about Ubuntu in other episodes.

43
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:49.440
That company is canonical and

44
00:01:49.440 --> 00:01:52.730
they make their money based on
selling support agreements, right.

45
00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:55.115
In Fedora land, they don't do support.

46
00:01:55.115 --> 00:01:56.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you're on your own.

47
00:01:56.990 --> 00:01:58.250
So how do they make money?

48
00:01:58.250 --> 00:01:59.010
And the reality is,

49
00:01:59.010 --> 00:02:03.670
that Fedora is actually not an independent
operating system all by itself.

50
00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:07.242
Fedora actually starts at Red Hat.

51
00:02:07.242 --> 00:02:10.320
Red Hat is the largest commercial

52
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:13.130
entity that releases a Linux
distribution in the world.

53
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:16.310
They have a distribution called
Red Hat Enterprise Linux, or

54
00:02:16.310 --> 00:02:19.220
RHEL, and companies can buy it.

55
00:02:19.220 --> 00:02:23.096
And it costs, I believe it`s something
like $350 per server as a license.

56
00:02:23.096 --> 00:02:25.989
And when you purchase that
you get a year of support and

57
00:02:25.989 --> 00:02:29.175
you can call them and get help and
that`s Red Hat, right.

58
00:02:29.175 --> 00:02:30.946
It`s a commercial distribution.

59
00:02:30.946 --> 00:02:33.376
But under the Open Source license,

60
00:02:33.376 --> 00:02:38.800
they have to make their source code
available for free, and so they do.

61
00:02:38.800 --> 00:02:41.704
And so there's another organization
out there called CentOS,

62
00:02:41.704 --> 00:02:44.250
the Community Enterprise Operating System.

63
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:47.860
And what they do is they take all
the source code that Red Hat releases and

64
00:02:47.860 --> 00:02:51.750
they just recompile it without the Red Hat
logos cuz those are copyrighted.

65
00:02:51.750 --> 00:02:55.350
And then they release it as
basically Red Hat that's free.

66
00:02:55.350 --> 00:02:58.800
Now Red Hat focuses on stability.

67
00:02:58.800 --> 00:03:03.210
They want to have the most stable,
rock solid operating system possible so

68
00:03:03.210 --> 00:03:05.130
that businesses can use it and
use it reliably.

69
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:06.350
You can run it on your servers.

70
00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:10.080
When I spin up a Linux server,
if I'm given a choice I use Red Hat for

71
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:13.760
my Linux servers almost exclusively,
that's the operating system I prefer.

72
00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:17.880
It cost money but
it is very very stable, all right.

73
00:03:17.880 --> 00:03:22.520
But on the desktop Red Hat is
a bit of a mixed bag because

74
00:03:22.520 --> 00:03:27.250
by getting stability they give up being
on the latest cutting edge features.

75
00:03:27.250 --> 00:03:31.580
They like a feature to be out for a few
years before they adopt it into the OS.

76
00:03:31.580 --> 00:03:34.820
That means they want these features
to be tested and tried and

77
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:39.027
proven true out there in the field before
bringing it into the rank and file OS.

78
00:03:39.027 --> 00:03:44.410
Now the way they do that,
is through their Fedora project.

79
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:47.450
Fedora is an extension of Red Hat.

80
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:50.430
In fact, the majority of the people
that work on the Fedora project

81
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:52.090
are actually Red Hat employees.

82
00:03:52.090 --> 00:03:54.170
They draw their salary from Red Hat.

83
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:57.150
So whenever there's a new feature,
something exciting and fancy and

84
00:03:57.150 --> 00:04:00.830
cutting edge that Red Hat wants to try,
they put it in Fedora first.

85
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:02.860
And they let it cook in Fedora for
a year or two.

86
00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:06.880
And after they've seen that feature
stabilized, they've fixed the bugs,

87
00:04:06.880 --> 00:04:10.810
they get everything working perfectly,
then they integrate it into Red Hat.

88
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:13.580
So if you want a rock solid,
stable OS you go with Red Hat,

89
00:04:13.580 --> 00:04:15.540
but you're not going to
have the latest features.

90
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:17.160
If you want the latest
features you go with Fedora.

91
00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:21.240
Now as an IT administrator we're
pretty comfortable with dealing with

92
00:04:21.240 --> 00:04:24.600
little issues and getting things
squared away, so Fedora works great.

93
00:04:24.600 --> 00:04:27.580
But for a production desktop
you might not want that.

94
00:04:27.580 --> 00:04:31.660
So these are all related,
Red Hat, CentOS, and Fedora.

95
00:04:31.660 --> 00:04:34.520
I like Fedora because it does
give me the latest software, and

96
00:04:34.520 --> 00:04:36.380
as an IT guy I need that.

97
00:04:36.380 --> 00:04:40.490
So I can go to the Fedora project's
website and I can download the latest and

98
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:41.660
greatest distro.

99
00:04:41.660 --> 00:04:43.420
Now they do have more than one version.

100
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:47.140
As you scroll down, you'll see where
they've got a workstation, a server, and

101
00:04:47.140 --> 00:04:48.530
atomic, all right.

102
00:04:48.530 --> 00:04:52.170
Now technically all three
of these are the same OS.

103
00:04:52.170 --> 00:04:54.620
Under the hood,
you've got the same Linux kernel

104
00:04:54.620 --> 00:04:57.990
with the same Fedora core utilities.

105
00:04:57.990 --> 00:05:00.920
Where it gets different is what's
added on after that, right.

106
00:05:00.920 --> 00:05:05.830
The workstation includes a graphical
user interface, LibreOffice,

107
00:05:05.830 --> 00:05:07.610
it's got the GNOME window manager.

108
00:05:07.610 --> 00:05:10.280
All the different things that
we want on a desktop, right.

109
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:13.340
And that's actually what I'm running on my
very laptop right now, what we're seeing,

110
00:05:13.340 --> 00:05:14.519
I'm running Fedora Workstation.

111
00:05:15.790 --> 00:05:17.963
On a server though, we don't need a GUI.

112
00:05:17.963 --> 00:05:21.317
We don't need GNOME, we don't need
all these desktopie type features,

113
00:05:21.317 --> 00:05:22.990
we don't need LibreOffice.

114
00:05:22.990 --> 00:05:25.650
And so with the server install,
it's scaled down,

115
00:05:25.650 --> 00:05:27.380
it leaves all that software off.

116
00:05:27.380 --> 00:05:32.250
Now I could install the server version and
add the graphical user interface to it,

117
00:05:32.250 --> 00:05:35.180
and all of a sudden I'm basically
a workstation because the core OS

118
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:35.790
is the same.

119
00:05:35.790 --> 00:05:38.430
There's not a functional
difference between these two

120
00:05:38.430 --> 00:05:40.830
aside from the packages that
are installed by default.

121
00:05:40.830 --> 00:05:43.495
It's really just
a repackage of the same OS.

122
00:05:43.495 --> 00:05:48.100
And Atomic is one of the newest ones,
and this one is scaled down even more.

123
00:05:48.100 --> 00:05:52.902
The operating system is insanely basic
because it's got just enough to be able to

124
00:05:52.902 --> 00:05:55.230
run container applications.

125
00:05:55.230 --> 00:05:58.150
So if you hear people who are excited
about Docker, right, Docker,

126
00:05:58.150 --> 00:05:59.050
you can take an application and

127
00:05:59.050 --> 00:06:01.550
you stick it in a container and
you can run that container anywhere.

128
00:06:01.550 --> 00:06:04.320
Atomic is designed to be
a host that can provide that.

129
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:08.278
And so if you look it says, Fedora Atomic
provides the best platform for your Linux,

130
00:06:08.278 --> 00:06:10.580
Docker, Cubernetis, LDK applications tech.

131
00:06:10.580 --> 00:06:14.550
>> Wow, that's congratulations to them,
they have the best.

132
00:06:14.550 --> 00:06:15.221
[LAUGH]
>> The best, yes,

133
00:06:15.221 --> 00:06:16.548
as tested by their marketing team.

134
00:06:16.548 --> 00:06:18.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> So who knows if the best or not, but

135
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:21.230
that's what that one's available for.

136
00:06:21.230 --> 00:06:23.530
So most of us aren't going to want Atomic.

137
00:06:23.530 --> 00:06:26.120
If you're a developer, if you're doing
whatever, then you might want Atomic.

138
00:06:26.120 --> 00:06:29.440
But Atomic would be designed to run
on a server because it's not gonna

139
00:06:29.440 --> 00:06:32.250

really work with very well.

140
00:06:32.250 --> 00:06:35.070
So in this show,
I'm gonna be using Workstation.

141
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:37.110
But again,
the install would be the same for Server,

00:06:37.110 --> 00:06:39.410
it's just gonna be less software
packages that are installed.

143
00:06:39.410 --> 00:06:43.550
So when you float over Workstation, you'll
see that Download Now button I can hit.

144
00:06:43.550 --> 00:06:45.720
And that's gonna take me
to the download screen.

145
00:06:45.720 --> 00:06:49.710
Now the current version of
Fedora is Fedora 25, all right.

146
00:06:49.710 --> 00:06:53.250
And with Fedora 25, that's gonna give
us the latest and greatest features.

147
00:06:53.250 --> 00:06:56.420
And so it's the default
download right here, okay.

148
00:06:56.420 --> 00:07:00.190
Notice that it's a 64 bit OS, that's

149
00:07:00.190 --> 00:07:04.290
And so I can pull it or right beneath it
there's a little link here that says,

150
00:07:04.290 --> 00:07:07.720
do I need instructions or
a different version?

151
00:07:07.720 --> 00:07:10.820
There are other versions
of Fedora available.

152
00:07:10.820 --> 00:07:14.149
And you kinda see that here on
the web page under other downloads.

153
00:07:14.149 --> 00:07:17.500
The 64 bit version is the default,
but there is a 32 bit version.

154
00:07:17.500 --> 00:07:21.870
If I've got a 32 bit processor and
I try and boot off of a 64 bit installer,

155
00:07:21.870 --> 00:07:23.360
I'll just get a black screen.

156
00:07:23.360 --> 00:07:26.424
It won't do it, right,
it can't run a 64 bit instruction set.

157
00:07:26.424 --> 00:07:31.090
But I can run 32 bit on either 64 or
32 bit.

158
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:33.580
The thing is on a 32 bit system,

159
00:07:33.580 --> 00:07:37.300
no one application can consume
more than 4 gigs of RAM.

160
00:07:37.300 --> 00:07:39.470
You can have more than four gigs of RAM,
but

161
00:07:39.470 --> 00:07:42.450
each application would be
limited to four gigs itself.

162
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:44.780
And if you're running a database software,

163
00:07:44.780 --> 00:07:46.810
then it may need way more
than four gigs of RAM.

164
00:07:46.810 --> 00:07:49.763
Or video editing, always, it'll take
as much RAM as you can get it, right.

165
00:07:49.763 --> 00:07:53.287
And on a 32 bit system it would be
artificially held to this 4 gig limit

166
00:07:53.287 --> 00:07:56.723
because of the address space is not
large enough to go beyond 4 gigs.

167
00:07:56.723 --> 00:07:58.685
In 64 bit we can though.

168
00:07:58.685 --> 00:08:00.646
And so in most of our distributions or

169
00:08:00.646 --> 00:08:04.780
most of our installs on most of our
computers today, we want 64 bit.

170
00:08:04.780 --> 00:08:09.030
In fact if you bought a computer
in the last seven years probably,

171
00:08:09.030 --> 00:08:10.920
it should be 64 bit capable.

172
00:08:10.920 --> 00:08:14.270
If you're not sure you can always drop
to a command line and do an LSCPU and

173
00:08:14.270 --> 00:08:17.900
it will tell you, or if you're in Windows
you can run utilities like CPUID.

174
00:08:17.900 --> 00:08:20.620
And they'll tell you what CPU you have,
and you should see that it

175
00:08:20.620 --> 00:08:22.200
has 64 bits imported/g/
>> Now Don,

176
00:08:22.200 --> 00:08:26.150
if I have a little laptop laying around,
maybe it's 10 years old or whatever,

177
00:08:26.150 --> 00:08:28.970
sitting in a closet, and
I think I wanna play with Fedora,

178
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:31.850
would that work on this or
is there a hardware compatibility list?

179
00:08:31.850 --> 00:08:36.440
Or specs that I have to meet for
Fedora to be my OS of choice?

180
00:08:36.440 --> 00:08:37.660
>> The other will work.

181
00:08:37.660 --> 00:08:38.980
>> Yeah.
>> They do have,

182
00:08:38.980 --> 00:08:41.860
if you poke around on the page you'll see
where they've got a lot of information

183
00:08:41.860 --> 00:08:45.530
here on the installation guide and
common bugs and

184
00:08:45.530 --> 00:08:48.320
things that layout what
you're expected to have.

185
00:08:48.320 --> 00:08:52.330
But the reality is that Fedora will
run on a ton of different hardware,

186
00:08:52.330 --> 00:08:53.040
even on older hardware.

187
00:08:53.040 --> 00:08:54.508
It may not run as well,

188
00:08:54.508 --> 00:08:57.130
there's other distros out there
a little more tuned to it.

189
00:08:57.130 --> 00:08:59.820
But usually it's just your window
manager that affects performance.

190
00:08:59.820 --> 00:09:02.100
And with fedora, it's gonna
install the GNONME Window Manager,

191
00:09:02.100 --> 00:09:03.470
which is not the best for performance.

192
00:09:03.470 --> 00:09:06.310
So you might wanna change to XFCE or
one of the other ones.

193
00:09:06.310 --> 00:09:06.970
And it'll run great.

194
00:09:06.970 --> 00:09:08.256
But yeah, you'll see all that.

195
00:09:08.256 --> 00:09:10.180
If I were to do this
need instructions link,

196
00:09:10.180 --> 00:09:13.770
see how it just takes me right down
here to the things that I'm identifying.

197
00:09:13.770 --> 00:09:17.750
But it tells you how to obtain the media
and it gives the other information here to

198
00:09:17.750 --> 00:09:21.456
find out whether or not your system
meets the specs and what you need.

199
00:09:21.456 --> 00:09:25.220
All right, now if I want to install this,

200
00:09:25.220 --> 00:09:28.610
I need to come up with an idea of
how I'm gonna be doing the install.

201
00:09:28.610 --> 00:09:31.070
And there's a few different
ways we can do it.

202
00:09:31.070 --> 00:09:33.170
But normally,
it's gonna boil down to two things.

203
00:09:33.170 --> 00:09:37.390
Either installing from a CD-ROM or
installing from a USB key, okay?

204
00:09:37.390 --> 00:09:40.560
Now most of what we're gonna see
on here hints at being run from

205
00:09:40.560 --> 00:09:43.970
a CD-ROM because that's how things were
done for years and years and years, right?

206
00:09:43.970 --> 00:09:46.317
But I don't have a CD drive in my laptop.

207
00:09:46.317 --> 00:09:47.258
Daniel do you have one in yours?

00:09:47.258 --> 00:09:48.280

00:20:31.577 --> 00:20:34.600

00:20:34.600 --> 00:20:41.010

00:20:41.010 --> 00:20:44.173
pv is a utility that's been

00:20:44.173 --> 00:20:47.340

00:20:47.340 --> 00:20:51.120

00:20:51.120 --> 00:20:55.700

00:20:55.700 --> 00:20:57.420

00:20:57.420 --> 00:20:59.940
the newer versions of DD have

00:20:59.940 --> 00:21:04.515
So when I run that, it's gonna start,
and ooh, I got an error.

00:21:04.515 --> 00:21:07.928
/dev/sdb, I did spell it right, didn't I?

00:21:07.928 --> 00:21:08.519
>> sdb.

00:21:08.519 --> 00:21:11.280
>> All right, so
I got an error writing that output file.

00:21:11.280 --> 00:21:14.520

it wasn't too happy with that.

00:21:14.520 --> 00:21:17.616
This can be caused by
a few different things.

00:21:17.616 --> 00:21:19.130

451
00:21:19.130 --> 00:21:21.190
not giving it
the administrative privileges.

452
00:21:21.190 --> 00:21:24.480
But it could also be that there are some
partition on there that's protected or

00:21:24.480 --> 00:21:26.150
even in use, right?

454
00:21:26.150 --> 00:21:30.170
When I popped in that USB key,
it's possible that the operating system is

455
00:21:30.170 --> 00:21:32.960
already dove in there and
started messing with it.

456
00:21:32.960 --> 00:21:35.260
So I might need to unmount that disk.

457
00:21:35.260 --> 00:21:39.715
Now, if I run the mount command,
it'll show me things that are mounted.

458
00:21:39.715 --> 00:21:42.333
And you can look in here, there`s kind of

00:21:42.333 --> 00:21:42.925
>> Grab that out.

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, sdb.

I don`t see sdb, it`s not mounted.

00:21:46.156 --> 00:21:48.442
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> So it`s not mounted,

00:21:48.442 --> 00:21:50.301
I bet if I rerun this, it just works.

464
00:21:50.301 --> 00:21:51.628
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

465
00:21:51.628 --> 00:21:52.724
>> That does happen.

466
00:21:52.724 --> 00:21:54.755
But a lot of times you`ll see,
and there it goes.

467
00:21:54.755 --> 00:21:56.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> Where if the disk was mounted and

468
00:21:56.410 --> 00:21:59.992
it just had a hard time unmounting it,
then you might get an error like that.

469
00:21:59.992 --> 00:22:03.370
So I just double checked if
it was mounted, mine wasn't.

470
00:22:03.370 --> 00:22:07.180
But if it was, you could use
the umount command, or unmount, sorry.

471
00:22:07.180 --> 00:22:11.650
So I would say, sudo unmount/dev/sdb,
and that would unmount it.

472
00:22:11.650 --> 00:22:13.330
Or it usually be a partition inside of it.

473
00:22:13.330 --> 00:22:17.760
So the /dev/sdb1 or /sdb2, or so on.

474
00:22:17.760 --> 00:22:21.570
And that'll unmount it, get it out
of there, and once it’s free, then,

475
00:22:21.570 --> 00:22:23.240
you can run the command and do it again.

476
00:22:23.240 --> 00:22:25.260
In my case,
it would probably just slow to unmount,

477
00:22:25.260 --> 00:22:28.750
and that’s why when I ran it

00:22:28.750 --> 00:22:31.940
Now, it’s churning along, and

00:22:31.940 --> 00:22:33.780

00:22:43.938 --> 00:22:44.680

485

It's just churning along and
when it ends, it ends, right?

486
00:22:47.490 --> 00:22:52.140
So at this rate, it looks like it's
probably gonna take another two or

three minutes.

488
00:22:53.070 --> 00:22:54.870
And we don't need to sit around and

00:22:54.870 --> 00:22:59.020

490
00:22:59.020 --> 00:23:02.630
It's not like you're gonna see fireworks
or anything, [LAUGH] it just stops.

491

492
00:23:05.710 --> 00:23:10.840

493
00:23:10.840 --> 00:23:14.550
So that makes life super easy,
and I can hang onto that.

494
00:23:14.550 --> 00:23:19.275
This DD process I just showed you works
on Mac OS, and on Linux, and Unix BSD,

495
00:23:19.275 --> 00:23:20.674
works on any of those.

496
00:23:20.674 --> 00:23:23.145
Windows is the only one that
would be different, and

00:23:23.145 --> 00:23:26.260

the Rawrite32 utility.

498
00:23:26.260 --> 00:23:30.620
Those are both ones that work reliably for
creating an installation media.

499
00:23:30.620 --> 00:23:32.642
All right, but that being said,
this is probably a good spot for

00:23:43.070 --> 00:23:46.955
So in this episode,
we got a chance to see what Fedora is and

504
00:23:46.955 --> 00:23:49.320
kinda how it came about
from the Red Hat world.

00:23:49.320 --> 00:23:51.633
And we saw creating that
installation media.

506
00:23:51.633 --> 00:23:54.090
In the next episode,
we'll get a chance to install it.

00:23:54.090 --> 00:23:55.271
>> All right, well, Don,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue walking you through installing Fedora Linux. Here they demonstrate how to boot the installation media from a usb key, explore configuring the hard disk partitions, configuring the time zone, and setting up network connectivity in the installer.
episodes.title: Installing Fedora Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish walking you through installing Fedora Linux. Here they will explore and explain logging in for the first time, and post-install administration like checking for hardware error with dmesg and installing software and/or kernel updates.
episodes.title: Installing Fedora Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at performing an unattended installation of your Linux distro. Here they will explain and explore how to use Kickstart to build an answer file which will answer all the necessary configuration questions for a light-touch install. Then they will show you how to deploy your Kickstart answer file to install the OS.
episodes.title: Enterprise Installations

environment it allows you to boot

00:03:51.470 --> 00:03:52.902

00:03:52.902 --> 00:03:53.553

00:03:53.553 --> 00:04:00.080
>> Okay, when you install Red Hat,
Fedora or right?

00:04:00.080 --> 00:04:02.470

00:04:02.470 --> 00:04:06.090

00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:08.610

00:04:08.610 --> 00:04:09.720
that you have to answer.

93
00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:12.050
What you don't realize is
that in the background,

00:04:12.050 --> 00:04:14.940
it says I wonder if these

95
00:04:14.940 --> 00:04:19.590
And if they are,
I can get all the answers ahead of time.

96
00:04:19.590 --> 00:04:24.240
Kickstart is a system where we provide
answers to Anaconda's questions

97
00:04:24.240 --> 00:04:27.450
In a predefined format, so
it doesn't have to ask us.

98
00:04:27.450 --> 00:04:29.360
So the install can run automatically.

99
00:04:29.360 --> 00:04:31.990
A lot of people refer to this

00:04:31.990 --> 00:04:33.440

101
00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:34.230
You don't have to watch it.

102
00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:36.560
It'll answer everything just
the way that you want to.

103
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:39.343
Some people call it an LTE,
a light touch, or

104
00:04:39.343 --> 00:04:44.260
LTI light touch installation or

105
00:04:44.260 --> 00:04:46.427
You never truly have zero though cuz
somebody's gotta push that power button.

106
00:04:46.427 --> 00:04:49.750
There's gonna be a touch there somewhere.

107
00:04:49.750 --> 00:04:52.460
But that's what kickstart is,
it's really just an answer file.

108
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:54.030
It's answering all the questions.

109
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:55.840
Well what were the questions we had?

110
00:04:55.840 --> 00:04:57.280

00:04:57.280 --> 00:04:58.690

00:04:58.690 --> 00:05:00.220

113
00:05:00.220 --> 00:05:01.660
We had to create a user account,

114
00:05:01.660 --> 00:05:05.850
set a time zone,
maybe configure a network adapter right?

115
00:05:05.850 --> 00:05:07.840
Nothing earth shattering here,
not hard stuff,

116
00:05:07.840 --> 00:05:11.090
it's just stuff that had to be
provided as part of the core install.

117
00:05:11.090 --> 00:05:16.720
So what kickstart does is it allows us to
build a file that has those answers and

118
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:20.750
when you start the installer,
It looks for that file.

119
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:22.770
And it can actually look
several different places.

120
00:05:22.770 --> 00:05:24.900
Now a file can be right on the CD.

121
00:05:24.900 --> 00:05:27.186
So now, I pop in the CD,
I boot off the installer.

122
00:05:27.186 --> 00:05:29.760
Or USB, let's do it in modern times.

123
00:05:29.760 --> 00:05:32.310
So I can put that right on the USB key.

00:05:32.310 --> 00:05:36.760
I plug in the USB key, I boot it up,
and the install starts and

00:05:36.760 --> 00:05:38.940

126
00:05:38.940 --> 00:05:40.020
It looks for a particular name.

127
00:05:40.020 --> 00:05:45.099
It can be called ks.cfg, right, ks for
kickstart and cfg it's a config file.

128
00:05:45.099 --> 00:05:48.500
[LAUGH] Or you can call it kickstart.cfg.

129
00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:50.300
We normally call it ks.cfg.

130
00:05:50.300 --> 00:05:52.350
So it looks for
it right there on the install media.

131
00:05:52.350 --> 00:05:56.269
And it's got it there great but let me

00:28:32.240 --> 00:28:35.890
>> Well, they definitely need to start
promoting that a little bit more cuz this

579
00:28:35.890 --> 00:28:37.450
is the way to fly ladies and gentlemen.

580
00:28:37.450 --> 00:28:41.040
If you have the means,
I do suggest it, that's for sure.

581
00:28:41.040 --> 00:28:44.310
Because who likes to sit around and
watch installation after installation,

582
00:28:44.310 --> 00:28:48.390
have to answer question after question,
the same time over and over again.

583
00:28:48.390 --> 00:28:51.250
When you have that environment where
you're doing multiple installations,

584
00:28:51.250 --> 00:28:53.810
this is the way that you should be going.

585
00:28:53.810 --> 00:28:58.160
It does take a little setup, but once it's
setup your life becomes so much easier.

586
00:28:58.160 --> 00:29:00.780
Don, we do thank you for
showing us how to use Kickstart and

587
00:29:00.780 --> 00:29:05.850
if you were unaware that it was there,
[LAUGH] then now you are in the know.

588
00:29:05.850 --> 00:29:08.080
That being said, Don, looks like
we're out of time for this episode.

589
00:29:08.080 --> 00:29:09.270
Thanks again for joining us.

590
00:29:09.270 --> 00:29:12.400
We do thank our audience for watching,
but signing off for ITPro TV,

591
00:29:12.400 --> 00:29:13.780
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

592
00:29:13.780 --> 00:29:14.760
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

593
00:29:14.760 --> 00:29:16.567
>> See you next time.

594
00:29:16.567 --> 00:29:22.496
[MUSIC]

595
00:29:22.496 --> 00:29:24.700
>> Thank you for watching IT PRO TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what 'Dual Booting' is, what are the considerations/gotchas involved in setting up and using, virtualization, configuring Dual Boot, and maintenance considerations of a Dual Boot config.
episodes.title: Dual Booting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.718
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.718 --> 00:00:08.315
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.315 --> 00:00:11.943
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.943 --> 00:00:15.240
>> Hello, again, and thank you for
joining us on ITProTV,

5
00:00:15.240 --> 00:00:17.311
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.311 --> 00:00:22.851
I am Zach Memos and I'm your host on
becoming a Linux system administrator and

7
00:00:22.851 --> 00:00:25.006
this is dual-booting time.

8
00:00:25.006 --> 00:00:26.815
And I know some people
are excited about this,

9
00:00:26.815 --> 00:00:30.305
I know I am and bringing us all
the information we need is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:30.305 --> 00:00:31.415
Don, you are so smart.

11
00:00:31.415 --> 00:00:34.025
Please, please,
impart upon us your wisdom.

12
00:00:34.025 --> 00:00:35.770
Please.
>> Well, you definitely got it right.

13
00:00:35.770 --> 00:00:38.260
In this episode, we're doing dual
booting cuz single bootings not enough.

14
00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:40.265
We need the double dose
[CROSSTALK] of booting.

15
00:00:40.265 --> 00:00:44.137
We're going to be taking a look at how
to run more than one operating system

16
00:00:44.137 --> 00:00:45.250
simultaneously.

17
00:00:45.250 --> 00:00:47.053
Well, I shouldn't say simultaneously,

18
00:00:47.053 --> 00:00:50.064
but running more than one operating
system natively on your hardware.

19
00:00:50.064 --> 00:00:50.840
I'm gonna use a laptop.

20
00:00:50.840 --> 00:00:55.192
Same as on a desktop but a neat process if
you're one of those people who can't just

21
00:00:55.192 --> 00:00:57.916
fully dedicate yourself
to one operating system.

22
00:00:57.916 --> 00:01:00.550
And you've got a need to move back and
forth between other ones.

23
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:02.700
We're gonna take a look at that
right here in this episode and

24
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:03.740
see how to get that set up.

25
00:01:03.740 --> 00:01:06.565
>> So that exactly is what dual
booting is, what you just said?

26
00:01:06.565 --> 00:01:09.180
>> Well dual booting,
It's kinda interesting.

27
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:10.380
There's a little more to it, right?

28
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:11.890
First off, we say dual booting,

29
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:15.880
so that could kinda let you know that
we're talking about booting up, right, and

30
00:01:15.880 --> 00:01:18.640
when we boot, you've got this
choice between two different OS's.

31
00:01:18.640 --> 00:01:19.990
But it really shouldn't
be called dual booting,

32
00:01:19.990 --> 00:01:23.290
it should be called multi-boot because
you could have more than two OS's.

33
00:01:23.290 --> 00:01:26.148
Now the more you have,
the more complex it gets,

34
00:01:26.148 --> 00:01:30.287
because a lot of operating systems
don't play nicely well together.

35
00:01:30.287 --> 00:01:32.478
And so when you start getting three and
four and five, all of a sudden,

36
00:01:32.478 --> 00:01:34.060
things kind of flake out a little bit.

37
00:01:34.060 --> 00:01:37.545
But if we just focus on two,
it's pretty easy to get two up and going.

38
00:01:37.545 --> 00:01:42.119
And the idea is that I have two operating
systems installed on my hardware,

39
00:01:42.119 --> 00:01:45.473
and when I push the power button,
It gives me a choice.

40
00:01:45.473 --> 00:01:48.890
And it says do you want to boot
into operating system number one or

41
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:52.264
operating system number two and
it might be Windows and Linux.

42
00:01:52.264 --> 00:01:56.481
It might be Mac OS and Linux, it might be
two different Linux distros, it doesn't

43
00:01:56.481 --> 00:02:00.470
matter it's just two different operating
systems and you make that choice.

44
00:02:00.470 --> 00:02:05.640
Now technically you are only running one
at a time right, you make the choice and

45
00:02:05.640 --> 00:02:08.290
from that time point on you are running
that OS until you reboot and

46
00:02:08.290 --> 00:02:09.740
then you can boot to the other.

47
00:02:09.740 --> 00:02:12.196
So, a lot of you might be thinking,
well wait a minute Don,

48
00:02:12.196 --> 00:02:13.537
I can just do virtual machines.

49
00:02:13.537 --> 00:02:17.758
I can have one OS on my laptop and
then use VMware or Virtual Box or

50
00:02:17.758 --> 00:02:21.501
any other number of products
that are out there to do it,

51
00:02:21.501 --> 00:02:24.463
to create virtual machines with other OSs.

52
00:02:24.463 --> 00:02:27.432
Wait, why would I want to do dual booting?

53
00:02:27.432 --> 00:02:29.184
Well you make a good argument.

54
00:02:29.184 --> 00:02:33.598
Virtual machines are a great solution,
except virtual machines don't

55
00:02:33.598 --> 00:02:37.370
give you true,
what's called bare metal performance.

56
00:02:37.370 --> 00:02:40.235
When you have an OS running
directly on the hardware,

57
00:02:40.235 --> 00:02:43.400
it's able to take advantage of
all of the bells and whistles.

58
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:45.840
All the features all
the power of that hardware,

59
00:02:45.840 --> 00:02:49.920
when joining in a virtual machine It
depends on the virtualization software and

60
00:02:49.920 --> 00:02:53.640
some of it like virtual box is
what's called a type 2 hyperviser.

61
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:56.450
And a lot of the hardware instructions
that you're sending are having to be

62
00:02:56.450 --> 00:02:58.802
translated into real hardware
instructions on the back end of that,

63
00:02:58.802 --> 00:03:00.300
hurts performance.

64
00:03:00.300 --> 00:03:04.690
So if speed is your concern,
performance is your concern.

65
00:03:04.690 --> 00:03:07.350
You'll prefer dual booting
over virtual machines.

66
00:03:07.350 --> 00:03:09.080
But if you just had some software program.

67
00:03:09.080 --> 00:03:12.804
Maybe you have a legacy line of business
application that you run once a month and

68
00:03:12.804 --> 00:03:13.927
you need this other OS.

69
00:03:13.927 --> 00:03:18.160
A virtual machine is a better solution
because it's much easier to set up.

70
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:22.486
It's less invasive and you don't run
the risk of messing up your other OS.

71
00:03:22.486 --> 00:03:25.040
Now, in the real world examples
of where we might use this,

72
00:03:25.040 --> 00:03:26.994
the video gamers use it all the time,
right?

73
00:03:26.994 --> 00:03:27.764
>> Mm-hm.

74
00:03:27.764 --> 00:03:29.637
>> Linux is a great operating system.

75
00:03:29.637 --> 00:03:31.807
It's very powerful, very stable,

76
00:03:31.807 --> 00:03:35.447
but most of the video games that
come out in the Windows world,

77
00:03:35.447 --> 00:03:39.860
and so a lot of Linux gamers will have
a Windows OS that are set to dual boost.

78
00:03:39.860 --> 00:03:42.130
They could boot to Windows and
run their game when they're done,

79
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:43.930
then they boot back over to Linux.

80
00:03:43.930 --> 00:03:47.110
But even in the business
world there's times like for

81
00:03:47.110 --> 00:03:50.040
me where I need to be able
to dual boot into Windows.

82
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:54.092
I have a Windows partition on my laptop
that I boot to because I have a video

83
00:03:54.092 --> 00:03:57.946
capture card at my office that I use for
some of my Skype interviews and

84
00:03:57.946 --> 00:04:01.019
that capture card doesn't
have a driver under Linux.

85
00:04:01.019 --> 00:04:01.919
You know it's very hard

86
00:04:01.919 --> 00:04:04.460
to find specialized hardware
that works under Linux.

87
00:04:04.460 --> 00:04:08.270
And so when I do those interviews,
I boot to Windows, I do the interview.

88
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:10.110
When I'm done, I boot back to Linux.

89
00:04:10.110 --> 00:04:13.870
And so having that little back-up that
I can switch to takes care of that.

90
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:15.730
But I usually use VMs.

91
00:04:15.730 --> 00:04:16.430
And I think at this point,

92
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:20.330
it's probably been over a month since
I booted in to Windows on my laptop

93
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:24.370
because the majority of what I can do
is done right here inside of Linux.

94
00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:28.055
>> So if you do dual boot, a true
dual boot will give you heavy metal,

95
00:04:28.055 --> 00:04:28.928
is that right?

96
00:04:28.928 --> 00:04:31.553
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It gives you that hardcore

97
00:04:31.553 --> 00:04:35.220
performance on your system,
it's what a lot of people seek.

98
00:04:35.220 --> 00:04:38.873
>> Well, are there any considerations or
gotchas for setting this up?

99
00:04:38.873 --> 00:04:41.410
>> Yeah, so
a couple of things to think about.

100
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:44.944
First off, a lot of the people that try
dual boot the first time are doing it

101
00:04:44.944 --> 00:04:46.832
because they're considering Linux.

102
00:04:46.832 --> 00:04:48.740
But they don't know if it's
gonna be right for them.

103
00:04:48.740 --> 00:04:51.350
So they wanna keep their
old OS laying around.

104
00:04:51.350 --> 00:04:52.753
Maybe it's MacOS, maybe it's Windows.

105
00:04:52.753 --> 00:04:56.406
So the first gotcha we need to be aware
of is when you're configuring dual boot,

106
00:04:56.406 --> 00:04:58.541
if you do it wrong ,you
can lose your other OS.

107
00:04:58.541 --> 00:05:02.185
So if I'm trying to keep my old
operating system as a safety net and

108
00:05:02.185 --> 00:05:06.290
just try out Linux, dual boot might
not be the best solution there.

109
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:07.530
You might want to use a live CD.

110
00:05:07.530 --> 00:05:08.250
If you go back and

111
00:05:08.250 --> 00:05:11.690
watch our installing Linux shows I
talk about those a little bit there.

112
00:05:11.690 --> 00:05:14.644
But a lot of the installers like
the Fedora install media you can run

113
00:05:14.644 --> 00:05:15.235
as a live CD.

114
00:05:15.235 --> 00:05:17.189
You can boot off of the USB key.

115
00:05:17.189 --> 00:05:20.358
So it doesn't mess with your hard drive,
with dual booting we have to mess with

116
00:05:20.358 --> 00:05:23.350
the hard drive and there's always risk
when you mess with the hard drive.

117
00:05:23.350 --> 00:05:26.340
So you're gonna need to make
sure you back up all your data

118
00:05:26.340 --> 00:05:30.290
before you configure dual boot or
you run that risk of losing information.

119
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:34.640
The other thing is if you're dual
booting Linux you're fine but

120
00:05:34.640 --> 00:05:37.810
if you're dual booting Windows for
example.

121
00:05:37.810 --> 00:05:40.550
You do still have to
have a Windows license.

122
00:05:40.550 --> 00:05:41.720
So, for example, my laptop,

123
00:05:41.720 --> 00:05:46.010
when I bought my laptop,
it came with Ubuntu Linux pre-installed.

124
00:05:46.010 --> 00:05:49.400
Well, Ubuntu Linux is free, so
you know, anybody can run that.

125
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:52.960
But I said, I'm dual booting Windows and
Windows is not free.

126
00:05:52.960 --> 00:05:57.960
So I have to have a valid Windows
license in order to install that and

127
00:05:57.960 --> 00:05:59.170
get it up and operational.

128
00:05:59.170 --> 00:06:02.314
If you're just dual booting Linux you
don't really worry about the licensing.

129
00:06:02.314 --> 00:06:06.850
Well even Red Hat though is
a commercial licensed operating system.

130
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:09.200
So if you're running Red Hat Linux
you've got to worry about that license.

131
00:06:09.200 --> 00:06:13.900
And they're usually licensed based
on how many installs you have.

132
00:06:13.900 --> 00:06:15.620
Not whether they're running or not.

133
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:18.930
So even though my Windows partition
is not booted up right now

134
00:06:18.930 --> 00:06:21.060
I do still have to have a license for it.

135
00:06:21.060 --> 00:06:23.510
So licensing is another gotcha
that we have to worry about.

136
00:06:23.510 --> 00:06:26.020
And then the last one that I
wanna mention is virtualization.

137
00:06:26.020 --> 00:06:29.831
There's some hardware, like if you watched
my older shows I used to use a Mac book

138
00:06:29.831 --> 00:06:32.198
on the show until I got
frustrated enough with it.

139
00:06:32.198 --> 00:06:36.755
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's reasons why I did that, right?

140
00:06:36.755 --> 00:06:38.634
So a lot of people I use
to get emails all the time.

141
00:06:38.634 --> 00:06:39.739
Don why are you using a Mac book?

142
00:06:39.739 --> 00:06:42.424
It's crazy and
the main reason was because of licensing.

143
00:06:42.424 --> 00:06:47.046
That Apple will not allow you
to virtualize MacOS unless

144
00:06:47.046 --> 00:06:49.608
it's running on top of MacOS.

145
00:06:49.608 --> 00:06:50.474
That was their rule.

146
00:06:50.474 --> 00:06:52.225
It had to be running on their hardware,

147
00:06:52.225 --> 00:06:54.610
with their OS in order
to do virtualization.

148
00:06:54.610 --> 00:06:58.744
So I do virtualization in my shows and
for licensing reasons I had to do that.

149
00:06:58.744 --> 00:07:02.430
But there were problems,
like if I dual booted into Linux or if I

150
00:07:02.430 --> 00:07:07.106
dual booted into Windows for that matter,
it didn't really matter who it was.

151
00:07:07.106 --> 00:07:11.025
There were features like Intel's VTX,
the virtualization technologies

152
00:07:11.025 --> 00:07:15.202
that are built right into the processor,
we need that for a Type 1 Hypervisor.

153
00:07:15.202 --> 00:07:18.920
Well, they would be turned on
when I booted into MAC OS.

154
00:07:18.920 --> 00:07:21.770
And they wouldn't be turned on
when I booted into Windows.

155
00:07:21.770 --> 00:07:24.680
And so if I boot it into Windows
things like hyper v wouldn't work.

156
00:07:24.680 --> 00:07:28.693
If I boot it into Linux things like KVM
wouldn't see it as a type one Hyperviser

157
00:07:28.693 --> 00:07:30.933
and they'd flip in into the type two mode.

158
00:07:30.933 --> 00:07:33.564
Start using QEMU and
I get poorer performance and

159
00:07:33.564 --> 00:07:37.155
you can't go into the BIOS on a Mac
to adjust stuff like that, and so

160
00:07:37.155 --> 00:07:40.695
I would start to lose features and
that was really challenging.

161
00:07:40.695 --> 00:07:43.905
That happens on some
hardware Macs specifically.

162
00:07:43.905 --> 00:07:47.890
But if you've got a standard PC like
the one I've got in front of me.

163
00:07:47.890 --> 00:07:50.469
Then you should be able to
dual boot without issues.

164
00:07:50.469 --> 00:07:52.071
That all of your hardware should function,

165
00:07:52.071 --> 00:07:54.338
all of your features should be
there to be taken advantage of.

166
00:07:54.338 --> 00:07:56.110
But it's something that you'll
want to keep an eye on,

167
00:07:56.110 --> 00:07:57.551
you'll want to watch out for
those options.

168
00:07:57.551 --> 00:08:02.052
>> So I'm excited to see this happen, so
can we configure it and see what happens?

169
00:08:02.052 --> 00:08:03.320
Or how to configure it?

170
00:08:03.320 --> 00:08:04.370
>> Absolutely.

171
00:08:04.370 --> 00:08:06.960
So I'm going to do this
inside of a virtual machine.

172
00:08:06.960 --> 00:08:08.880
And normally,
I'd want to show you on bare metal.

173
00:08:08.880 --> 00:08:10.000
Well, I mean, I've got my laptop.

174
00:08:10.000 --> 00:08:12.360
My laptop actually is set
to dual-boot right now, but

175
00:08:12.360 --> 00:08:13.320
I'm gonna use a virtual machine.

176
00:08:13.320 --> 00:08:15.530
And the main reason is,
we're gonna have to reboot a few times.

177
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:18.220
And when I do that, the only way I
can show you guys what's going on,

178
00:08:18.220 --> 00:08:19.540
on the screen, is if I'm virtualized.

179
00:08:19.540 --> 00:08:21.410
So I'm running this in a VM.

180
00:08:21.410 --> 00:08:23.800
And I've got a Windows virtual
machine fired up here.

181
00:08:23.800 --> 00:08:25.066
So this is running Windows 10.

182
00:08:25.066 --> 00:08:31.080
Now, if you're dual-booting, we need
to be considerate over which operating

183
00:08:31.080 --> 00:08:34.840
system is installed first, and which
operating system is installed second.

184
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:39.540
Because to do dual-boot, step one, is you
need to get one operating system up and

185
00:08:39.540 --> 00:08:41.330
running, your choice.

186
00:08:41.330 --> 00:08:44.330
Well, it's not entirely your choice.

187
00:08:44.330 --> 00:08:46.340
If you're gonna be
dual-booting with Windows,

188
00:08:46.340 --> 00:08:49.045
it's really important that
you install Windows first.

189
00:08:50.185 --> 00:08:53.845
And not because Windows is better or
we like Windows or whatever, but

190
00:08:53.845 --> 00:08:57.320
because Windows hates everything else.

191
00:08:57.320 --> 00:08:58.445
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

192
00:08:58.445 --> 00:09:02.932
if you install Windows second, guess what
it's gonna do to the Linux Boot Loader?

193
00:09:02.932 --> 00:09:04.282
It's gonna wipe it out, right?

194
00:09:04.282 --> 00:09:06.012
That's what it does,
Windows hates everything.

195
00:09:06.012 --> 00:09:07.852
So when you install,

196
00:09:07.852 --> 00:09:11.122
you need to install your least
friendly operating system first.

197
00:09:11.122 --> 00:09:13.402
If you're on a Mac,
you need to install Mac OS first.

198
00:09:13.402 --> 00:09:14.712
If you're on a Windows machine or

199
00:09:14.712 --> 00:09:18.140
a PC or you're just dual-booting Windows,
you need to install Windows first.

200
00:09:18.140 --> 00:09:21.784
All right, if you're installing Linux,
multiple versions of Linux, right?

201
00:09:21.784 --> 00:09:24.478
We had,
I think it was Ryan in the chat-room,

202
00:09:24.478 --> 00:09:27.790
who was doing Red Hat Enterprise Linux and
Ubuntu.

203
00:09:27.790 --> 00:09:29.710
Okay well that's two Linux distros right?

204
00:09:29.710 --> 00:09:31.980
>> Right.
>> But we need to be careful there,

205
00:09:31.980 --> 00:09:35.960
because there are multiple boot
loaders supported by Linux distros

206
00:09:35.960 --> 00:09:36.870
that are out there.
