00:26:22.270 --> 00:26:24.830
now I'm looking at the actual
packages in there.

492
00:26:24.830 --> 00:26:25.480
>> That's fantastic.

493
00:26:25.480 --> 00:26:28.000
>> And you can browse through and find,
you can search through and stuff.

494
00:26:28.000 --> 00:26:30.670
You see all the commands up
here at the top of the screen.

495
00:26:30.670 --> 00:26:33.680
So we can search and
other things to find what we want.

496
00:26:33.680 --> 00:26:36.930
It's a neat little utility that
just gives you that ability to

497
00:26:36.930 --> 00:26:40.010
quickly find what you're looking for and
kind of browse around and experiment.

498
00:26:40.010 --> 00:26:42.210
You've got your graphical stuff too,

499
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:45.880
if you're on the server you don't have the
graphical stuff, but on a work station,

500
00:26:45.880 --> 00:26:50.300
you can always go into the software
utility, this Ubuntu software.

501
00:26:50.300 --> 00:26:53.030
But you'll find that some software
doesn't show up in here and

502
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:55.510
I have mixed results
actually installing things.

503
00:26:55.510 --> 00:26:56.966
If you're looking for server services,

504
00:26:56.966 --> 00:26:59.100
they don't show up here like if
I wanna set up a web server.

505
00:26:59.100 --> 00:27:00.350
I can't do that from here.

506
00:27:00.350 --> 00:27:04.446
So the apt utility from the command
line is really superior to that.

507
00:27:04.446 --> 00:27:07.610
And I've been using apt pretty plainly.

508
00:27:07.610 --> 00:27:10.540
I used apt get install and
apt get removed.

509
00:27:10.540 --> 00:27:14.740
But there are a lot of other
command line tags that you can use,

510
00:27:14.740 --> 00:27:16.340
like list and search.

511
00:27:16.340 --> 00:27:19.420
So I can search for
those packages right from the apt utility.

512
00:27:19.420 --> 00:27:23.540
Install and remove I use,
autoremove is a neat one.

513
00:27:23.540 --> 00:27:26.820
There are times, in fact,
I think I had a warning about it,

514
00:27:26.820 --> 00:27:30.240
where you can end up with some packages
left over that you don't need anymore.

515
00:27:30.240 --> 00:27:35.161
So when I ran the apt -get update command,
I think I saw a complaint earlier.

516
00:27:35.161 --> 00:27:36.650
Let's see if it comes up here.

517
00:27:36.650 --> 00:27:39.294
That said I had some packages
I didn't need anymore.

518
00:27:39.294 --> 00:27:40.584
No, I guess not.

519
00:27:40.584 --> 00:27:45.000
You know what?
It was when I went to install Aptitude.

520
00:27:45.000 --> 00:27:49.050
So if I install aptitude again and
see, there we go.

521
00:27:49.050 --> 00:27:52.580
See how it says this, the following
packages were automatically installed and

522
00:27:52.580 --> 00:27:53.840
are no longer required.

523
00:27:53.840 --> 00:27:57.820
I ended up with a few extras and
it's apt show versions and

524
00:27:57.820 --> 00:28:00.050
lib authentication pam perl.

525
00:28:00.050 --> 00:28:02.350
It was supposed to remove
those when we removed Webmin.

526
00:28:02.350 --> 00:28:05.440
But something happened, and it didn't
actually remove them for some reason.

527
00:28:05.440 --> 00:28:13.060
But we can come in and we can say,
sudo apt get autoremove, like that.

528
00:28:13.060 --> 00:28:15.730
And it'll remove those
packages that we don't need.

529
00:28:15.730 --> 00:28:19.850
And notice here how they're telling me
to run sudo apt instead of apt -get.

530
00:28:19.850 --> 00:28:21.835
Because that's that alias that's in place.

531
00:28:21.835 --> 00:28:23.119
And that makes a little more sense for

532
00:28:23.119 --> 00:28:25.370
people cuz I'm not getting
something when I'm autoremoving.

533
00:28:25.370 --> 00:28:28.459
So, but it's the same thing,
I'm running apt -get autoremove here.

534
00:28:28.459 --> 00:28:31.409
And it'll remove those packages and
get them out of there so

535
00:28:31.409 --> 00:28:34.831
that they're not taking up space on
my system or increasing my attack

536
00:28:34.831 --> 00:28:38.315
surface by having software I don't
need and kinda clearing that out.

537
00:28:38.315 --> 00:28:43.043
Some of the other things you can do when
you do an install, you can do a /d and

538
00:28:43.043 --> 00:28:47.641
it'll tell it to just download
the package but not actually install it.

539
00:28:47.641 --> 00:28:50.368
That's useful if you want to
do something offline later,

540
00:28:50.368 --> 00:28:54.135
you can download a bunch of packages now
and install them at your leisure later.

541
00:28:54.135 --> 00:28:57.643
-f can be used to try and
fix a broken package.

542
00:28:57.643 --> 00:29:00.499
So maybe I installed a package and
I did something and messed it up,

543
00:29:00.499 --> 00:29:02.310
maybe I deleted a file by accident.

544
00:29:02.310 --> 00:29:05.640
So I could do the install command and
if I do install for

545
00:29:05.640 --> 00:29:08.110
a package that's already installed,
it usually just ignores it, but

546
00:29:08.110 --> 00:29:11.046
if you do a -f,
it's like telling it to reinstall, right?

547
00:29:11.046 --> 00:29:15.224
-f or a --fix is the other alias for
that one or,

548
00:29:15.224 --> 00:29:19.014
I'm sorry, --fix -broken is what it is.

549
00:29:19.014 --> 00:29:20.680
So those are couple of other ones.

550
00:29:20.680 --> 00:29:23.780
You can do a -y to make it just
automatically say yes to anything that

551
00:29:23.780 --> 00:29:24.490
it's about to do.

552
00:29:24.490 --> 00:29:28.620
That's nice if you tried to schedule this
to run with a Cron job or something.

553
00:29:28.620 --> 00:29:33.324
But for the most part,
apt get update, apt get upgrade,

554
00:29:33.324 --> 00:29:38.100
apt get distgrade,
right those the three main ones.

555
00:29:38.100 --> 00:29:40.410
And then,
app get install followed by package name.

556
00:29:40.410 --> 00:29:42.550
Apt get removed followed by package name.

557
00:29:42.550 --> 00:29:43.878
Those are really the key.

558
00:29:43.878 --> 00:29:45.880
If you can remember all
those five commands,

559
00:29:45.880 --> 00:29:48.020
those are the key critical engine need for
apt.

560
00:29:48.020 --> 00:29:51.650
The other stuff like Aptitude and
fixing broken stuff,

561
00:29:51.650 --> 00:29:55.060
those are far less common so you can
just look those up when you need them.

562
00:29:55.060 --> 00:29:57.880
But the key five commands, those are what
you're gonna need to keep your system

563
00:29:57.880 --> 00:30:01.050
up to date, healthy and
keep your software installed and running.

564
00:30:01.050 --> 00:30:01.870
>> Fantastic, Don.

565
00:30:01.870 --> 00:30:03.770
Becoming a Linux system administrator,

566
00:30:03.770 --> 00:30:06.559
managing software with Apt,
anything else you wanna leave us with?

567
00:30:07.680 --> 00:30:09.343
Last words?
>> That's pretty much it,

568
00:30:09.343 --> 00:30:13.180
do be aware that there's plenty of other
utilities out there that work with Apt.

569
00:30:13.180 --> 00:30:15.255
They have an open API so
there's a lot of other systems,

570
00:30:15.255 --> 00:30:17.030
don't hesitate to use
the other software too.

571
00:30:17.030 --> 00:30:20.700
But Apt is a really great
infrastructure for managing packages.

572
00:30:20.700 --> 00:30:25.010
There is another technology coming
down the line called Flat Pack that is

573
00:30:25.010 --> 00:30:30.310
supposedly going to replace Apt, but that
is not gonna happen for years and years.

574
00:30:30.310 --> 00:30:31.910
That's gonna be a ways down the wet line.

575
00:30:31.910 --> 00:30:34.472
So for right now,
Apt is your go-to utility for

576
00:30:34.472 --> 00:30:36.211
updating to be in base systems.

577
00:30:36.211 --> 00:30:38.250
>> Fantastic, great job as usual.

578
00:30:38.250 --> 00:30:41.345
And again,
becoming a Linux system administrator,

579
00:30:41.345 --> 00:30:43.829
there's a lot of content in this library.

580
00:30:43.829 --> 00:30:45.088
A lot of videos to check out.

581
00:30:45.088 --> 00:30:47.520
Please check them all out,
you'll be glad you did.

582
00:30:47.520 --> 00:30:49.612
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

583
00:30:49.612 --> 00:30:51.880
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

584
00:30:51.880 --> 00:30:53.070
I'm Zach Memos.

585
00:30:53.070 --> 00:30:53.880
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

586
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:56.195
>> And we will see you soon.

587
00:30:56.195 --> 00:31:02.184
[MUSIC]

588
00:31:02.184 --> 00:31:05.417
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss the utilities of YUM & DNF, history of them, differences between the two, how to use the utilities, where we can acquire software from, using 'Checksum, using the 'Repository,' installing software, and importing the "Signing Key."
episodes.title: Managing Software with YUM/DNF
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.454
Welcome to IT pro TV.

2
00:00:01.454 --> 00:00:02.535
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.535 --> 00:00:04.727
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.727 --> 00:00:08.050
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.050 --> 00:00:11.687
>> You're watching IT pro TV.

6
00:00:11.687 --> 00:00:13.019
>> Hello and thank you for

7
00:00:13.019 --> 00:00:17.028
joining us again on ITproTV where
we help you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:17.028 --> 00:00:20.715
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with becoming a Linux

9
00:00:20.715 --> 00:00:23.808
system administrator and
very cool topic right here.

10
00:00:23.808 --> 00:00:28.891
We're gonna be doing managing
software with YUM and DNF.

11
00:00:28.891 --> 00:00:32.413
And providing all the information
we need is our very own, Don Pezet.

12
00:00:32.413 --> 00:00:33.593
Hey, Don, good to see you, sir.

13
00:00:33.593 --> 00:00:34.924
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Zach.

14
00:00:34.924 --> 00:00:38.236
Yeah, ready to dive into the world of the
YUM and DNF, which are two utilities that,

15
00:00:38.236 --> 00:00:40.350
I'll tell you I have spent
a lot of time working with.

16
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:45.051
And if you use any of the RedHat, Centas,
or Fedora variances of Linux that

17
00:00:45.051 --> 00:00:48.493
are out there you're gonna
encounter these guys too.

18
00:00:48.493 --> 00:00:49.800
So very important utilities,

19
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:52.915
they're the ones we're gonna use when
it comes to installing software,

20
00:00:52.915 --> 00:00:56.297
uninstalling, removing software,
maintaining and updating, upgrading.

21
00:00:56.297 --> 00:00:59.661
Obviously very critical features here
to keep our system up and going so

22
00:00:59.661 --> 00:01:02.702
that's what we're taking a look
at right here in this episode.

23
00:01:02.702 --> 00:01:05.430
>> So Don,
why are learning about two utilities?

24
00:01:05.430 --> 00:01:07.096
Why not just one?

25
00:01:07.096 --> 00:01:09.504
>> We've got some kind
of identity complex.

26
00:01:09.504 --> 00:01:10.191
>> That's it.

27
00:01:10.191 --> 00:01:13.626
>> [LAUGH] All right, so
we're learning about two because out there

28
00:01:13.626 --> 00:01:16.680
in the real world you still see both,
right?

29
00:01:16.680 --> 00:01:19.133
YUM is the older utility,
DNF is the new one.

30
00:01:19.133 --> 00:01:20.882
There's actually a third
utility called RPM, right?

31
00:01:20.882 --> 00:01:23.419
This all started back in the day,
>> RPM by the way.

32
00:01:23.419 --> 00:01:26.725
>> In the early Red Hat days, we had RPM,
the Red Hat Package Manager, and

33
00:01:26.725 --> 00:01:29.999
it would allow you to install packages,
you could install a program.

34
00:01:29.999 --> 00:01:35.320
The problem with RPM is it didn't
do any dependency checking at all.

35
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:39.744
So if I was installing the Google Chrome
web browser via an RPM, and

36
00:01:39.744 --> 00:01:45.038
it depended on GLib C or a bunch of other
libraries, RPM didn't check for that.

37
00:01:45.038 --> 00:01:48.991
And so I might be able to install
Chrome but not actually run it and so

38
00:01:48.991 --> 00:01:50.269
things were broken.

39
00:01:50.269 --> 00:01:53.550
So YUM was actually
part of a side project.

40
00:01:53.550 --> 00:01:56.592
There was a project called
Yellow Dog Linux and

41
00:01:56.592 --> 00:02:01.831
Yellow Dog Linux was a version of Red Hat
that would run on a Mac or run on PowerPC.

42
00:02:01.831 --> 00:02:03.643
We don't see Power PC machines anymore,

43
00:02:03.643 --> 00:02:06.241
so Yellow Dog is not nearly as
prevalent as it was back then.

44
00:02:06.241 --> 00:02:08.931
But they created
the Yellow Dog Update Manager.

45
00:02:08.931 --> 00:02:11.366
And what it did was it would
allow you to install package and

46
00:02:11.366 --> 00:02:13.712
it could look at the dependencies
that package needed.

47
00:02:13.712 --> 00:02:17.324
It would say hey, if I installed Chrome,
it also needs Open SSL to be able to do

48
00:02:17.324 --> 00:02:19.560
encryption, it needs
all these other things.

49
00:02:19.560 --> 00:02:22.762
So it will install them at the same time
and it did a pretty decent job at this.

50
00:02:22.762 --> 00:02:27.944
>> But wouldn't it be get guidem, widem,
get yellow dog, it would wouldn't it?

51
00:02:27.944 --> 00:02:28.982
>> Yellow Dog Update Manager.

52
00:02:28.982 --> 00:02:30.072
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, they just kinda truncate it,

53
00:02:30.072 --> 00:02:30.817
I guess yum sounds nicer.

54
00:02:30.817 --> 00:02:32.444
>> Yeah, it does sound better.

55
00:02:32.444 --> 00:02:33.350
>> It is sad but

56
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:38.539
how it sounds is kind of what these
guys use to pick names sometimes.

57
00:02:38.539 --> 00:02:39.092
>> Yum, yum, yum.

58
00:02:39.092 --> 00:02:41.365
>> And so, that's what YUM did.

59
00:02:41.365 --> 00:02:45.388
The thing about YUM though, is that
it's old, it's been around a long time.

60
00:02:45.388 --> 00:02:48.262
Like PowerPC processors,
when's the last time you saw one of those?

61
00:02:48.262 --> 00:02:51.360
In a laptop, for example,
they're not common.

62
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:54.289
So, that technology hasn't
aged all that well.

63
00:02:54.289 --> 00:02:57.627
The database that it uses for
tracking dependencies has some problems,

64
00:02:57.627 --> 00:02:58.890
it's not always perfect.

65
00:02:58.890 --> 00:03:03.115
And it frequently leaves files behind
which is a problem in and of itself.

66
00:03:03.115 --> 00:03:05.322
So there's a new guy in town, right?

67
00:03:05.322 --> 00:03:08.208
To take the place of YUM, and that is DNF.

68
00:03:08.208 --> 00:03:12.242
Now, DNF stands for,
it's not what you think?

69
00:03:12.242 --> 00:03:16.568
DNF stands for Dandified YUM and,
yeah, it's dumb.

70
00:03:16.568 --> 00:03:20.164
>> [LAUGH]
>> So basically, what that is,

71
00:03:20.164 --> 00:03:25.414
is a complete rewrite of YUM from scratch,
with an all new database,

72
00:03:25.414 --> 00:03:28.960
that does far superior
dependency tracking.

73
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:33.072
It's able to come in, and say, we're gonna
keep track of these dependencies better

74
00:03:33.072 --> 00:03:35.710
and make sure we have good
logic being applied to each.

75
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:40.377
And we'll have a fully documented API
that programmers can interface with to

76
00:03:40.377 --> 00:03:43.839
be able to call DNF,
to be able to perform these actions.

77
00:03:43.839 --> 00:03:47.115
So, DNF syntactically is
almost identical to YUM,

78
00:03:47.115 --> 00:03:50.420
the commands that we run
are almost identical.

79
00:03:50.420 --> 00:03:53.365
So, for most users, we won't notice
the difference between YUM and DNF,

80
00:03:53.365 --> 00:03:54.880
they're interchangeable, right?

81
00:03:54.880 --> 00:03:56.941
So, what do we care which one we use.

82
00:03:56.941 --> 00:04:00.133
But, from the developers side,
from the OS side,

83
00:04:00.133 --> 00:04:02.818
from the support side DNF is far superior.

84
00:04:02.818 --> 00:04:07.241
And so, that's the new guy in town and
that's the one everybody's gonna move to.

85
00:04:07.241 --> 00:04:13.908
Right now, Fedora uses DNF by default, Red
Hat and CentOS do not, they still use YUM.

86
00:04:13.908 --> 00:04:17.261
Fortunately, from the command-line,
it's almost the same, right?

87
00:04:17.261 --> 00:04:19.087
So we don't have to learn
anything different.

88
00:04:19.087 --> 00:04:22.910
But as soon as you're on an OS that
supports DNF, you want to use it.

89
00:04:22.910 --> 00:04:24.496
It's the superior of the two but

90
00:04:24.496 --> 00:04:28.562
that's why their show is covering both
because you still both that are out there.

91
00:04:28.562 --> 00:04:33.550
>> So okay, we use YUM or
DNF to grab software, right?

92
00:04:33.550 --> 00:04:35.082
>> Right.
>> But where is this software coming from?

93
00:04:35.082 --> 00:04:37.890
>> Okay, so the software is
coming from a repository, and

94
00:04:37.890 --> 00:04:42.010
that is the neat part about DNF and
YUM is that the repositories don't change.

95
00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:44.388
You have all these packages
that are stored on a server or

96
00:04:44.388 --> 00:04:46.370
somewhere out there on the Internet,
right?

97
00:04:46.370 --> 00:04:49.253
And, or you could even have
an internal repository if you want.

98
00:04:49.253 --> 00:04:51.852
And you reach out and
you get that software.

99
00:04:51.852 --> 00:04:56.835
Now when you install Red Hat or CentOS or
Fedora, they have certain repositories

100
00:04:56.835 --> 00:05:01.460
defined by default that they looked to and
then when we can add more on to it.

101
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:04.595
So for example my laptop,
I'm running Fedora and

102
00:05:04.595 --> 00:05:07.589
I've already got some repos defined,
right?

103
00:05:07.589 --> 00:05:10.874
A repo is short for a repository,
server that holds files.

104
00:05:10.874 --> 00:05:18.115
And if you go into /etc/yum.repos.d,
all right?

105
00:05:18.115 --> 00:05:18.884
That's a folder.
And

106
00:05:18.884 --> 00:05:24.727
in that folder will be a file defined for
each repository that you support.

107
00:05:24.727 --> 00:05:30.580
Now I've got a bunch in here that you may
not have or that you probably don't have.

108
00:05:30.580 --> 00:05:33.401
In fact,
if you do a clean install of Fedora,

109
00:05:33.401 --> 00:05:36.539
you'll likely just have
these first four right?

110
00:05:36.539 --> 00:05:42.430
Fedora, Cisco Open H264, fedora.repo,
Fedora Updates and Fedora Updates Testing.

111
00:05:42.430 --> 00:05:47.965
Okay, each of these are different
repositories that contain software, right?

112
00:05:47.965 --> 00:05:53.398
The main one, fedora.repo, that one has a
lot of software in it that is open source,

113
00:05:53.398 --> 00:05:57.547
that is fully supported by the Fedora
team that you can install and

114
00:05:57.547 --> 00:05:59.521
it's free of charge, right?

115
00:05:59.521 --> 00:06:02.929
So that's where the bulk of our
software's going to come from.

116
00:06:02.929 --> 00:06:06.320
And if I look inside of that file,
fedora.repo,

117
00:06:06.320 --> 00:06:09.647
you'll see that there's
not that much in here.

118
00:06:09.647 --> 00:06:15.348
It's kinda broken up into these sections,
so here's the main repo called Fedora and

119
00:06:15.348 --> 00:06:19.402
it's pointing to a URL,
download.fedoraproject.org.

120
00:06:19.402 --> 00:06:23.304
And on their site there's a subfolder and
you can browse in and you can find all

121
00:06:23.304 --> 00:06:27.701
the packages that are available for your
system, and so that's where it's looking.

122
00:06:27.701 --> 00:06:29.600
But notice there's more
than one repo in here.

123
00:06:29.600 --> 00:06:33.910
Technically this first entry,

00:18:27.790 --> 00:18:31.180
dnf list is only searching
the package name.

350
00:18:31.180 --> 00:18:35.490
There's another option which is dnf search
and you have to be careful with this one.

351
00:18:35.490 --> 00:18:38.720
Cuz it's searching for
keywords instead of package names.

352
00:18:38.720 --> 00:18:42.230
So it will look in this
description as well

353
00:18:42.230 --> 00:18:45.740
because sometimes the program may
have some wierd crazy name, right?

354
00:18:46.790 --> 00:18:49.280
I might be looking for
a text editor, right?

355
00:18:49.280 --> 00:18:51.590
Well, the text editor I'm looking for
might be called nano,

356
00:18:51.590 --> 00:18:55.000
but if I don't know that it's called nano,
list isn't gonna help me.

357
00:18:55.000 --> 00:19:00.230
If I do a dnf list text, right, it's gonna

358
00:19:00.230 --> 00:19:03.480
show me any package that has text in the
name, which apparently there isn't one.

359
00:19:03.480 --> 00:19:04.634
Seems odd.
>> [LAUGH]

360
00:19:04.634 --> 00:19:06.740
>> And you can use wild cards also.

361
00:19:06.740 --> 00:19:10.182
So if I do text*, it would be
anything that starts with text.

362
00:19:10.182 --> 00:19:14.568
Or *text*, it would be anything that
has text anywhere inside of it.

363
00:19:14.568 --> 00:19:18.002
So there's textcat and
now if I go a little further, there we go.

364
00:19:18.002 --> 00:19:22.860
You get textmerg, texttopo,
just a bunch of different ones here.

365
00:19:22.860 --> 00:19:24.825
So it's just searching those names.

366
00:19:24.825 --> 00:19:28.586
But if I were to do dnf search text,
right,

367
00:19:28.586 --> 00:19:34.705
now I get a lot of stuff, right,
a lot of things coming back here.

368
00:19:34.705 --> 00:19:39.090
That's usually the better option if you
have no idea what something is called but

369
00:19:39.090 --> 00:19:41.890
boy does it get a lot of information back.

370
00:19:41.890 --> 00:19:43.747
And some of these packages
can be really confusing and

371
00:19:43.747 --> 00:19:45.340
you just have no idea what they are.

372
00:19:45.340 --> 00:19:49.118
And so I usually end up using
a combination of these, right?

373
00:19:49.118 --> 00:19:52.610
dnf list, if I have a clue as
to what the package name is.

374
00:19:52.610 --> 00:19:55.620
dnf search if I don't have
a clue what the package name is.

375
00:19:55.620 --> 00:19:58.820
And then dnf info to get more information.

376
00:19:58.820 --> 00:20:01.432
Now with all of these, I keep saying dnf.

377
00:20:01.432 --> 00:20:04.680
You can sub out dnf for Yum and
that'll work on all of these.

378
00:20:04.680 --> 00:20:09.410
So in Yum you have Yum List,
Yum Search, and Yum Info.

379
00:20:09.410 --> 00:20:13.380
In fact, even though I'm on a dnf system,
if I run yum list here,

380
00:20:13.380 --> 00:20:15.850
if I do yum list webmin,
watch what happens.

381
00:20:15.850 --> 00:20:19.290
It says, redirecting to /usr/bin/dnf.

382
00:20:19.290 --> 00:20:22.260
So it just converted it right over,
and I'm using.

383
00:20:22.260 --> 00:20:24.960
So you can still use the yum
commands even on a dnf system,

384
00:20:24.960 --> 00:20:29.120
and you'll get the same results as
if I had done a dnf list webmin.

385
00:20:29.120 --> 00:20:31.410
It pulls that same information.

386
00:20:31.410 --> 00:20:35.090
So these are really
compatible syntax wise.

387
00:20:35.090 --> 00:20:37.750
They're not compatible as far
as the utilities themselves, but

388
00:20:37.750 --> 00:20:42.390
the syntax we use to interact with them
is practically identical between the two.

389
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:45.464
So here I can find the package
that I'm looking for and

390
00:20:45.464 --> 00:20:48.623
now I can get ready to actually
work with that package.

391
00:20:48.623 --> 00:20:51.066
>> So having found the right package,
how do we install it?

392
00:20:51.066 --> 00:20:52.867
>> All right, and
that's typically pretty easy.

393
00:20:52.867 --> 00:20:54.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> Unless things get screwed up.

394
00:20:54.940 --> 00:20:59.696
So I can just come in and say something
like sudo dnf install webmin, right?

395
00:20:59.696 --> 00:21:02.208
And that install is saying,
I wanna install it.

396
00:21:02.208 --> 00:21:03.220
So I'm gonna run that.

397
00:21:03.220 --> 00:21:04.140
And it's gonna do the install.

398
00:21:04.140 --> 00:21:06.750
Now the first thing it's going to do
is it's going to look for dependencies.

399
00:21:06.750 --> 00:21:08.030
Are there dependencies that I'm missing?

400
00:21:08.030 --> 00:21:09.140
And it turns out that I am.

401
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:12.025
I'm missing perl-encode-detect.

402
00:21:12.025 --> 00:21:14.835
Now I don't know,
Perl is a programming language.

403
00:21:14.835 --> 00:21:16.145
I don't know it.

404
00:21:16.145 --> 00:21:18.525
I don't know what Perl and
Code Detect does, right, but

405
00:21:18.525 --> 00:21:21.355
apparently web min needs it and
dnf was able to figure that out.

406
00:21:21.355 --> 00:21:22.045
And so it says hey,

407
00:21:22.045 --> 00:21:26.155
you need this piece, we're gonna install
it alongside webmin and get it in there.

408
00:21:26.155 --> 00:21:29.905
Sometimes you'll have just one entry
like that, and it's not a big deal.

409
00:21:29.905 --> 00:21:33.790
Other times you might be installing one
program and it has 100 dependencies.

410
00:21:33.790 --> 00:21:36.340
Right, that is a fairly common thing.

411
00:21:36.340 --> 00:21:39.755
And so now it's gotta load all these
other packages and keep track of that.

412
00:21:39.755 --> 00:21:42.950
And that's what Yum was struggling
with and dnf kinda fixes.

413
00:21:42.950 --> 00:21:47.250
And so when I say yes to this, it's gonna
go in and install and there it goes.

414
00:21:47.250 --> 00:21:50.470
Now this one's coming from
a third party repository.

415
00:21:50.470 --> 00:21:54.130
I know that because when I look at the
repository over here, the dependency came

416
00:21:54.130 --> 00:21:58.560
from Fedora but webmin itself came from
the webmin repository and that's okay.

417
00:21:58.560 --> 00:21:59.390
They work together.

418
00:21:59.390 --> 00:22:01.160
Dnf keeps track of all that.

419
00:22:01.160 --> 00:22:02.780
If I were installing something native,

420
00:22:02.780 --> 00:22:05.330
like if I wanted to install Cockpit,
right?

421
00:22:05.330 --> 00:22:08.840
Webmin, if you never heard of Webmin, it's
a web-based administration utility that

422
00:22:08.840 --> 00:22:12.690
let's you kind of have a, almost like
a GUI for managing your servers.

423
00:22:12.690 --> 00:22:15.240
Cockpit does the same thing,
it's just another alternative.

424
00:22:15.240 --> 00:22:19.719
So I could come in and
I could say, dnf list cockpit *.

425
00:22:19.719 --> 00:22:22.628
And I'm looking for any of the cockpit
packages that are out there, and

426
00:22:22.628 --> 00:22:23.460
I see it here.

427
00:22:23.460 --> 00:22:25.390
It's just called plain old cockpit.

428
00:22:25.390 --> 00:22:28.850
If you look, there's all these other
cockpit packages that are available.

429
00:22:28.850 --> 00:22:32.250
A lot of these are dependencies
that are built upon Cockpit itself.

430
00:22:32.250 --> 00:22:34.870
So I'm gonna say, dnf install cockpit.

431
00:22:36.460 --> 00:22:39.958
And when I go to install that, it says,
[LAUGH] I've already got it installed.

432
00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:43.540
[LAUGH] I've already got it installed,

433
00:22:43.540 --> 00:22:46.070
so no point in installing it
again if it's already there.

434
00:22:46.070 --> 00:22:47.660
And so that's gonna keep track of that.

435
00:22:47.660 --> 00:22:53.290
So now they're installed,
and usually up and going.

436
00:22:53.290 --> 00:22:56.310
If this was an end-user application,
then now I could go and

437
00:22:56.310 --> 00:22:57.560
I could run that application.

438
00:22:57.560 --> 00:23:03.380
So for example, if I wanted Vim installed,
I might already have it, or I could just

439
00:23:03.380 --> 00:23:07.520
run sudo dnf install vim, and now when
I run vim, it'll launch and that's it.

440
00:23:07.520 --> 00:23:10.705
If it's a service, though, you might
actually need to turn the service on.

441
00:23:10.705 --> 00:23:14.586
So some of that stuff is actually
controlled by system CTL.

442
00:23:14.586 --> 00:23:18.420
And you might need to pull the status
of webmin and take a look at it.

443
00:23:18.420 --> 00:23:20.290
And I've got,
webmin that service cannot be found.

444
00:23:20.290 --> 00:23:23.330
So apparently it's not enabled yet.

445
00:23:23.330 --> 00:23:28.810
And so I might need to come in and do
something like system CTL enable Webmin.

446
00:23:28.810 --> 00:23:31.350
And that's going to
configure it as a service.

447
00:23:31.350 --> 00:23:33.640
And then I can come in and
take a look at its status,

448
00:23:33.640 --> 00:23:36.260
which is that it's not running,
and I can start it.

449
00:23:36.260 --> 00:23:39.400
So if it's a service,
I'll probably need to start it.

450
00:23:39.400 --> 00:23:43.850
But if it is a application,
it's installed, and it's just ready for

451
00:23:43.850 --> 00:23:45.270
me to run and go.

452
00:23:45.270 --> 00:23:49.210
Now Webmin is gonna crash on me
because I've got SELinux turned on and

453
00:23:49.210 --> 00:23:50.550
it's blocking its access.

454
00:23:50.550 --> 00:23:53.900
So I'd need to go in and allow it through
SELinux and all that other stuff.

455
00:23:53.900 --> 00:23:57.960
A lot of applications have more that
you need to do, but other applications,

456
00:23:57.960 --> 00:23:59.640
they just install.

457
00:23:59.640 --> 00:24:01.909
And you're done.
You're able to fire them up and run them.

458
00:24:01.909 --> 00:24:05.542
So, for example,
if I wanted the VLC video viewer, right.

459
00:24:05.542 --> 00:24:08.700
I could say dnf list vlc*.

460
00:24:08.700 --> 00:24:10.488
And I could look, there it is, right?

461
00:24:10.488 --> 00:24:17.175
And I can say sudo dnf install vlc,
and we'll do it.

462
00:24:17.175 --> 00:24:18.925
Notice there's two packages
up there called vlc, but

463
00:24:18.925 --> 00:24:21.106
it's the different architectures,
so it will pick the right one.

464
00:24:21.106 --> 00:24:22.918
And this one has quite a few dependencies.

465
00:24:22.918 --> 00:24:24.147
Look at all those.

466
00:24:24.147 --> 00:24:27.620
So I'm trying to install one program but
it's gotta install 48 packages.

467
00:24:27.620 --> 00:24:28.850
I'll say yes to that.

468
00:24:28.850 --> 00:24:30.790
And now it's gonna get in there and
it's gonna install them,

469
00:24:30.790 --> 00:24:33.210
all 48 of these, right?

470
00:24:33.210 --> 00:24:36.870
And the cool part here is
anytime I do an update,

471
00:24:36.870 --> 00:24:42.490
the update will grab all of these other
packages that need to be updated as well.

472
00:24:42.490 --> 00:24:45.012
And it'll we'll keep it up to date and I
don't have to worry about reaching out to

473
00:24:45.012 --> 00:24:47.330
all of these different vendor websites and
employing that information.

474
00:24:47.330 --> 00:24:50.530
So now that it's done,
VLC is not a service in the background.

475
00:24:50.530 --> 00:24:55.490
So, if I just go up to my activities
menu here and type VLC, there it is.

476
00:24:55.490 --> 00:24:59.510
And I can launch VLC and looks like I
have to give it some network access.

477
00:24:59.510 --> 00:25:00.670
And now I'm ready to place some videos,
right?

478
00:25:00.670 --> 00:25:02.329
So it's really easy to get that installed.

479
00:25:02.329 --> 00:25:05.611
>> [LAUGH]
>> And if an update is out,

480
00:25:05.611 --> 00:25:09.480
I just come in here and say dnf update.

481
00:25:09.480 --> 00:25:12.557
And when you run dnf update, it looks at
all the packages you have installed and

482
00:25:12.557 --> 00:25:14.151
it looks to see if there's any updates.

483
00:25:14.151 --> 00:25:15.707
And sure enough, there's some updates.

484
00:25:15.707 --> 00:25:17.818
Actually, it looks like there's
a kernel update that I need to do.

485
00:25:17.818 --> 00:25:21.690
So there's update, and I can apply
those and it'll get them put in place.

486
00:25:21.690 --> 00:25:23.900
All these updates are coming
from Fedora right now.

487
00:25:23.900 --> 00:25:26.640
But you might see some coming from
your third party repositories as those

488
00:25:26.640 --> 00:25:29.890
updates come along and
you apply them right from here.

489
00:25:29.890 --> 00:25:32.265
So once that's done, you're up and going.

490
00:25:32.265 --> 00:25:34.070
You've got your software,
and you're in business.

491
00:25:34.070 --> 00:25:38.490
You do need to remember to periodically
run the updates just to check them and

492
00:25:38.490 --> 00:25:39.580
make sure they work.

493
00:25:39.580 --> 00:25:40.616
>> Fantastic information, Don.

494
00:25:40.616 --> 00:25:41.510
You did a great job.

495
00:25:41.510 --> 00:25:43.019
Anything else you wanna leave us with?

496
00:25:43.019 --> 00:25:46.328
>> There does come a time where you
don't need software anymore, right?

497
00:25:46.328 --> 00:25:47.780
I installed Webmin a second ago.

498
00:25:47.780 --> 00:25:48.730
It was kinda broken.

499
00:25:48.730 --> 00:25:49.980
And I don't actually want it.

500
00:25:49.980 --> 00:25:51.400
So, I wanna remove it from my system.

501
00:25:51.400 --> 00:25:54.220
So you can remove software
using dnf just as well.

502
00:25:54.220 --> 00:25:55.123
Let me show you that real quick.

503
00:25:55.123 --> 00:25:59.125
>> Awesome.
>> I'll say sudo dnf remove webmin.

504
00:25:59.125 --> 00:26:01.783
And that's gonna reach right in there and
locate that package.

505
00:26:01.783 --> 00:26:07.159
And notice it's not just removing Webmin,
it's also removing pearl-Encode-Detect.

506
00:26:07.159 --> 00:26:09.716
It's saying,
we installed this dependancy for Webmin.

507
00:26:09.716 --> 00:26:12.825
And now that you're getting rid of Webmin,
you don't need that dependency anymore.

508
00:26:12.825 --> 00:26:14.335
So, let's get rid of that too.

509
00:26:14.335 --> 00:26:17.435
And so it's keeping track of all that and
it'll remove it.

510
00:26:17.435 --> 00:26:21.065
Now DNF does a really good
job of this stuff, okay?

511
00:26:21.065 --> 00:26:22.735
It keeps track of it very well.

512
00:26:22.735 --> 00:26:24.535
Yum not so much.

513
00:26:24.535 --> 00:26:26.855
Yum will oftentimes miss dependencies.

514
00:26:26.855 --> 00:26:29.235
And so, a lot of times with Yum,
I'll follow this up with one more command.

515
00:26:29.235 --> 00:26:31.710
I'll say sudoo yum autoremove.

516
00:26:32.790 --> 00:26:34.510
And under dnf, we don't really need that.

517
00:26:34.510 --> 00:26:36.250
But under Yum, that'll look for

518
00:26:36.250 --> 00:26:39.160
any dependencies that are no
longer attached to a package.

519
00:26:39.160 --> 00:26:41.630
And it'll get rid of those and
free up a little extra space,

520
00:26:41.630 --> 00:26:44.140
reduce your attack surface,
get rid of things that you don't need.

521
00:26:44.140 --> 00:26:48.290
So, I don't need that, cuz I used DNF,
but if you do, you've got that.

522
00:26:48.290 --> 00:26:51.660
Also, I did sudo dnf remove.

523
00:26:51.660 --> 00:26:55.200
This is the one command that's
actually not compatible with Yum.

524
00:26:55.200 --> 00:26:55.796
Yum doesn't have remove.

525
00:26:55.796 --> 00:26:57.014
It has erase.

526
00:26:57.014 --> 00:27:03.380
So I would say sudo yum erase
webmin instead of sudo dnf remove.

527
00:27:03.380 --> 00:27:05.743
I don't know why they changed that name,
but they did.

528
00:27:05.743 --> 00:27:09.160
But erase is what we used under Yum.

529
00:27:09.160 --> 00:27:10.950
So, that's basically it.

530
00:27:10.950 --> 00:27:14.220
You can also work with more
than one package at a time.

531
00:27:14.220 --> 00:27:16.952
So if I wanted to get rid of webmin,
and vlc, and nano,

532
00:27:16.952 --> 00:27:22.240
typing's the hardest part,
I can do it like that.

533
00:27:22.240 --> 00:27:24.220
And it's gonna remove each one of them.

534
00:27:24.220 --> 00:27:25.820
So, you can install more than one package.

535
00:27:25.820 --> 00:27:27.915
You can remove more than one
package all at the same time.

536
00:27:27.915 --> 00:27:28.987
And that's all kinda built right in there.

537
00:27:28.987 --> 00:27:33.020
And it's ultimately how Yum and dnf work.

538
00:27:33.020 --> 00:27:34.444
>> Excellent job as usual, sir.

539
00:27:34.444 --> 00:27:36.581
Managing software with Yum and dnf.

540
00:27:36.581 --> 00:27:38.857
Becoming a Linux system administrator,

541
00:27:38.857 --> 00:27:41.529
there's a lot of content
in this video library.

542
00:27:41.529 --> 00:27:42.676
So you'll wanna check out all videos.

543
00:27:42.676 --> 00:27:44.662
You'll be very glad you did.

544
00:27:44.662 --> 00:27:46.762
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

545
00:27:46.762 --> 00:27:49.121
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

546
00:27:49.121 --> 00:27:50.226
I'm Zack Memos.

547
00:27:50.226 --> 00:27:51.071
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

548
00:27:51.071 --> 00:27:52.824
>> And we'll see you soon.

549
00:27:52.824 --> 00:27:58.513
[MUSIC]

550
00:27:58.513 --> 00:28:02.321
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:02.460
Welcome to ITPro.TV,

2
00:00:02.460 --> 00:00:06.294

3
00:00:06.294 --> 00:00:08.245
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.245 --> 00:00:12.007
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.007 --> 00:00:15.045
>> Hello again, and thank you for
joining us here on ITPro.TV,

6
00:00:15.045 --> 00:00:17.097
where we help you learn where ever you go.

7
00:00:17.097 --> 00:00:18.908
I'm your host Zach Memos,

8
00:00:18.908 --> 00:00:23.091
as we continue on with becoming
a Linux System Administrator.

9
00:00:23.091 --> 00:00:26.435
And the topic right now is
creating user accounts and

10
00:00:26.435 --> 00:00:31.050
the person bringing us all
the information we need is Don Pezet.

11
00:00:31.050 --> 00:00:32.360
Hey Don, thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:32.360 --> 00:00:33.258
You're awesome.
[LAUGH]

13
00:00:33.258 --> 00:00:34.237
>> Thanks for having me back, Zack.

14
00:00:34.237 --> 00:00:36.703
Get ready to dive into the world of
creating user accounts inside of Linux.

15
00:00:36.703 --> 00:00:39.852
And let's just start off real basic here
with why the heck do we even need these

16
00:00:39.852 --> 00:00:40.537
user accounts?

17
00:00:40.537 --> 00:00:41.214
>> Yeah.

18
00:00:41.214 --> 00:00:44.776
>> For a home user a lot of times,
you have a laptop or you have a desktop,

19
00:00:44.776 --> 00:00:47.020
and you are the only one that uses it.

20
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:49.440
But in a business environment, it is very,

21
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:53.140
very common to have shared machines
where more than one user uses them.

22
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:54.560
Or to have a centralized server,

23
00:00:54.560 --> 00:00:59.140
like a file server, where more than user
is accessing resources on that system.

24
00:00:59.140 --> 00:01:02.160

accounts that come into play.

468
00:24:44.130 --> 00:24:46.570
But as far as interactive users,
regular people,

469
00:24:46.570 --> 00:24:50.010
I think we've pretty much seen what's
our day to day operations, Matt.

470
00:24:50.010 --> 00:24:51.590
>> Don, I love listening to you.

471
00:24:51.590 --> 00:24:55.590
You're terrific, you make the
un-understandable, understandable, always.

472
00:24:55.590 --> 00:24:58.297
So becoming a Linux system administrator,
there's so

473
00:24:58.297 --> 00:25:00.032
much video content in this series.

474
00:25:00.032 --> 00:25:02.530
And you want to visit all of
those videos again and again.

475
00:25:02.530 --> 00:25:04.650
Check it all out, you'll be glad you did.

476
00:25:04.650 --> 00:25:07.570
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

477
00:25:07.570 --> 00:25:09.630
Remember, a good IT Pro's always learning.

478
00:25:09.630 --> 00:25:10.510
I'm Zach Memos.

479
00:25:10.510 --> 00:25:11.039
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

480
00:25:11.039 --> 00:25:13.617
And we'll see you again real soon.

481
00:25:13.617 --> 00:25:19.700
[MUSIC]

482
00:25:19.700 --> 00:25:26.989
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss why we need groups, how we create them, how we use them, and how as an administrator we can access info to see what groups a user is part of.
episodes.title: Understanding Group Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.304
Welcome to IT Pro IT.

2
00:00:01.304 --> 00:00:08.233
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:10.120
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:10.120 --> 00:00:13.640
>> Hello again and thank you for

5
00:00:13.640 --> 00:00:17.330
joining us at IT Pro TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.330 --> 00:00:20.740
I"m your host Zach Mennis as we
continue on with becoming a Linux

7
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:22.530
system administrator.

8
00:00:22.530 --> 00:00:26.400
And right now we're gonna take
a look at creating group accounts

9
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:27.700
with our very own Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.700 --> 00:00:29.050
Don, thanks for joining us again.

11
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:32.350
>> And my pleasure, ready to
continue on working with our, well,

12
00:00:32.350 --> 00:00:33.590
we were doing user accounts before.

13
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:36.800
Now we're gonna do groups, which really
go hand-in-hand with user accounts.

14
00:00:36.800 --> 00:00:39.010
So we're going to learn little
bit of groups, and how we can,

15
00:00:39.010 --> 00:00:42.960
basically collect users together, into
these single entities that are groups, and

16
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:46.240
make use of those, for, well all
sorts of crazy things, really handy.

17
00:00:46.240 --> 00:00:48.920
So, if you ever find yourself
doing some repetitious task,

18
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:52.650
like assigning permissions to users over
and over and over again, we can take

19
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:56.780
a group and collect those people together
and now we can just do things once.

20
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.160
Groups are really handy,

21
00:00:58.160 --> 00:01:01.220
we're gonna get a chance to see how to
do all that right here in this episode.

22
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:03.160
>> So that's basically why we need groups,
right?

23
00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:06.810
Because it just saves you time and
energy and resources?

24
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:07.780
>> It's one of the main reasons.

25
00:01:07.780 --> 00:01:11.420
So groups are absolutely handy
when it comes to saving us time.

26
00:01:11.420 --> 00:01:14.040
So as an administrator
if I have 50 users and

27
00:01:14.040 --> 00:01:16.370
I wanna give them all
permission to a single folder.

28
00:01:16.370 --> 00:01:20.400
I could go one by one and
give each of them permissions, right, or

29
00:01:20.400 --> 00:01:23.940
I could put them all in a group and
give them permissions one time.

30
00:01:23.940 --> 00:01:27.950
Well, that's a nice thing, that's a time
saving feature but there's also a kind of

31
00:01:27.950 --> 00:01:33.140
a forced requirement here because remember
in the Unix world when we set permissions,

32
00:01:33.140 --> 00:01:35.750
there's really only three
entities we give permissions to.

33
00:01:35.750 --> 00:01:41.080
There's the owner, there's the group,
and there's everyone else, right.

34
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:44.850
So there's only one owner and
there's only one group.

35
00:01:44.850 --> 00:01:48.730
And so if I have 50 users,
can I even have 50 owners?

36
00:01:48.730 --> 00:01:50.380
No, you can only have one owner.

37
00:01:50.380 --> 00:01:54.950
And so I have to use a group to assign
permissions that way if I wanna give all

38
00:01:54.950 --> 00:01:55.900
these people access.

39
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:58.360
Or, otherwise,
I have to use the everyone category.

40
00:01:58.360 --> 00:01:59.810
And now it's not just those 50 users.

41
00:01:59.810 --> 00:02:02.370
It's everyone,
even people outside of that 50 years.

42
00:02:02.370 --> 00:02:04.270
So there are scenarios,

43
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:07.460
when we're trying to assign permissions,
where groups are the only option.

44
00:02:07.460 --> 00:02:10.510
So it's not a, I'm just using
groups to save time kind of thing.

45
00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:13.960
It's a, I'm using groups cuz this is
the only [LAUGH] way to achieve my goal.

46
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:17.510
So those are great examples right
there of how we might use that,

47
00:02:17.510 --> 00:02:20.440
and I'll show you some of
that as the episode goes on.

48
00:02:20.440 --> 00:02:23.830
>> So, the next basic questions is
how do we create group accounts?

49
00:02:23.830 --> 00:02:25.620
>> All right, it's actually pretty easy.

50
00:02:25.620 --> 00:02:28.560
We've got a couple of standard UNIX
command line utilities we can use to

51
00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:29.540
whip these up.

52
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:32.010
You might have a GUI available for groups.

53
00:02:32.010 --> 00:02:35.490
Actually I'm running Fedora Workstation
here and it does not have a GUI for

54
00:02:35.490 --> 00:02:36.250
creating groups so

55
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:38.320
I'm gonna have to go to the command
line on this one no matter what.

56
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:40.670
But some distros do have a GUI for it.

57
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:42.720
But the command line utilities
are pretty simple and

58
00:02:42.720 --> 00:02:44.110
you know they're going to be there.

59
00:02:44.110 --> 00:02:46.060
So they're the way that you really
wanna learn if you're gonna

60
00:02:46.060 --> 00:02:47.200
be a system hand man.

61
00:02:47.200 --> 00:02:51.240
And for creating the group we
just have the group add command.

62
00:02:51.240 --> 00:02:55.770
Now if you watched our user episode,
there was the user add command, group add,

63
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:56.680
very similar.

64
00:02:56.680 --> 00:02:59.480
If you run group add you'll see
it's got a couple of options here,

65
00:02:59.480 --> 00:03:02.630
most of which we don't
really need to specify.

66
00:03:02.630 --> 00:03:04.545
You'll see things in
here like the group ID.

67
00:03:04.545 --> 00:03:08.263
And the group ID number we don't normally
care about unless we're trying to

68
00:03:08.263 --> 00:03:10.364
synchronize ID numbers between servers.

69
00:03:10.364 --> 00:03:13.220
We don't normally worry about it, so
it'll be automatically generated.

70
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:16.920
The password, we don't normally
worry about a password on a group,

71
00:03:16.920 --> 00:03:19.600
because nobody logs in as the group.

72
00:03:19.600 --> 00:03:22.480
They log in as themselves, and
then they're a part of the group.

73
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:25.130
So we don't normally
even worry about that.

74
00:03:25.130 --> 00:03:29.880
We might choose to tie
a group to a directory or

75
00:03:29.880 --> 00:03:34.060
something, but, most of the time,
we don't need any of these options.

76
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:37.020
We really just need group add,
followed by a name.

77
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:38.950
Now, I do need to be
an administrator to add groups, so

78
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:43.130
I'm going to sudo, group add, and
whatever I want to call it, right.

79
00:03:43.130 --> 00:03:47.500
Maybe I have a sales team, so
I'm gonna create a group called sales.

80
00:03:47.500 --> 00:03:50.670
There, easy enough, or if I'm
a marketing team I might come in and

81
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:54.340
say group add marketing and
I run it, there.

82
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:57.748
We keep going on with however
many groups it is that we need,

83
00:03:57.748 --> 00:04:02.722
maybe these are job titles, right, but you
might be doing it based on permissions, so

84
00:04:02.722 --> 00:04:06.061
I might say something like
group add allowed to print, and

85
00:04:06.061 --> 00:04:09.020
these are gonna be people
who are allowed to print.

86
00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:09.880
Anybody in this group,

87
00:04:09.880 --> 00:04:12.930
I'll give permission to be able to print
to a printer or something of that sort.

88
00:04:12.930 --> 00:04:14.380
So you just go through and

89
00:04:14.380 --> 00:04:18.850
you create each of the groups that
you need, a very simple process.

90
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:23.306
And all of these groups are being created
and stored away in a file inside of

91
00:04:23.306 --> 00:04:28.335
/etc/groups, just like /etc/passwd
is where our users go.

92
00:04:28.335 --> 00:04:30.870
/etc/groups where the groups go.

93
00:04:30.870 --> 00:04:33.300
So they're getting kind
of tucked away in there.

94
00:04:33.300 --> 00:04:35.530
Now when I create a group,

95
00:04:35.530 --> 00:04:40.400
it's not incredibly useful because
there's not anybody in the group, right?

96
00:04:40.400 --> 00:04:45.704
If I were to go in and look at /etc/group.

97
00:04:46.800 --> 00:04:49.430
And look in that file,
here's all the groups on my system.

98
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:52.850
And here's sales,
marketing and allowed to print.

99
00:04:52.850 --> 00:04:55.070
The three that I just created, okay?

100
00:04:55.070 --> 00:04:57.200
So that was /etc/group.

101
00:04:57.200 --> 00:05:00.060
Well right now nobody's in them.

102
00:05:00.060 --> 00:05:04.800
See how it's sales followed by an x cuz I
didn't assign a password followed by 1,003

103
00:05:04.800 --> 00:05:09.570
that's the group ID and then it's
followed by the people who were in it.

104
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:12.130
And nobody's in it, so
when you create a group.

105
00:05:12.130 --> 00:05:16.160
The logical next step is to
put people in the group and

106
00:05:16.160 --> 00:05:19.950
we put people in the group
by using a strange command.

107
00:05:19.950 --> 00:05:24.910
It's a gpasswd okay,
pass wd is a command we

108
00:05:24.910 --> 00:05:30.120
can use to change somebody's password,
gpasswd let's us change the group.

109
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:33.030
Now, why gpasswd?

110
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:37.490
Well I showed you /etc/group,

111
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:40.860
but groups are actually tracked
in a few different places.

112
00:05:40.860 --> 00:05:47.730
If you look inside of /etc/ /passwd,

113
00:05:47.730 --> 00:05:53.660
when you look at individual users, like my
user account right here, dpezet, right?

114
00:05:53.660 --> 00:05:55.670
I am in my own group.

115
00:05:55.670 --> 00:05:59.300
I have my UID, my user ID and my group ID.

116
00:05:59.300 --> 00:06:01.460
I'm in group ID 1000, okay?

117
00:06:01.460 --> 00:06:06.650
So I can see that I'm in this other group,
right.

118
00:06:06.650 --> 00:06:09.330
So groups actually participate
here inside the passwd

119
00:06:09.330 --> 00:06:12.070
just as much as they do in
some of the other files.

120
00:06:12.070 --> 00:06:14.730
And so that's why it get's kinda
grouped together on the same command.

121
00:06:14.730 --> 00:06:18.720
But I can come through and
I can take gpasswd and

122
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:21.530
I can assign people to a group.

123
00:06:21.530 --> 00:06:28.150
So for example if I want to I want to
add a user, I would say dash a and I

124
00:06:28.150 --> 00:06:33.190
would specify the user that I want to add
and the group that I want to add them to.

125
00:06:33.190 --> 00:06:36.660
So, maybe I want John Doe to be in sales.

126
00:06:36.660 --> 00:06:40.130
So, I would say dash a J Doe sales.

127
00:06:40.130 --> 00:06:41.730
I'm going to add him to sales.

128
00:06:42.760 --> 00:06:46.020
So, now it's adding user
J Doe to group sales.

129
00:06:46.020 --> 00:06:46.910
And then I can come through and

130
00:06:46.910 --> 00:06:50.660
I could say, add jsmith,
I wanna add Jane to marketing.

131
00:06:51.750 --> 00:06:52.730
And so I'll punch that one in.

132
00:06:52.730 --> 00:06:55.420
And so now she is being added
to marketing, all right?

133
00:06:55.420 --> 00:06:57.890
Now let's take a look at what that did.

134
00:06:57.890 --> 00:07:04.980
If I take a look at /etc/passwd,
and I find Jane and John.

135
00:07:04.980 --> 00:07:07.030
They haven't changed here, right?

136
00:07:07.030 --> 00:07:12.110
Their primary group is still set to
what it was before, I didn't change

137
00:07:12.110 --> 00:07:16.770
their primary group, I changed their
secondary group, groups their a member of.

138
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:22.260
And you don't see that here, but
if I look inside of a /etc/group,

139
00:07:22.260 --> 00:07:26.430
and I take a look at this,
I can see the end of sales.

140
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:27.190
There's John Doe.

141
00:07:27.190 --> 00:07:29.740
And at the end of marketing,
there's Jane Smith.

142
00:07:29.740 --> 00:07:32.620
And if I want to add Jane to
sales as well I can do that.

143
00:07:32.620 --> 00:07:34.250
Somebody can be in more than one group.

144
00:07:34.250 --> 00:07:38.310
So I might want to add Jane to sales,
right?

145
00:07:38.310 --> 00:07:45.050
And then if I go and
take a look at /etc./group.

146
00:07:45.050 --> 00:07:50.070
I can see where I've got the sales
group John Doe and Jane Smith.

147
00:07:50.070 --> 00:07:51.757
See how they're separated by commas.

148
00:07:51.757 --> 00:07:54.756
You can have a whole list of
users that are in that group.

149
00:07:54.756 --> 00:07:56.719
Jane is in marketing and sales.

150
00:07:56.719 --> 00:07:58.966
John is just in sales.

151
00:07:58.966 --> 00:08:02.557
So now when I assign permissions there
might be things that I want marketing

152
00:08:02.557 --> 00:08:05.931
people to get to and there might be
things I want sales people to get to.

153
00:08:05.931 --> 00:08:10.218
Jane will be able to get to both but John
will only be able to get to the things

154
00:08:10.218 --> 00:08:12.776
that the sales department can get to,
and so

155
00:08:12.776 --> 00:08:17.040
that is all kind of being broken
up here by using G passed WD.

156
00:08:17.040 --> 00:08:22.213
Now when I did that I did G passed WD
with a dash a with a lower case A.

157
00:08:22.213 --> 00:08:25.570
That is just adding a regular user,
you can do -a with a capital A.

158
00:08:25.570 --> 00:08:29.360
And that's adding an administrative user,
right?

159
00:08:29.360 --> 00:08:32.176
An administrative user is not
an an administrator on your system.

160
00:08:32.176 --> 00:08:33.610
They're the administrator for that group.

161
00:08:33.610 --> 00:08:36.700
And that means, they can add people
to the group and take people out.

162
00:08:36.700 --> 00:08:39.820
So the sales department might actually
have somebody who's pretty savvy.

163
00:08:39.820 --> 00:08:42.471
And you want them to be able to manage
who's in the group on their own without

164
00:08:42.471 --> 00:08:43.530
bugging you.

165
00:08:43.530 --> 00:08:45.680
So you can add them using dash capital A,

166
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:49.350
and they still get added to the group like
normal, but now they're administrator and

167
00:08:49.350 --> 00:08:54.050
they have the ability to actually
change the membership of that group.

168
00:08:54.050 --> 00:09:00.900
Along the same lines, I'm using g past
wd dash a, I could use g past wd dash d.

169
00:09:00.900 --> 00:09:03.020
To delete or remove a user from a group.

170
00:09:03.020 --> 00:09:05.590
So I could take Jane right
back out of the sales group.

171
00:09:05.590 --> 00:09:06.730
And when I do that,

172
00:09:06.730 --> 00:09:11.060
now she's out of the sales group and
she's just in marketing again.

173
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:16.386
So easy enough to add people in and take
people out by using gpas wd -a and -d.

174
00:09:16.386 --> 00:09:18.610
I always think of it as add and delete.

175
00:09:18.610 --> 00:09:19.310
But it's actually.

176
00:09:19.310 --> 00:09:22.030
I think it's -a is short for
append, if I remember right.

177
00:09:22.030 --> 00:09:24.090
But I always think of it as add and
delete, cuz that's what you're doing.

178
00:09:24.090 --> 00:09:26.600
You're adding people to the group and
deleting people out of it.

179
00:09:26.600 --> 00:09:29.790
>> So John, now that we have the groups
all set up, how do we use them?

180
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:31.760
>> Okay, so now that we got the groups.

181
00:09:31.760 --> 00:09:33.520
They don't actually do
anything by default.

182
00:09:33.520 --> 00:09:35.315
So what I've done is wasted our time.

183
00:09:35.315 --> 00:09:38.810
[LAUGH] I created the groups,
they do nothing.

184
00:09:38.810 --> 00:09:39.720
>> Just for fun.

185
00:09:39.720 --> 00:09:42.250
>> So
I need to find out how I'm gonna use them.

186
00:09:42.250 --> 00:09:45.130
So I mentioned for example that I might
have folders that I want the salespeople

187
00:09:45.130 --> 00:09:48.100
to get to and folders that I want
the marketing people to get to.

188
00:09:48.100 --> 00:09:50.980
Well, I would need to
create those folders.

189
00:09:50.980 --> 00:09:56.740
So for
example maybe on my storage drive here I'm

190
00:09:56.740 --> 00:10:01.420
gonna make a directory
called Corp docs right.

191
00:10:01.420 --> 00:10:06.510
This will be my corporate documents folder
and I'm gonna share this folder out so

192
00:10:06.510 --> 00:10:07.800
the company can get o it.

193
00:10:07.800 --> 00:10:10.210
So I want people to be able to browse
trough this corps doc folder and

194
00:10:10.210 --> 00:10:11.200
get to things.

195
00:10:11.200 --> 00:10:18.680
And inside of that folder maybe I create
a sales folder and a marketing folder.

196
00:10:18.680 --> 00:10:21.790
And in those folders are where I'm
gonna put the sales documents and

197
00:10:21.790 --> 00:10:23.400
the marketing documents and so on.

198
00:10:23.400 --> 00:10:27.600
Well, I'm making this stuff, so
if I take a look at this with permissions,

199
00:10:27.600 --> 00:10:31.890
I'll see marketing has a default.

200
00:10:31.890 --> 00:10:33.860
Set of permissions and so does sales.

201
00:10:33.860 --> 00:10:36.555
And the default permissions were,
shoot, I'm still logged in as root.

202
00:10:36.555 --> 00:10:39.530
[LAUGH] So, I just noticed I was
logged in as the wrong user.

203
00:10:39.530 --> 00:10:40.380
>> Rooty toot toot.

204
00:10:40.380 --> 00:10:42.368
>> Yeah, I elevated to root I
think at the last episode and

205
00:10:42.368 --> 00:10:43.457
I guess I just stayed as root.

206
00:10:43.457 --> 00:10:46.580
So whoever creates it though is the owner.

207
00:10:46.580 --> 00:10:48.330
So I guess this kinda reinforces my point.

208
00:10:48.330 --> 00:10:52.030
The owner here is root,
and the group is root.

209
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:54.520
And so it's telling me that
the root user has read, write, and

210
00:10:54.520 --> 00:10:57.110

00:23:02.170 --> 00:23:03.640
So if you've got 500 machines out there.

434
00:23:03.640 --> 00:23:06.000
That's a lot of groups
that you'd have to manage.

435
00:23:06.000 --> 00:23:09.190
So you may also incorporate
a centralized directory,

436
00:23:09.190 --> 00:23:11.230
which we're gonna cover
in an upcoming episode.

437
00:23:11.230 --> 00:23:13.130
In the next one or two episodes.

438
00:23:13.130 --> 00:23:16.124
So bear in mind that you may
have centralized groups.

439
00:23:16.124 --> 00:23:19.840
But everything we saw right here were
groups managed on an individual system.

440
00:23:19.840 --> 00:23:21.420
Pretty straightforward,
pretty easy to work with.

441
00:23:21.420 --> 00:23:24.460
Just keep track of it and always remember
to pay attention to your context.

442
00:23:24.460 --> 00:23:27.220
Like I messed up and I stayed logged
in as root there for a minute.

443
00:23:27.220 --> 00:23:30.510
And it was messing up the context of
some of the files that I was creating.

444
00:23:30.510 --> 00:23:34.128
So don't hesitate to use the chown
command liberally to go in and

445
00:23:34.128 --> 00:23:36.206
fix anything you screw up like I did.

446
00:23:36.206 --> 00:23:38.035
[LAUGH]
>> C-H-O-W-N.

447
00:23:38.035 --> 00:23:40.322
Being a Linux system administrator,

448
00:23:40.322 --> 00:23:44.980
there is a lot of video in this library
of information, so check them all out.

449
00:23:44.980 --> 00:23:46.170
You'll be very glad you did.

450
00:23:47.600 --> 00:23:49.440
And thank for watching ITPro TV.

451
00:23:49.440 --> 00:23:52.330
Remember a good IT Pro is always learning.

452
00:23:52.330 --> 00:23:53.360
I'm Zach Memos.

453
00:23:53.360 --> 00:23:54.250
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

454
00:23:54.250 --> 00:23:57.270
>> And we'll see you again very soon.

455
00:23:57.270 --> 00:24:03.296
[MUSIC]

456
00:24:03.296 --> 00:24:06.397
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.title: Advanced Permissions

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what partitioning systems are, why they are useful, MBR partitions, GPT partitions, how to use these systems, partitioning an MBR disk, using 'Gdisk' for GPT disks, and other tools to use for partitioning,
episodes.title: Partitioning Disks

1

watching ITPRO.TV,

5
00:00:14.870 --> 00:00:16.748
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.748 --> 00:00:18.303
My name is Zack Memos, and

7
00:00:18.303 --> 00:00:23.432
I'm your host as we continue on with
becoming a Linux System Administrator.

8
00:00:23.432 --> 00:00:26.121
We're gonna be looking at
partitioning disks in this episode.

9
00:00:26.121 --> 00:00:30.071
And the person bringing us all the
information we need is the one, the only,

10
00:00:30.071 --> 00:00:30.700
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:30.700 --> 00:00:31.390
Hey Don.
[LAUGH]

12
00:00:31.390 --> 00:00:33.098
>> [LAUGH] Now I feel like I've got

13
00:00:33.098 --> 00:00:35.045
to live up to that amazing intro.

14
00:00:35.045 --> 00:00:35.829
>> [SOUND]
>> So

15
00:00:35.829 --> 00:00:39.000
we are back again with another
episode of Linux System Administrator.

16
00:00:39.000 --> 00:00:42.035
And we're gonna be taking
a look at partitioning disks.

17
00:00:42.035 --> 00:00:45.900
It's a pretty important task, it's one
we don't perform every day, right?

18
00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:48.454
Normally we get a new disk,
we partition it, and that's it,

19
00:00:48.454 --> 00:00:49.693
we don't mess with it again.

20
00:00:49.693 --> 00:00:52.773
But it is important to understand how
to do it, how to partition the disk,

21
00:00:52.773 --> 00:00:54.779
some of the different
options that we've got.

22
00:00:54.779 --> 00:00:57.740
The gotchas that we have, and
make sure that we do it correctly.

23
00:00:57.740 --> 00:01:01.220
Because while we usually only do it once,
if you ever have to change it,

24
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:03.466
it's actually a super big pain.

25
00:01:03.466 --> 00:01:06.170
So we don't wanna have to change
these things, if we don't have to, so

26
00:01:06.170 --> 00:01:08.390
making the right decisions in
the beginning is really important.

27
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:10.730
So in this episode, we're gonna
give you the chance to see that.

28
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:13.514
How to get the foot in place, and
how to make those right decisions.

29
00:01:13.514 --> 00:01:15.165
>> Don, didn't we, and
not to be redundant,

30
00:01:15.165 --> 00:01:17.790
because I'm gonna be the department
of redundancy department.

31
00:01:17.790 --> 00:01:20.910
But didn't we already talk about
partitioning disks during install

32
00:01:20.910 --> 00:01:21.920
when we talked about install?

33
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:22.597
>> We did, right?

34
00:01:22.597 --> 00:01:26.253
So during the installation episodes,
we did Fedora and Ubuntu,

35
00:01:26.253 --> 00:01:27.719
or whatever other OS's.

36
00:01:28.890 --> 00:01:31.750
We saw where there was the option to
automatically partition our disks,

37
00:01:31.750 --> 00:01:33.900
and that's great, right,
you can choose to do that.

38
00:01:33.900 --> 00:01:36.680
Or you can manually do it, and at that
time I believe I walked us through a few

39
00:01:36.680 --> 00:01:39.010
examples of manually
partitioning the disk.

40
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:40.870
But, in all those examples,

41
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:43.820
we're really running with just whatever
the Operating System was recommending.

42
00:01:43.820 --> 00:01:48.020
And there's plenty of times when we
need to go in, and do things ourselves.

43
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:49.520
In fact, with the installer,

44
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.810
it's only touching the drives
where you're installing Linux too.

45
00:01:52.810 --> 00:01:54.010
What if you have other drives?

46
00:01:54.010 --> 00:01:57.050
Right, like my laptop, for example,
where I have a 500 gig drive,

47
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:58.550
where my Operating System is.

48
00:01:58.550 --> 00:02:00.940
And then I have a one terabyte
drive where my data is.

49
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:03.776
Well, during the install,
if I pick the 500 gig drive,

50
00:02:03.776 --> 00:02:05.720
that's all that we're partitioning.

51
00:02:05.720 --> 00:02:08.170
We're not partitioning that one terabyte
drive, it's just sitting there.

52
00:02:08.170 --> 00:02:12.079
So now after the install is done, I've
gotta come in, partition that other disk.

53
00:02:12.079 --> 00:02:13.670
Get it formatted, get it mounted.

54
00:02:13.670 --> 00:02:17.080
Get it put where we need it to be, before
I can actually start to make use of it.

55
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:19.640
And I don't wanna throw a bunch of
data on there, and the decide yeah,

56
00:02:19.640 --> 00:02:21.210
I need to change that a little bit, right?

57
00:02:21.210 --> 00:02:23.605
So, that's stuff that doesn't
happen in the installer.

58
00:02:23.605 --> 00:02:24.642
So in this episode,

59
00:02:24.642 --> 00:02:29.480
we're gonna be even moving beyond just the
cookie cutter installation type template.

60
00:02:29.480 --> 00:02:32.700
And going a little more diverse with
some of the options that we've got.

61
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:35.712
>> And
there's a couple of different partitioning

62
00:02:35.712 --> 00:02:36.829
systems-
>> Yeah.

63
00:02:36.829 --> 00:02:38.100
>> Right, I mean.

64
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:41.680
>> Back in the olden days-
>> Back in the olden days.

65
00:02:41.680 --> 00:02:44.210
>> We have one partitioning
system that was really available,

66
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:45.970
it was the MBR system.

67
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:48.224
So you call it the MBR
partitioning scheme.

68
00:02:48.224 --> 00:02:50.230
MBR is Master Boot Record.

69
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:54.058
And the way it used to work was that
on every hard drive right at the very

70
00:02:54.058 --> 00:02:56.633
beginning of the disk
was a little partition.

71
00:02:56.633 --> 00:02:58.178
And I say little, it is really,

72
00:02:58.178 --> 00:03:01.340
really small, and
it was considered partition zero.

73
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:04.270
And that partition was
the master boot record.

74
00:03:04.270 --> 00:03:07.710
And all it did was keep track
of all of the other partitions.

75
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:10.522
So all the other divisions that were on
disk were kind of logged into this one.

76
00:03:10.522 --> 00:03:12.204
And that's why on MBR disks,

77
00:03:12.204 --> 00:03:15.670
the first partition that you
see is actually partition one.

78
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:17.100
And normally, in computers,

79
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:18.950
we always start with zero,
this is the one exception.

80
00:03:18.950 --> 00:03:22.040
Well it´s actually not an exception, zero
is referring to the master boot record.

81
00:03:22.040 --> 00:03:26.426
So that MBR system is what has
been used for a long, long time.

82
00:03:26.426 --> 00:03:31.371
It was developed in the late 1970s, early
1980s, it´s been around a long time, and

83
00:03:31.371 --> 00:03:32.017
it worked.

84
00:03:32.017 --> 00:03:33.061
Okay, right.

85
00:03:33.061 --> 00:03:35.554
>> [LAUGH]
>> I shouldn't say it in past tense,

86
00:03:35.554 --> 00:03:39.010
it still worked fine today, but
it has certain limitations.

87
00:03:39.010 --> 00:03:41.572
The biggest limitation
that the MBR system had,

88
00:03:41.572 --> 00:03:44.083
was that it could only
handle four partitions.

89
00:03:44.083 --> 00:03:47.048
Well, most of us get a hard drive and
you stick one partition on there and

90
00:03:47.048 --> 00:03:47.720
you're done.

91
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:50.320
So you never really run into that limit,
right?

92
00:03:50.320 --> 00:03:52.460
But if you need more than four,

93
00:03:52.460 --> 00:03:57.820
they use this really convoluted logical
kind of virtual partition scheme.

94
00:03:57.820 --> 00:04:00.780
So it would take the fourth partition, and

95
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:04.350
it would turn it into what was
called an extended partition.

96
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:07.280
And in that extended partition you could,
then start to create these logical

97
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:10.320
partitions to get beyond
that limit of four.

98
00:04:10.320 --> 00:04:13.860
It wasn't a good system, and so
most people don't like to use that.

99
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:16.217
If you have less than four partitions,
who cares, right?

100
00:04:16.217 --> 00:04:18.488
You go in and
create what are called primary partitions,

101
00:04:18.488 --> 00:04:20.060
you put them in there and you're done.

102
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:23.520
And honestly, that works for most people,
and so the master boot record model,

103
00:04:23.520 --> 00:04:26.950
the MBR model works fine, all right.

104
00:04:26.950 --> 00:04:30.792
But, by and large is being
replaced by a new technology,

105
00:04:30.792 --> 00:04:34.886
which is called the GPT,
which is the GUID Partition Table.

106
00:04:34.886 --> 00:04:39.650
And what the GUID partition table does,
is it takes these partitions.

107
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:41.730
And instead of assigning them a number,

108
00:04:41.730 --> 00:04:44.495
it assigns them
a Global Unique Identifier, a GUID.

109
00:04:44.495 --> 00:04:49.101
And because it's doing that, it's not
limited to four partitions, in fact,

110
00:04:49.101 --> 00:04:51.383
it can handle hundreds of partitions.

111
00:04:51.383 --> 00:04:52.703
>> Good.
>> Tons of partitions,

112
00:04:52.703 --> 00:04:56.303
without any crazy magic,
extended virtual whatever mess,

113
00:04:56.303 --> 00:04:58.925
it's just used as a different identifier.

114
00:04:58.925 --> 00:05:01.399
It's kind of like when we went
from 32 bit to 64 bit computers,

115
00:05:01.399 --> 00:05:02.646
now they can adjust more memory.

116
00:05:02.646 --> 00:05:07.685
Well GPT can adjust more partitions,
and so that's usually ideal.

117
00:05:08.905 --> 00:05:13.492
The default implementation of GPT
gives you up to 128 partitions.

118
00:05:13.492 --> 00:05:16.490
There are ways you can manipulate
it to go even beyond that.

119
00:05:16.490 --> 00:05:19.536
But if you have more than 128
partitions on a single disk,

120
00:05:19.536 --> 00:05:21.581
you've got a pretty unusual scenario.

121
00:05:21.581 --> 00:05:24.776
That's really really rare,
it gets rare to have more than two or

122
00:05:24.776 --> 00:05:26.560
three partitions on a normal disk.

123
00:05:26.560 --> 00:05:29.280
In the Linux world,
you might see eight to ten partitions,

124
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:30.980
depending on how you divide things up.

125
00:05:30.980 --> 00:05:34.500
But after that,
it's really uncommon to go more than that.

126
00:05:34.500 --> 00:05:37.200
So, GPT is really suitable for
most systems.

127
00:05:37.200 --> 00:05:42.050
Now, if that's the new technology,
why do we even care about MBR anymore?

128
00:05:42.050 --> 00:05:46.280
The main reason is,
not everything supports GPT, all right?

129
00:05:46.280 --> 00:05:49.550
Most modern Linux distros do, so if you're
running a Linux distribution that was

130
00:05:49.550 --> 00:05:53.140
released in the last four or five years,
you're likely gonna be okay.

131
00:05:53.140 --> 00:05:56.330
If you're running Windows, a version of
Windows in the last four or five years,

132
00:05:56.330 --> 00:05:57.470
you're gonna be okay.

133
00:05:57.470 --> 00:06:02.010
But if you have to support older Operating
Systems, they may not recognize GPT.

134
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:05.841
They may depend on MBR,
that master boot record being there, and

135
00:06:05.841 --> 00:06:08.790
if they're not there, they don't work.

136
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:11.960
An example of that would be like USB
keys that you plan on booting off of.

137
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:15.949
Those, typically require the MBR,
because the BIOS in most mother board,

138
00:06:15.949 --> 00:06:20.420
just doing the USB boot, is looking for a
master boot record, not looking for a GPT.

139
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:22.597
And so
then we get confused what we boot, so

140
00:06:22.597 --> 00:06:24.663
that an example where we bump in to that.

141
00:06:24.663 --> 00:06:28.199
Again, at the USB key not my
credit at that partitions anyway,

142
00:06:28.199 --> 00:06:29.620
MBR works just fine.

143
00:06:29.620 --> 00:06:32.270
So, that's one of the first
decisions we have to make.

144
00:06:32.270 --> 00:06:34.500
And if you think back to
those installation episodes,

145
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:39.830
when I was installing Fedora, did it
ask me if I wanted to go MBR or GPT?

146
00:06:39.830 --> 00:06:41.500
No, it just did it, right?

147
00:06:41.500 --> 00:06:43.601
I don't even think the option
shows up on the screen.

148
00:06:43.601 --> 00:06:47.510
So it just does it,
it sets a default based on the distro.

149
00:06:47.510 --> 00:06:50.680
But when we partition a disk ourself,
we get to choose.

150
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:54.230
We get to pick which of those
types we want to use, and

151
00:06:54.230 --> 00:06:55.620
get it set the way that we need it to.

152
00:06:55.620 --> 00:06:58.530
So, that's kind of a neat feature that
we have when we do this stuff by hand,

153
00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:00.520
and that's what we're gonna see here.

154
00:07:00.520 --> 00:07:05.560
>> So, how do we use the systems and
do they use different sets of tools?

155
00:07:05.560 --> 00:07:07.030
I mean, how does that all work?

156
00:07:07.030 --> 00:07:11.010
>> Yes, so in this case, there are
absolutely different sets of tools, right?

157
00:07:11.010 --> 00:07:12.680
When it comes to working with the MBR,

158
00:07:12.680 --> 00:07:16.650
the old style master boot record,
there's a utility called F Disk.

159
00:07:16.650 --> 00:07:18.990
And F Disk has been around forever.

160
00:07:18.990 --> 00:07:22.054
I cannot remember using a computer
that didn't have F Disk.

161
00:07:22.054 --> 00:07:24.375
Now, admittedly I'm not that old, and

162
00:07:24.375 --> 00:07:27.250
I started using computers in the late 80s,
so.

163
00:07:27.250 --> 00:07:29.592
But F Ddsk has been around a long,
long time.

164
00:07:29.592 --> 00:07:33.950
And it's designed to manipulate the master
boot record, that's what is does.

165
00:07:33.950 --> 00:07:35.950
So, let me just show you an example here.

166
00:07:35.950 --> 00:07:41.245
If I take this system, one of the most
basic examples of F disk is to run

167
00:07:41.245 --> 00:07:48.690
fdisk-l, which says, list for
me all of my disks and partitions, right?

168
00:07:48.690 --> 00:07:51.483
Now, every command I'm
gonna run in this episode,

169
00:07:51.483 --> 00:07:54.539
almost every command,
requires elevated privileges.

170
00:07:54.539 --> 00:07:55.872
So I'm gonna have to sudo everything.

171
00:07:55.872 --> 00:07:58.059
So to save a little bit of time,

172
00:07:58.059 --> 00:08:02.024
I'm gonna do a sudo-s And
switch over to the root user.

173
00:08:02.024 --> 00:08:04.816
And we don't normally want to be logged in
as the root user but I'm gonna to run so

174
00:08:04.816 --> 00:08:07.880
many administrative commands here that
is gonna make life a little easier.

175
00:08:07.880 --> 00:08:10.520
But just know out there in the real life,
in the real world,

176
00:08:10.520 --> 00:08:14.100
you'll need to do sudo for each of these
commands to elevate your privileges or

177
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:16.060
do what I'm doing and
switch to the root context.

178
00:08:16.060 --> 00:08:17.980
So I'm gonna run that fdisk -l and

179
00:08:17.980 --> 00:08:24.580
what it's gonna do is it's gonna give me
a list of all of the disks in my system.

180
00:08:24.580 --> 00:08:27.300
And I'm gonna see quite
a bit of stuff in here.

181
00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:32.120
And if I kinda scroll up,
what I'll see are not just the disks.

182
00:08:32.120 --> 00:08:34.840
But the partitions inside of them as well.

183
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:38.780
>> So for example, /dev/sda is
a 256 Gig drive on this system.

184
00:08:38.780 --> 00:08:42.540
>> Now this system's
actually a virtual machine.

185
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:45.130
It's running on my laptop but
it's not my actual laptop.

186
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:47.968
So this system's got a 256 Gig
drive that we boot off of.

187
00:08:47.968 --> 00:08:50.740
And that's /dev/sda.

188
00:08:50.740 --> 00:08:55.018
When hard drives are named, they're named
based on the type of drive they are and

189
00:08:55.018 --> 00:08:56.198
their order.

190
00:08:56.198 --> 00:09:01.590
So, SD is telling me that this is
a standard SATA disk vs a SCSI or

191
00:09:01.590 --> 00:09:04.610
an NVME or something else that
will have a different name and

192
00:09:04.610 --> 00:09:10.120
then a is letting me know that this
is the first SATA disk in my system.

193
00:09:10.120 --> 00:09:11.560
They're lettered like the alphabet, so

194
00:09:11.560 --> 00:09:16.480
the second one will be sdb which I can see
right here and then sdc and so on, right.

195
00:09:16.480 --> 00:09:18.450
So I'm seeing those disks.

196
00:09:18.450 --> 00:09:22.316
Now this first disk is already partitioned
cuz that's where my operating system is.

197
00:09:22.316 --> 00:09:28.591
And I can see that it's got two
partitions, /dev/sda1/dev/sda2.

198
00:09:28.591 --> 00:09:30.730
Notice that the partitions

There's a file called

00:27:47.020 --> 00:27:50.470
File system table,

00:27:51.780 --> 00:27:56.060

00:27:56.060 --> 00:27:58.770

00:27:58.770 --> 00:28:03.680
All those ones I just added they're not

00:28:03.680 --> 00:28:06.280

00:28:06.280 --> 00:28:08.390

00:28:08.390 --> 00:28:12.490

00:28:12.490 --> 00:28:15.710

00:28:15.710 --> 00:28:22.010

00:28:22.010 --> 00:28:25.480

00:28:25.480 --> 00:28:29.340

00:28:29.340 --> 00:28:30.257

00:28:40.137 --> 00:28:41.881
I don't remember how I

00:28:41.881 --> 00:28:43.110
I'll just make it up as I go here.

00:28:43.110 --> 00:28:46.100

00:28:46.100 --> 00:28:48.220
I do need it to tell it the file system,

00:28:48.220 --> 00:28:49.540
Well, that one is ext2.

00:28:49.540 --> 00:28:51.750
So I do need to know that.

00:28:51.750 --> 00:28:53.320

00:28:53.320 --> 00:28:55.050
You could provide all sorts

00:28:55.050 --> 00:28:57.180

00:28:57.180 --> 00:29:00.023

00:29:00.023 --> 00:29:03.110
That's really handy if you have like

577
00:29:03.110 --> 00:29:05.880
You can adjust how the caches work and
the buffers.

578
00:29:05.880 --> 00:29:08.110
You can set certain permissions,

00:29:08.110 --> 00:29:11.670
there's all sorts of crazy things

00:29:11.670 --> 00:29:13.738
But if you're just trying
to get the disk on line,
