00:29:13.738 --> 00:29:16.620
defaults is what we're normally
going to use, all right?

582
00:29:16.620 --> 00:29:20.570
These next two options aren't
really used all that much anymore.

583
00:29:20.570 --> 00:29:23.438
The first one is actually keyed
to a utility called dump,

584
00:29:23.438 --> 00:29:26.379
way back in the olden days there
was a utility called dump.

585
00:29:26.379 --> 00:29:29.510
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean, this is like 1970s.

586
00:29:29.510 --> 00:29:31.730
>> Way back in the olden days.

587
00:29:31.730 --> 00:29:35.160
>> And you would use the dump
utility to basically back up a disk.

588
00:29:35.160 --> 00:29:38.330
And if you had a one here

589
00:29:38.330 --> 00:29:41.620
that would say when you run dump
it's allowed to back up this disk.

590
00:29:41.620 --> 00:29:45.360
And if you had zero then when dump was
run it wouldn't back up this disk.

591
00:29:45.360 --> 00:29:48.306
Notice how the partition,
the swap drive, has a 0.

592
00:29:48.306 --> 00:29:50.290
No point in backing up a swap drive.

593
00:29:50.290 --> 00:29:52.050
But your other disks here have a 1.

594
00:29:52.050 --> 00:29:53.840
So you can set it to 1 if you want.

595
00:29:53.840 --> 00:29:57.416
The reality is nobody runs dump anymore,
so this is effectively useless.

596
00:29:57.416 --> 00:30:00.420
So it doesn't really matter if you put
0 or 1 here if you don't use dump.

597
00:30:00.420 --> 00:30:02.987
But if you want to air on the side of
safety you can stick a 1 on there and

598
00:30:02.987 --> 00:30:04.820
now the dump command will
be able to back this up.

599
00:30:04.820 --> 00:30:10.960
The next one is customizing the order
in which the file system check is run.

600
00:30:10.960 --> 00:30:13.080
When you boot your operating
system it looks for

601
00:30:13.080 --> 00:30:15.687
any corruption in the file system and
tries to fix any problems, right?

602
00:30:16.890 --> 00:30:20.266
And it focuses on the root drive first
because we need that to boot, and

603
00:30:20.266 --> 00:30:22.430
then all of the other drives second.

604
00:30:22.430 --> 00:30:25.040
So in here you can put
one of three values.

605
00:30:25.040 --> 00:30:25.980
You can put zero, one, or two.

606
00:30:25.980 --> 00:30:29.470
If you put zero,
that means don't do a file system check.

607
00:30:29.470 --> 00:30:30.095
That's not good.

608
00:30:30.095 --> 00:30:33.285
One means this is high priority,
I need to check it right away.

609
00:30:33.285 --> 00:30:37.550
Two means it's low priority,
you can check it whenever, right?

610
00:30:37.550 --> 00:30:42.375
According to standard,
you should have one for your root and

611
00:30:42.375 --> 00:30:43.880
two for everything else, right?

612
00:30:43.880 --> 00:30:46.640
Unless you don't want to check it and
then you can just leave it at zero, so

613
00:30:46.640 --> 00:30:47.500
it'll be one, zero.

614
00:30:47.500 --> 00:30:51.250
But all across the United, you'll find

615
00:30:51.250 --> 00:30:52.300
you can do that.

616
00:30:52.300 --> 00:30:53.760
One means the dump utility worked and

617
00:30:53.760 --> 00:30:56.790
the second one means check
this at the same time as root.

618
00:30:56.790 --> 00:30:59.010
And what that's gonna do is it's
gonna slow down your boot up.

619
00:30:59.010 --> 00:31:02.340
So if you don't care about boot time,
you can put one one in here and

620
00:31:02.340 --> 00:31:03.140
that'll be fine.

621
00:31:03.140 --> 00:31:06.320
But one two will make sure that you
can continue to boot while it's still

622
00:31:06.320 --> 00:31:08.610
file system checking this drive.

00:31:19.010 --> 00:31:23.130

in each one of these and

00:31:23.130 --> 00:31:26.770

00:31:28.260 --> 00:31:32.442

anytime I reboot these will

00:31:32.442 --> 00:31:34.501

00:31:34.501 --> 00:31:37.930

00:31:45.110 --> 00:31:49.120
So you can get in here and
punch those in, and

00:31:49.120 --> 00:31:53.330

00:31:53.330 --> 00:31:55.250
So now they're permanent.

00:31:55.250 --> 00:31:58.836

00:31:58.836 --> 00:32:01.557

00:32:01.557 --> 00:32:05.463

00:32:12.835 --> 00:32:15.725

00:32:29.200 --> 00:32:32.040

00:32:35.542 --> 00:32:38.545

00:32:47.020 --> 00:32:50.630

00:33:20.534 --> 00:33:22.907

00:33:22.907 --> 00:33:25.195

00:33:27.360 --> 00:33:30.960
